PARA.TAB: The PRESIDENT (Senator the Hon. Michael Beahan) took the chair at 9.30 a.m., and read prayers.

TALK.START.PARA: —Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows:

PETITION.TITLE: Family Law Act
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:

PARA.TAB: The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia draws to the attention of the Senate the need for changes to the Family Law Act of Australia and to the child support scheme.
Your petitioners therefore request that the Senate support the following changes.

PETITION.PARA: (1)That the existing Family Law Act be scrapped and replaced by a more simplified version together with the minimum of rules and regulations necessary.

(2)That the Family Court be replaced by a Tribunal and that all matters resulting from divorce and family breakdown be heard before, and determined by a panel; the panel to be made up of persons qualified in matters arising from family breakdown.
(3)That legal professionals be barred from appearing before the Tribunal resulting in vast savings to the disputing parties.
(4)That a modified fault clause be re-introduced to Family Law primarily designed to discourage adultery and to stop rewarding adulterers at the expense of deserted and innocent parties.
(5)That the Child Support Agency be scrapped and replaced by an appropriate administrative procedure within the Tribunal.
(6)That apart from cases of exceptional circumstances parental-child access become the inalienable right of all parents.

(7)That alternative counselling, (Government funded) be made available through the Churches and that much more emphasis be placed on mediation in resolving disputes prior to the commencement of legal proceedings.

PETITION.TITLE: Television Reception in Tasmania
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:

PARA.TAB: The petition of the undersigned shows that:

PETITION.PARA: 1.The UHF line-of-sight transmission is not suited to Tasmania's mountainous terrain.
2.It is unjust that compulsory UHF has resulted in poorer reception for many Tasmanians and that those living in weak "pockets" have outlaid of up to $450 in order to receive the signal.
3.It is unjust that many low-income Tasmanians and pensioners do not have the means to outlay hundreds of dollars so they can view their own television sets.
4.Compulsory UHF has resulted in some Tasmanians being denied a signal.

PARA.TAB: Your petitioners ask that the Senate, in Parliament assembled:
Call on the Government to:

PETITION.PARA: (a)honour its commitment to ensure that first class television reception is delivered to all the residents of Tasmania by providing additional funding for the urgent implementation of the necessary number of transmitters.
(b)provide all Tasmanians with access to their own national broadcasters, the ABC and the SBS.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade References Committee

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

PARA.TAB: That the following matters be referred to the Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade References Committee for inquiry and report on or before 5 December 1994:
(1)In relation to the death of Royal Australian Air Force (RAAF) Flight Lieutenant Glen Donovan in the crash of the Nomad aircraft A18-401 on 12 March 1990:

TAB.TAB: (a)whether the interests of the deceased and his family have been given adequate support by the Commonwealth;

(b)the failure of the Minister for Defence (Senator Ray) or the RAAF to pursue the question of individual responsibility for actions contributing to the failure to detect the dangerous condition of Nomad A18-401 in a defence force in which the highest levels of professional expertise and quality assurance are demanded;
(c)what action, if any, could still be taken against individuals alleged to have committed disciplinary offences in connection with the crash of Nomad A18-401;

(d)what amendments, if any, should be made to the Defence Force Discipline Act 1982 to ensure that statutory time limits cannot operate in the future to prevent disciplinary action where the alleged offences have led to the death or serious injury of defence force members; and

(e)whether the Ombudsman's recommendations in relation to the Civil Aviation Authority and Aerospace Technologies Australia Limited have been satisfactorily and fully implemented, and whether these organisations have properly addressed the issue of personal responsibility reasonably to be expected of their employees.

PARA.TAB: (2)In relation to the Ombudsman's investigation of the adequacy of the RAAF response to the loss of Nomad A18-401, whether reports of the Ombudsman of this kind should not be tabled in both Houses of Parliament as expeditiously as possible.

(3)Such other matters arising in the course of the committee's inquiry in relation to the crash and the Ombudsman's report as the committee determines are reasonably relevant to reporting on the foregoing terms of reference.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen C.V.

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the first report of the Parliamentary Joint Committee on Native Title, together with the Hansard record of the committee's proceedings.

PARA.TAB: Ordered that the report be printed.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the report.

SPEECH.PARA: This is the first report of the Parliamentary Joint Committee on Native Title. The report deals with our duties under section 206 of the Native Title Act, the first of which is to consult extensively with the community about the implementation of native title. The committee completed its first round of public consultations during August. This report is very much a record of those consultations and the evidence we received. I am pleased to say that the report is unanimous and it provides a snapshot of the developments and issues that have emerged concerning native title since the passage of the act.

PARA.TAB: It is important to note that we have not sought to fully assess the act because it is very much early days in the development of native title in this country. The committee took the opportunity to consult widely and travel around Australia to talk to people about native title, the act and related issues. Our intention was to consult rather than try to form definitive views on how the act was operating—and the report reflects that. For some people the report might be less controversial than they had hoped; but, as I say, it was a unanimous report of the committee and really just a reflection of those consultations.

There are a number of reasons why it is too early to make definitive judgments about the act. The first of those is that there have been surprisingly few claims lodged at this stage—certainly when the committee was taking evidence in August. Therefore, there has been very little progress in processing those claims. It is also worth noting that industry in general has shown a reluctance to make claims using the non-claimant application route provided in the legislation. So until they start to use that device more freely, developments in that area will be slow.

There are another couple of points worth mentioning in terms of why developments have not proceeded as quickly as some might have thought. There is a general wait and see approach to a number of test cases that are proceeding—particularly the Wik claim in Queensland, and a range of other cases. These cases will further develop the common law concept of native title.

One of the other issues is the long preparation time required for claims. A number of Aboriginal groups have expressed the view to the committee that they are working away at claims, but that the resources and time requirements of properly developing a claim are quite extensive. We expect to see more claims coming in over the next year or so.

Another point I would like to mention is that, despite the fact that a number of states have passed state legislation which sets up a sort of complementary regime to the Native Title Act, most of those have not yet been proclaimed; so the regimes under state legislation, provided for in the legislation, are not in place. That has also acted to slow developments compared with what might otherwise have been expected.

The other major issue is the fact that the Western Australian government is challenging the legislation in the High Court. That challenge will no doubt resolve a range of outstanding issues. Clearly, there is an impact on the community generally that leads people to wait to assess that High Court decision. That is also impacting on state governments. All those things are important in assessing the development of the progress under the act.

In Western Australia, where there are two competing regimes—the regime under the native title legislation and the regime under the Western Australian Land (Titles and Traditional Usage) Act—people are quite confused and unable to proceed with confidence. Until those issues are resolved, we will need to wait for that determination before we see a greater number of claims and progress with those claims, in Western Australia in particular.

Because of this experience a number of the views expressed to the committee reflected the positions people had expressed and adopted prior to the legislation being enacted. As I say, they have not had a great deal of practical experience of the act being in operation, and very much a `wait and see' approach has been adopted by a range of key groups.

I want to mention briefly a couple of matters that arise from the report. The first is that the President of the National Native Title Tribunal, Justice French, has set up liaison committees of industry and Aboriginal groups in each state. That has been a very good initiative in that it has allowed him to work through with those groups a range of issues and problems that were raised with the committee. We have found that a number of those issues have been resolved, at least partly, since our consultations, as he has worked with those industry and Aboriginal groups to refine processes and resolve some of the teething problems.

The second issue that I want to mention briefly is the need for resources for education about native title. By this, I am not suggesting a major PR campaign or television advertising campaign about native title, but there is a need for key groups, including Aboriginal groups, to be provided with more information and knowledge about native title. This includes groups which have not been directly involved to any great extent, such as local government, the tourism industry and other groups. There is a need for them to be provided with solid information and assistance in coming to terms with native title issues. Aboriginal groups and industry groups may also require assistance both in coming to terms with native title and in dealing with the implications of the act.

One of the other points I want to stress is that it is important that we provide resources to either the tribunal or some other group to make sure that communities which are affected by native title claims quickly get easily understandable information on the impact of those claims and the legal issues surrounding them. It is important that we have people on the ground who are able to talk to people about how native title claims may impact on them. That would help alleviate a lot of the fear and misunderstanding that could be associated with claims being lodged. It would be a very good pro-active move if we were to get out early into the community and provide that educative role. It will not resolve all the difficulties, but it will at least promote better understanding of the issues involved.

I also want to mention the issue of land tenure history and maps for dealing with native title claims. It has been a fairly widespread experience for industry and Aboriginal groups that land tenure information and mapping has been inadequate and that the costs of that are prohibitive. The president of the tribunal has been playing a role in trying to resolve that issue, but clearly the native title issue is placing demands on state government land administration in relation to this issue. Those problems need to be resolved to facilitate the purposes of the act and the resolution of native title claims.

Finally, I wish to place on record my thanks to the staff of the committee, who have worked very hard in coming to terms with this new native title concept and the demands of the committee I also thank the members of the native title committee, who, despite their quite different views on native title issues and the Native Title Act, worked very cooperatively. It has been a good learning experience for all of us who were involved in this initial round of consultations. Hopefully, the knowledge we have gained will be useful when we come to have a closer look at the provisions of the act in the coming years.

TALK.START.PARA: —To take the last point made by Senator Chris Evans, I thank the staff of the Joint Parliamentary Committee on Native Title, who did a tremendous job in our recent consultative process. I commend them for their assistance in relation to the preparation of this report. I also commend the input of fellow members of the committee in relation to the first interim report. This report succinctly sets out some of the issues that we are facing. Senator Evans has touched on those issues, and I might raise one or two in my address to the Senate today.

PARA.TAB: Firstly, I think that Mr Justice French is doing a very good job. The setting up of these liaison committees can iron out a lot of the wrinkles, so to speak. One of the criticisms has been the low threshold in accepting claims: that is, that a prima facie case does not necessarily have to be made out. It has been said that one could lodge anything with the Native Title Tribunal and it would be accepted. That is unfair. There is some uncertainty, however, and Mr Justice French has been on record as saying that an applicant is not required to establish a prima facie case in order to have an application accepted.

Evidence was given by the New South Wales land council that there has been a good deal of uncertainty in relation to exactly what is the position. The making out of a claim for native title is a very complex issue, and it places a great demand on the staff of the Native Title Tribunal in accepting evidence and determining what is proper evidence. As Senator Evans said, a demand has been made on the various state land administration departments. That matter will have to be addressed.

The matter of the non-claimant application has not provided the remedy that everyone thought it would. Certainly it has not been used by pastoralists or the mining sector, who have expressed concerns with the process. I recall that one witness highlighted the problem of having to go through the non-claimant process before anything else was done. That process held up any proposed activity or venture. The non-claimant process has some problems which need looking at. It has the potential to blow out and delay matters. It does not provide the quick result that some people said it would.

With respect to cooperation from the states, it was a shame that we did not hear from Queensland or New South Wales. The submission made by the Western Australian government was most helpful and that sort of cooperation is essential if this committee is to fulfil its task as outlined in the terms of reference. The situation in the Northern Territory has to be closely looked at. Without burdening the committee with too much work, that situation could merit attention some time in the future. Also, the South Australian situation should not be forgotten.

There is only so much that the committee can do. The committee covered a good deal of ground in going to Queensland, New South Wales and Western Australia. Nevertheless, there is still a good deal of uncertainty in relation to the act. It is some 10 months since we debated this legislation and I think many of us are none the wiser as to how it will affect the community in the fullness of time.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Forshaw Sen M.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Joint Committee of Public Accounts, I present the finance minute on the committee's report No. 326 on the Australian Taxation Office. I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the report.

SPEECH.PARA: I am pleased to be able to table on behalf of the Joint Committee of Public Accounts the finance minute in response to the committee's report No. 326 entitled An assessment of tax. It will be recalled that the committee tabled report No. 326 in November last year. The report contained 148 recommendations which were aimed at improving the administration of Australia's tax system. The committee's recommendations have been very favourably received by many individuals and organisations working in the tax profession. I am pleased to say that the government, too, has responded positively to the committee's recommendations.

PARA.TAB: In August this year the Assistant Treasurer, the Hon. George Gear MP, released the government's response to the 60 recommendations of the committee on matters of policy. The finance minute I have just tabled is the second and final part of the government's response to the report. The finance minute addresses the 88 recommendations of the committee which deal with administrative matters.

In summary, the vast majority of the committee's recommendations have been accepted and are being implemented. Some of the most significant policy recommendations agreed to by the committee are to establish the tax law improvement project, the aim of which is to rewrite and simplify the Income Tax Assessment Act 1936; to establish a small taxation claims tribunal to provide a cheap and streamlined review process for taxpayers with claims below $5,000; to sponsor the development of a charter of taxpayers' rights to better define the relationship between taxpayers and the Australian Taxation Office; to create a taxation ombudsman with the Office of the Commonwealth Ombudsman to provide a discrete and readily identifiable avenue of administrative review for taxpayers; and to publish rulings issued by the tax commissioner in the Commonwealth Gazette and to table them in parliament within five sitting days of publication.

The administrative recommendations accepted by the government cover such matters as encouraging the further development of the Australian Taxation Office's computer systems, particularly to allow external access to some databases; providing explanatory information which is well targeted, accurate and up to date; improving the quality of training for staff involved in tax audits; and restructuring the ATO and reorganising particular groups within the office. The measures contained in the finance minute in conjunction with those announced by the Assistant Treasurer will go a long way to ensuring that ordinary taxpayers are treated fairly, are clearly informed of their rights and have access to appropriate forms of administrative review.

I believe it is vitally important that the momentum for change which has been generated by the committee's inquiry and by the positive nature of the government's response is not lost. Therefore, over the next few months the committee intends to meet with the taxation commissioner, Mr Michael Carmody, to discuss the implementation of those recommendations which have been accepted and also to meet with the director of the tax law improvement project, Mr Brian Nolan, to discuss progress in the simplification of the Income Tax Assessment Act.

The rewrite of the tax act is a very significant undertaking, with potentially huge benefits for the Australian community. Although the early results from the improvement project are encouraging, I know that there are some in the tax profession who are concerned that the complexity of the tax laws will not be substantially reduced unless questions of tax policy are considered as they arise. The committee is inclined to agree that the best results will be achieved if the substantive provisions of the law are reviewed at the same time as the words are being redrafted. The work of the corporations law simplification program shows that such a task can be undertaken successfully.

In conclusion, as the finance minute acknowledges, the committee's report has created a real opportunity for change. I am pleased that the government and the tax office have shown a willingness to grasp the opportunity. The committee is hopeful that the changes being made will be to the benefit of all taxpayers.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Forshaw Sen M.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Joint Committee of Public Accounts, I present report No. 334 of the committee, entitled Annual report of activities. I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the report.

SPEECH.PARA: I am pleased to present to the Senate on behalf of the members of the Joint Committee of Public Accounts the committee's annual report of activities for 1993-94. This report, which is the 334th tabled by the committee since 1951, presents an overview of the committee's activities for the last financial year. The committee began the practice of presenting annual reports in parliament in 1976. Prior to that date, the committee regularly prepared indexes of committee reports for the information of parliament and, less frequently, tabled statements of committee activities and procedures.

PARA.TAB: The committee's decision to prepare annual reports was explained in the 1979 annual report in the following terms—and I quote from that report:

SPEECH.PARA: In reporting this way to Parliament, the Committee has recognised its responsibility as a statutory body to report on its activities. This Committee has always taken the view that bodies established by the Parliament should report to the Parliament and has been in the vanguard of encouraging increased standards and regularity in reporting.

That statement is as valid today as it was in 1979. The period 1993-94 was a year in which the committee tabled five reports, published a discussion paper in relation to its inquiry into the administration of Commonwealth-state agreements for specific purpose payments and gave its approval to a new set of annual report requirements for Commonwealth departments. The most significant of the reports tabled was undoubtedly report 326, An assessment of tax. The inquiry was a significant exercise which generated considerable attention within government circles and in the wider community. It is the committee's hope that its recommendations will lead to real improvements in the efficiency and effectiveness of Australia's tax system.

PARA.TAB: Other reports tabled by the committee in 1993-94 were: report 327, which contained the committee's comments on aspects of the finance minute in relation to the report of the Midford Paramount Inquiry; report 328, which was the committee's report of activities for 1992-93; report 329, which contained all the finance minutes presented in response to committee reports in the year 1993; and report 330, which presented the results of the committee's review of those reports of the Auditor-General which had been tabled in the period 1991-92.

One notable development in the last financial year has been the committee's decision to give a renewed focus to its statutory responsibility to examine reports of the Auditor-General. The committee believes this responsibility to be one of its most important duties. The committee has developed new procedures to allow it to report regularly to parliament on its examination of audit reports. These procedures are described in chapter 4 of the annual report.

Another highlight in the committee's year has been the approval of the new annual report requirements for departments. The new requirements state that an annual report must be tabled by 31 October and call for a much sharper focus on past year program performance rather than on administrative details.

For over 60 years the Joint Committee of Public Accounts has watched over the expenditure of public money by successive Commonwealth governments. I believe that the committee's work over the last 12 months has continued the tradition of helping to keep the executive accountable to parliament. I take this opportunity to thank the staff of the secretariat for their work in assisting the committee during the year. I commend the report to the Senate.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Joint Committee of Public Accounts, I present the Finance Minute on the committee's report No. 330—Auditor-General's reports—and move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the report.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.TITLE: BILLS RETURNED FROM THE HOUSE OF REPRESENTATIVES

PARA.TAB: The following bill was returned from the House of Representatives without amendment:
Excise Tariff Legislation Amendment Bill 1994.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Consideration of House of Representatives Message

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Zakharov)—The President has received a message from the House of Representatives returning to the Senate the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 3) 1994, agreeing to some amendments, disagreeing to others and making another amendment in place of a Senate amendment. The House of Representatives desires the reconsideration of the bill and requests the concurrence of the Senate in the amendment made by the House.
Motion (by Senator Faulkner) proposed:
That consideration of the message in committee of the whole be made an order of the day for a later hour of the day.

TALK.START.PARA: —We would require just a little bit longer time to consider this very important matter of the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 3) 1994 because there are widespread implications arising from the decision of the government virtually to reject the two very significant amendments moved by the opposition, one of which relates to sales tax. We are told that spare parts for goods re-manufactured outside Australia bear no sales tax and yet those re-manufactured in Australia attract a 21 per cent sales tax. That is a very significant amendment, given that the sales tax law of this country discriminates against Australian jobs and recycling—a matter which should be very close to Senator Faulkner's heart.

PARA.TAB: The other matter concerns the home child-care allowance, responsibility for the carriage of which rests with my colleague Senator Patterson. There are a lot of disgruntled people out there because of this particular measure. I believe that the government's attempt to ram it through the Senate today is just not good enough, so I seek a delay in the further consideration of this matter beyond this day.

TALKER.NAME: Senator FAULKNER
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I did not intend to cause Senator Watson such distress in this matter. This is the normal process for a motion before the Senate to keep a matter alive on the Notice Paper. I do believe that it is appropriate for the matter to be dealt with in this way; but I can tell Senator Watson that, obviously, there will be discussions between the opposition and other parties on when and where the matter is listed. This does have the effect, it is true to say, of keeping the option open for the matter to be debated today.

PARA.TAB: It would be the intention of the government to discuss with interested parties how we might deal with this. As Senator Watson knows, this is my approach to all matters that come before the chamber. I can say to Senator Watson that I think it would be useful to pass the motion in this form, which is not unusual. Discussions will occur between the whips as to how we might progress it at a later stage.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Watson is simply concerned that there is only one item down for government business, which is the ATSIC Amendment (Indigenous Land Corporation and Land Fund) Bill. Senator Watson makes the valid point that it is possible that this other matter, the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 3), could be brought on for reconsideration in committee of the whole at some stage this afternoon. That is what concerns Senator Watson. It would be fair to say that he would be happier if the motion made this an item of business for the next day of sitting, which would deal with our concerns.

PARA.TAB: It is unlikely that we will get through the ATSIC amendment bill today, anyway, in committee of the whole, as a substantial number of amendments have been brought before the chamber and they will require quite a long period of consideration. If Senator Faulkner amended his motion so that the bill is made an item of business for the next day of sitting, that would satisfy the opposition's concerns.
The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Zakharov)—Do you wish to move that amendment?

TALK.START.PARA: —We are happy to move an amendment, if Senator Faulkner will accept it.

TALKER.NAME: Senator FAULKNER
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I have moved the motion in the normal way and I have indicated that discussions will take place. I expect that most of today's business will be consumed with the ATSIC Amendment (Indigenous Land Corporation and Land Fund) Bill 1994. This is not an attempt to in some way spring a surprise on the opposition or any other senator in the chamber. It is the normal motion that is moved in these circumstances to keep the matter alive on the Notice Paper.

PARA.TAB: I have indicated that I would prefer to proceed with a motion in this form and for discussions, as they always do, to take place between the whips as to the scheduling of business. I am not going to die in the ditch about this. That is the proper and normal way of proceeding with a matter. I think it is sensible and I do not think it is appropriate to change our processes on this particular occasion.

TALK.START.PARA: —What is wrong with deferring it to the next day of sitting?

—I would like to keep the option open because negotiations are going on between the government, the opposition, the Democrats, the minor parties and the Independents now about the listing of the ATSIC amendment bill. I am not clear, as I stand here at 12 minutes past 10 in the chamber this Thursday morning, as to the status of those discussions. It may be that parties can agree that it is appropriate to bring this matter on today if those discussions that continue outside the chamber determine a particular course of action. It is a sensible and proper course of action. I think we can be comfortable with it and accept that, if the government plans to bring the matter on, there will certainly be discussion well in advance of that occurring.

—by leave—If Senator Faulkner's intention is not to spring any surprises but to keep the option open for possible negotiations, I believe the best way to deal with this matter is simply to list the bill as an item of business for the next day of sitting. If it is decided between the opposition, the government and anybody else who is involved in the bill that the bill should be dealt with today, the opposition will be quite happy—if it is agreed outside the chamber—for leave to be given for a motion to bring the item on early for consideration later today. I think that would give effect to the undertaking that Senator Faulkner has given.

PARA.TAB: What I am saying to Senator Faulkner is that if there are discussions taking place outside the chamber as to when this bill should be listed for consideration, and his intention is not to ambush the opposition, I suggest the best way to deal with it is to make the bill an item of business for the next day of sitting. If it is decided by all the parties concerned that we want to bring the item on earlier or later today, leave can be given for a motion to bring the item on early. That would deal with the concerns of both the government and the opposition, and I think that would be the best way to deal with the problem.

TALKER.NAME: Senator FAULKNER
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I cannot really add to what I have indicated. Discussions are occurring outside the chamber at the moment on this matter and on the ATSIC amendment bill. I am aware that there might be constraints on Senator Watson's time so I will try to be as flexible as I can, but I think this is really getting to the absurd stage.
—Who is creating the absurdity?

—You are. As I said, I have been perfectly reasonable in my approach to this matter. I have suggested a sensible and normal process which I would like to see embraced by the opposition. I am sensitive to the fact that certain honourable senators are paired later in the day. Those sorts of issues are of concern.

PARA.TAB: Having said that, I understand that there is a range of views about whether the ATSIC amendment bill should be brought forward, and we are trying to sort that out. That is the other factor in this equation. Clearly, that item is next on the Notice Paper. But there are only six of us the chamber at the moment, and the tick-tacking and negotiations are happening elsewhere. Senator Gareth Evans has just walked into the chamber, so I will sit down.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—We will not divide on this particular issue. We will take the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories (Senator Faulkner) at his word. However, I must say that I was rather distressed when the minister indicated in the course of the debate that he was not aware of the consequences, particularly the environmental consequences, of the legislation because it denies, through the tax system, real recycling opportunities.

PARA.TAB: Here we have the minister for the environment preaching the benefits of recycling when there is a proposal before him which he has not studied. We believe he needs the opportunity to examine this very closely because he has the capacity to change the government's mind on this particular issue. He therefore needs more time. However, if he wishes to push this thing through, I take him at his word that he will negotiate through the whips to ensure that the matter is not unnecessarily pushed through this chamber.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
The bill.

TALK.START.PARA: —I take it that we will be dealing with this bill clause by clause. It might be appropriate for me to ask whether it is the wish of the committee that we take the bill in the order shown on the running sheet.

DEBATE.TITLE: ATSIC AMENDMENT (INDIGENOUS LAND CORPORATION AND LAND FUND) BILL 1994

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Chairman, I think there is agreement around the chamber that that is the best way to proceed. There is a very large number of amendments for us to deal with in the course of this committee debate—I lost count of them after 120—so we have sought to consolidate them in accordance with the practice that we adopted during the debate on the native title legislation.

PARA.TAB: The amendments are grouped according to subject matter and will be dealt with together when that particular subject matter is first reached in the bill, even if it is not necessarily the most substantive treatment of the particular item. The point at which the particular subject matter first arises logically seems the best place to have the debate. To the extent that complementary or associated amendments are involved, it is the intention that they be dealt with at the same time, even though they may not be formally endorsed until the actual clause is later dealt with.

There are one or two exceptions to that principle in the running sheet which we will have to deal with when we find them, namely, where a particular amendment is foreshadowed, is referred to, but not intended to be debated at that point. The reference is to the matter being dealt with a little further down. By and large, the matter is dealt with where it first arises.

The amendments have been circulated around the chamber so far as the Greens are concerned. There is a bundle of opposition amendments which I think is just about to be circulated but has not yet got into formal circulation around the chamber. Similarly, with the Democrats' amendments, I think there are one or two last minute fiddles going on there and they are about to be circulated around the chamber.
Since the first couple of items involve Green amendments, I think we can, as soon as the Greens arrive—and that is one of the reasons for this extended procedural preamble—begin the debate.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why don't we shut down for half an hour?

—I think we are just about ready to go. There is no particular reason why we should defer it any longer. The government is certainly ready to go, even though we have had far and away the biggest task of trying to make sense of this sea of amendments. Under those circumstances, with Senator Chamarette now in the chamber and ready to start on the first Green amendment, which has been circulated around the chamber, I think we are ready to go.

—I understand there are some negotiations going on to put this off until 11 o'clock. The minister's office and my office are talking to each other, and I thought the PLO had given different instructions. Please tell us whether we are going to start immediately or not.
—As Senator Chamarette is ready, the question is that the title and clause 1 be agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chamarette Sen C.M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: 1.Title, page 1, omit the title, substitute the following title:
"An Act to establish a Land Fund and an Indigenous Land Corporation to help redress the dispossession of Aboriginal people and Torres Strait Islanders".
2.Clause 1, page 1, lines 3 to 7, omit the clause, substitute the following clause:

PARA.TAB: "1.(1) This Act may be cited as the Land Fund and Indigenous Land Corporation (ATSIC Amendment) Act 1994.

SPEECH.PARA: (2) In this Act, `Principal Act' means the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission Act 1989."

The Greens (WA) have proposed an amendment to the title because we feel that there are grave problems in presenting this bill without recognising the actual purpose for which at least the Prime Minister and the government say it is being set up. Instead of referring to it as the ATSIC Amendment (Indigenous Land Corporation and Land Fund) Bill 1994, which puts it in line with many other ATSIC amendment bills, we should have its clear and proper title at the front. Our substitute is:
An Act to establish a Land Fund and an Indigenous Land Corporation to help redress the dispossession of Aboriginal people and Torres Strait Islanders.

We feel that is a much better way of describing this bill because, firstly, that is what the government claims the act is being established for. Secondly, we think that the omission of the word `dispossession' from the legislation as it has been drafted is one that should be redressed immediately in its title.

PARA.TAB: If I may, I will speak to amendments Nos 1 and 2 because they are related as No 2 is a consequential amendment. The Greens support, in principle, the setting up of this land fund. We believe that it is an appropriate time in history to set up a land fund aimed at redressing the injustices of the last 200 years. We think it is a very important and historic principle to establish. If that fund were really offering Aboriginal people $1 billion with which they could acquire and manage land, then it would assume great importance, because the ATSIC budget itself is only $1 billion every year. If the fund made $1 billion available to Aboriginal people, equal to the current ATSIC budget, then we feel that the act should also be cited as the Land Fund and Indigenous Land Corporation (ATSIC Amendment) Act and should refer to section 1 of the principal act by omitting the word `Commission' and substituting `Commission and Indigenous Land Corporation'—that is, measuring the significance of the act that we are currently debating by including it on an equal footing with the principal act into which it is being inserted.

TALK.START.PARA: —In relation to amendment No. 2, I agree with the sentiments expressed by Senator Chamarette in relation to the change of name of the amending act. I think it makes sense. It tells the reader quite succinctly what it is all about. But with respect to amendment No. 1, I do not think that the coalition can go as far as to agree with that. The points that that covers can be dealt with when the coalition comes to its first amendment. I think amendment No. 2 is sensible and explains the matter much more clearly than the current title.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The government is prepared to accept both amendments Nos 1 and 2. Amendment No. 2, changing the short title of this act to make it more accurately reflect its actual subject matter, is perfectly acceptable. As to the long title, I think it needs to be clarified as to what Senator Chamarette's amendment actually does. I think there might have been some ambiguity in the way in which she explained the purpose of it. The amendment to the long title would interpolate the clause that is set out in her amendments, so the thing as a whole would read as follows:

SPEECH.PARA: An Act to amend the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission Act 1989 and certain other acts so as to establish a land fund and an indigenous land corporation to help redress the dispossession of Aboriginal people and Torres Strait Islanders and for related purposes.

That is the way it will read in its extended long title form. The government regards it as perfectly sensible for the long title of the act to be genuinely descriptive of the contents of the legislation, rather than just hinting at them in purely formal terms, the way it does at the moment.

PARA.TAB: There is a further point to be made, which I am happy to make for the record. The language is to establish a land fund et cetera to help redress the dispossession of Aboriginals and Torres Strait Islanders. It is worth acknowledging that nothing we can do now by way of legislation or by way of payment of other forms of compensation could completely redress the dispossession. It is very difficult after 200 years of dispossession, marginalisation and maltreatment of Aboriginal people to talk in terms of complete redress ever being able to be satisfactorily achieved. At most, we can make some important steps in that direction.

The Native Title Act itself is one such step; this is another major step in that direction. The further elements of the social justice package, when they come along, will go further again in that area. Over time, there may be still further ways in which we can address the subject of dispossession.

We are claiming no more than that this bill is helpful in that respect. I hope that clarifies some of the concerns that Senator Chamarette was expressing to me yesterday with great vigour about the government's attitude to the general thrust and shape of this legislation. With the exception, unfortunately, of the opposition, we are in passionate agreement about the terms of the long title and we can perhaps now get on to more substantive issues.
Amendments agreed to.
Title, as amended, agreed to.
Clause 1, as amended, agreed to.
Clause 2 agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chamarette Sen C.M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I apologise for the haste with which I dealt with amendment No.3 when speaking to my other amendments. I think amendment No.3 does follow, in a logical sequence, amendments Nos 1 and 2. Having changed the name of the act so that it more effectively describes the purpose for which it has been set up, the Greens are presenting amendment No.3 to the committee because they believe it will do more justice to the name of the principal act. The amendment seeks to substitute `Commission and Indigenous Land Corporation' for `Commission' so that the double function will be recognised. I move:

SPEECH.PARA: After clause 2, page 2, insert the following clause in Part 1:

TAB.TAB: "2A. Section 1 of the Principal Act is amended by omitting "Commission" and substituting "Commission and Indigenous Land Corporation".

TALK.START.PARA: —The government does not think it would be appropriate to amend the principal act title in the way that Senator Chamarette has suggested. The proposal to include a reference to the Indigenous Land Corporation—but only the Indigenous Land Corporation—as an additional reference in the title of the principal act will be inadequate and misleading because the principal act, the ATSIC Act, establishes not only ATSIC itself and this new body, as will be the case after this legislation is hopefully passed, but a number of other corporations as well—the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commercial Development Corporation, the Torres Strait Regional Authority and a large number of regional councils. They are all established by the principal act.

PARA.TAB: It is impracticable to mention in the short title to the principal act all the bodies that it establishes; and to single out one such additional body as a basis for amending the short title, whatever the significance of that body might be, we think lacks compelling logical foundation. For that reason, we would oppose the amendment.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to ask the minister for clarification. Is the government stating by its unwillingness to support this that the Indigenous Land Corporation is just one of many other corporations? We are making the point that quite a large bureaucracy is being established. We have a new structure which has $3 million allocated to it each year. While we do not agree that the government should in any way be regarding it as a billion dollar fund—that is not the amount of money that actually goes to Aboriginal people for land acquisition and management—we still see that the government has established a billion dollar fund for itself that will be held by the Indigenous Land Corporation.

PARA.TAB: We think that if the government is establishing something that has an equivalent budget to that of the current ATSIC structure, it should at least justify that balance. So I would like clarification from the minister. Does he see it as more comparable with the other aspects of ATSIC functioning, or as an important new structure that is being developed to achieve the purposes that the government has stated?.

TALK.START.PARA: —Manifestly an important new structure is being established to advance some very significant and important purposes, but that does not necessarily translate into a desirability to make the short title longer, and in particular selectively longer. It is a standard principle of drafting and publication that short titles should be short. Unless there is some really compelling reason for making them longer, we would prefer to avoid that.

PARA.TAB: This is not in any way to be taken as a downgrading of the significance of the Indigenous Land Council. We would be the last people in the country who would want to do that. It is just a matter of believing that it is inappropriate to expand the short title in that way. This is not a super significant issue, but I think our respective positions have been clearly placed on the record. We are not trying to put the council down. It is just a matter of drafting style and parliamentary practice to treat it this way, and I hope everyone will accept it in that spirit.

TALK.START.PARA: —Having regard to the points made by Senator Gareth Evans, the coalition agrees with the government that we conform with drafting practice and leave the description as the government says it should remain. I can foreshadow that no doubt we will agree with some of the other matters the Greens will raise. However, this is not a substantial issue.

—I concur with Senator Ellison's comments. Governments choose drafting styles and we inherit contexts. I think Senator Gareth Evans explained the government's views on this reasonably, and we are persuaded by them.

PARA.TAB: Amendment negatived.
Clause 3.

TALK.START.PARA: —We will be moving an amendment which seeks to insert `Division 1A—Object and principles—Object of Part'. In the first part of this amendment we have included the insertion of that part of the preamble of the Native Title Act which refers to the establishment of the land fund.

—On a point of process: before we get on to the consideration of clause 3, could we perhaps defer this amendment until the Democrat amendments are circulated, because there is a rival version of exactly what the opposition is trying to achieve. I think it makes sense to have them debated together. We could circulate right now some copies of the Democrats' proposal, but I think it makes more sense to deal with them together. It will be a matter of only minutes before the proposal is out.

PARA.TAB: That is also true of section 191B. There is a competing Democrat formulation of that. I understand those opposite have quite a few things to say on the subject of section 191C and also, when we get to section 191D, on the individuals versus corporations issue. Maybe we could get on to those and defer consideration of those intermediate items. Is that acceptable?

TALK.START.PARA: —I understand that we are not deferring all of the amendments to clause 3.

—No, we have to get on with them at some stage. We are deferring just the introductory division proposal. I am also suggesting we defer consideration of section 191B and get on now with section 191C. We will come back to section 191B as soon as the Democrat amendments have been circulated.
—Is that the wish of the committee? There being no objection, it is so ordered.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ellison Sen C.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (3)Clause 3, page 3, at the end of section 191C, add the following subsections:
" `(2) In the performance of its functions the Indigenous Land Corporation or a subsidiary:
(a)must not hold or acquire; or

TAB.TAB: (i)an Aboriginal or Torres Strait Islander corporation; or
(iv)trustees of Aboriginal or Torres Strait Islander trusts;

SPEECH.PARA: to hold or acquire;
an interest in land where the land is subject to native title or native title rights and interests within the meaning of section 223 of the Native Title Act 1993.
" `(3) A failure to comply with subsection (2) does not invalidate action by the Indigenous Land Corporation.".
(9)Clause 3, page 4, after proposed subsection 191D(3), at the end add the following subsection:

" `(4) In performing its land acquisition functions, the Indigenous Land Corporation must take all reasonable steps, including, where appropriate, making a non-claimant application within the meaning of section 67 of the Native Title Act 1993, to satisfy itself that any interest to be acquired in land is not subject to native title or native title rights and interests within the meaning of section 223 of that Act.".
(17)Clause 3, page 10, at the end of proposed subsection 191N(2) add the following paragraphs:

TAB.TAB: "(d)the need to give priority in the purchase of land to land on which Aboriginal people or Torres Strait Islanders cannot claim native title under the Native Title Act 1993 or land concerning which Aboriginal people cannot make applications under the Aboriginal Land Rights (Northern Territory) Act 1976;
(e)the need to ensure that land which is the subject of a claim under the Native Title Act 1993 is not acquired;

(f)the need to give the upgrading of Aboriginal pastoral properties priority over the acquisition of land in areas where there are already substantial land holdings by Aboriginal people or corporations.".

SPEECH.PARA: (30)Clause 3, page 15, after proposed subsection 191U(2) add the following subsection:

TAB.EMPHASIS: Section 47 of Native Title Act not to apply

PARA.TAB: " `(3) Section 47 of the Native Title Act 1993 does not apply to land acquired by a body corporate, person or trust under subsection (1).".

SPEECH.PARA: These amendments relate to the opposition's amendments Nos 9, 17 and 30 and deal with the principle of the separation of land granted by the land fund from native title land. The committee will note that the amendments state that the Indigenous Land Corporation, in the performance of its functions, must not hold or acquire, or enable Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people to hold or acquire, an interest in land where the land is subject to native title or native title rights. This is a very important aspect because it separates the two pieces of legislation—the land fund legislation and the native title legislation.

PARA.TAB: The committee will note that in the preamble it was said that the land fund was set up for those people who could not make a claim under the Native Title Act. The government recognised that there would be indigenous people who had a continuing association with the land and who could readily make out a claim. As I recall, the minister said something of the order of five per cent of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people would be able to make that sort of claim. That left a vast majority of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people who could not make a claim but who had still been dispossessed. That is, after all, what this land fund is all about.

If we muddy the waters and marry the two, there will be confusion. What is more, we could well find competing claims within the Aboriginal community. Where land has been granted to a group of fringe dwellers—perhaps living on the outskirts of a country town—those people may find that they are subject to a native title claim by another group which has a continuing association with the surrounding land. We could find that we have a group of Aboriginal people claiming native title over land held by another group of Aboriginal people. That is a distinct possibility.

The committee will note that the opposition's amendment No. 17 deals with section 191N(2). That sets out the need to give priority in the purchase of land to land which Aboriginal people cannot lay native title claim to. In (e) there is a need to ensure that the land which is the subject of a claim under native title is not acquired. In (f) there is the need to give the upgrading of Aboriginal pastoral properties priority over the acquisition of land in areas where there are already substantial land holdings by Aboriginal people.

For instance, we might find an area in the north-west of Australia where Aboriginal people have a vast tract of land. Perhaps acquisition is not then the most pressing need. What might need to be looked at is the question of improving that land, because the land is already in their possession.

Amendment No. 30 continues the theme I have mentioned and deals with section 47 of the Native Title Act. That says that section 47 of the Native Title Act does not apply to land acquired under subsection (1). It is saying that land cannot be granted under this legislation to a body of Aboriginal people or a corporation who can use the provisions of section 47 of the Native Title Act to fast-track a native title claim, that is, to convert it from land which was granted to them by the Indigenous Land Corporation to native title.

One of the problems I have highlighted previously is that we might have a community that has been granted land and the elders of the community would like to establish native title. If a pastoral lease is granted to them, they can use these fast-track provisions of section 47 of the Native Title Act to convert to native title. Other members of the community might not want that, and that could well create some sort of division within the community. Senator Campbell and I have stressed this on a number of occasions in the hearing in relation to this legislation, and also in previous debates on native title.

The question of converting land granted under this legislation to native title is a vexed one indeed. We can avoid this confusion and any possible division in the Aboriginal community by keeping the two schemes apart, so to speak. I understand that the Greens have reservations about this and I take on board the reasons they have expressed. Nonetheless, I believe it is sensible to keep the two schemes apart and not to risk confusion by overlapping.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to make clear that these amendments are not acceptable to the government. This is an old chestnut. It is an issue that has been debated very extensively in the context of the native title debate and also during the committee hearings on this legislation. The positions have been made reasonably clear.

PARA.TAB: Let me say at the outset that, as a practical matter, there is no doubt that the corporation will give precedence and priority to purchase and acquisition of land that is not likely to be capable of sustaining a native title claim. The whole point of this legislation is to try as far as possible to redress the balance for those who have been dispossessed. Almost by definition, the primary focus of the legislation is aimed at those who are unable to re-establish their connection with land by means other than through this sort of acquisition program. That is clear. That said, it needs to be appreciated that to try to draw an absolute formal line of division between the operation of the Native Title Act and this legislation is fraught with difficulty, complexity and also some problems of principle.

The first set of problems goes to the fact that there are some kinds of native title claims which simply do not amount to ownership in the same sense that will be possible for land acquired and granted under the scheme of this bill we are now considering. Some forms of native title claims extend only to rights of access—hunting rights and so on. To deny those people the capacity to have land granted to them, in effect, as owned land under the scheme of this legislation, simply because they have or possibly have a claim to native title rights in that very limited sense, would be seen as a travesty and a most unfair limitation on their capacity to acquire, in effect, full ownership.

Equally, we may have over a significant or large tract of land a possibly successful native title claim applicable as to only a very small proportion of it. The piece of land is an integrated whole, but if we try to draw an absolute wedge between the two pieces of legislation we would have again the unfortunate consequence of the availability of that native title claim over a very small part of the land—in effect, denying the capacity for acquisition of the whole. Again, I do not think that would be seen as fair or just.

A further consideration goes to the practicability of administering a division of the kind that is proposed by the opposition. It would create a nightmare situation for the corporation, constrained and restricted in this way, to have to satisfy itself, in effect, that there is no viable native title claim likely to be available before it proceeds with some other form of transaction.

The opposition suggests in amendment No. 9 that the corporation could avail itself of the non-claimant application procedure of going to the tribunal and getting the matter heard, determined and the doubts resolved in that way. But that is an extraordinarily cumbrous process. Given the flexibility and the speed with which we would like the corporation to be able to act and discharge its statutory functions, we regard this as an unnecessary and unhelpful constraint.

I come back to the practicalities of this, which is where I began. The pressures on the corporation to use its funds for acquiring land which would not otherwise come within the Native Title Act will be immense, because right around the country Aboriginal people who have been dispossessed, who have lost any connection with their land but who still have a hunger for it and want to re-establish that cultural, social and economic base for themselves, will be tremendously keen to be able to take advantage of this new legislation. The corporation will be tremendously keen to try to satisfy some of that hunger by those people. So as a practical matter all the pressures will be in the direction that the opposition and the government would want them to be—that is, a non-overlap. Nonetheless, it can be envisaged that overlap situations will arise. It is just an unnecessary restriction both in principle and in practice on the kind of flexibility and effectiveness we would like the corporation to have.

Again, it is not to be taken as any dog-in-the-manger, pig-headed, digging-in-at-all-costs response to an opposition viewpoint. We understand very well what the opposition is saying here, and the desirability. We just think that to try to formalise it in the way that the opposition has done creates many more problems than it will solve.

TALK.START.PARA: —I put on record that the Democrats will not be supporting these amendments, essentially for the reasons that have been outlined, but the main one being that, because native title does not often provide for ownership, it cuts across the purpose of this bill. I think it is illogical to attempt to combine the two in the way that the opposition has done.

—The Greens will not support these amendments, either, and for very similar reasons. We believe that at this point in history, where native title has only been recognised by white Australia for such a comparatively short time—the first action that was taken was the native title legislation last year which tried to secure and shore up all the other vested interests in land except those of the Aboriginal people but did allow a process to be put in place whereby native title claims could be dealt with—it is far too early to impose a restriction of this sort. We understand the rationale, which is simply to ensure that those people who will be given priority by this fund will be those who are dispossessed. But at this stage in Australia's history I think it can scarcely be stated that those who may possibly be able to exert a native title claim but have not yet been able to do so should be eliminated from the operations of this fund. Those are our reasons for not supporting the amendments.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Campbell Sen I.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to respond briefly to some of the comments made by Senator Gareth Evans and the other senators who have contributed to this discussion. Clearly, this is drawing a very clear distinction between the objects of the ILC and the objects of the Native Title Act. The preamble to the Native Title Act was quite explicit. It said, in part:

PARA.TAB: It is also important to recognise that many Aboriginal peoples and Torres Strait Islanders, because they have been dispossessed of their traditional lands, will be unable to assert native title rights and interests and that a special fund needs to be established to assist them to acquire land.

SPEECH.PARA: Of course, that preamble was quite specific about why the land fund was established. I think the Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration really teased out the point that one of the reasons why this land fund was being taken out of the Native Title Act was to get it away from the umbrella of that part of the preamble, because it was quite specific about who it should help.

PARA.TAB: The coalition feels very strongly that that principle should be adhered to and, of course, has designed a raft of amendments that seek to ensure that the ILC cannot go around hunting in native title country to buy land. I think we all understand that, so we have designed these amendments.

Some of the things that Senator Evans said require highlighting. Firstly, part of that raft of amendments does suggest that the ILC could use the non-claimant application route, which quickly became known in the Joint Committee on Native Title as the `Latham method'. It is a little hypocritical of the minister to now describe that non-claimant application as `extraordinarily cumbrous', because this is a procedure which the government is telling industry around Australia that it should avail itself of. Every time an industry spokesman says, `We have uncertainty about where native title occurs, so we are not prepared to explore or invest for mining', the government's response—and particularly Mark Latham's response in the other place—is, `You have this non-claimant procedure and it is quite easy: you just go and put a non-claimant application in and it is dealt with and all the uncertainty is cleared up.'

The coalition is saying to the government that if it is good enough to clear up uncertainty in that way for the mining industry, it is clearly no less cumbersome for the ILC to do it. I do face the reality that the Greens, the Democrats and the government will not be supporting our amendments, so I will not delay the committee any longer on that particular point.

What is interesting—and I am sure Senator Chamarette will be raising this later in the day—is that it has been good enough, however, for the government to draw a very clear distinction between native title land and land under the Northern Territory land rights act in subsection 191U(2) by making a very clear distinction about claims in the Northern Territory and ensuring that ILC land cannot be the subject of a claim there. So the principle that Senator Evans has held dear here has been emasculated in the government's treatment of the Northern Territory in that, certainly, the ILC cannot buy land that relates to a claim to land under that act.

On the matter of principle, we do believe strongly that there is a need to assist those who cannot assert native title rights. We accept the government's view that probably only five per cent of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Australians will be able to assert native title rights and that, clearly, there is a need to assist those others. With all the good intentions in the world, the ILC will be under enormous pressure to purchase land where there could be an overlap of native title. One of the practical reasons for that is that a lot of the Aboriginal organisations and individuals who have contact with land matters—land acquisition matters and land rights claims—are those people who are active and organised in those parts of Australia where the native title action is taking place at the moment.

All those parts of Australia where we already have claims registered and accepted with the Native Title Tribunal are those parts of Australia where the Aboriginal interests on the ground are the most organised when it comes to land claims and those sorts of things. That is a practical matter on which the ILC will see itself coming under pressure.

I accept, genuinely, the explanation of the government—and I can understand the process it has gone through in moving from the strict instruction of the preamble in the Native Title Act. I can understand the view that there could be a small bundle of rights granted to someone for native title and that it may well be in the best interests of those Aboriginals to be able to purchase the pastoral lease or the freehold title. We do not dispute that, I do not think. We are saying to the ILC that that is not the intention of this legislation.

I would think—and I am probably speaking out of school here—that had this amendment been passed by this place, then it would have been the coalition's view on coming into government that we would review the action of this provision in the three-year review we proposed, particularly after a period of, say, three to five years when we had seen the native title situation shake itself out a bit, where the uncertainty relating to native title claims would, hopefully, disappear, where the Australian community would understand where native title is and what it is, and indeed the actions of the Indigenous Land Corporation would have become clear as well.

I am saying, in a very longwinded way, that this is probably the sort of provision that, had it been put into the bill, the coalition would have looked at in a practical light at a sensible juncture down the track—probably in three or five years—in order to accept the arguments that Senator Evans has put both at the committee hearing and here this morning.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to clarify the issue of non-claimant applications. Of course we regard these as a very effective and practical way of testing the water in the standard situation where it is anticipated those provisions would apply. For example, if a mining company with an appropriate exploration interest in the land in question wants to know the status of that land before it embarks upon major potential investment activity. In that case, a single piece of land and a single competing interest are involved, and there is a simple process to be put in train.

PARA.TAB: But when we are talking about a corporation with a large purchasing strategy extending over the entire country—multiple parcels of land in different parts of the country—we have a different kind of environment in which this provision would apply. Moreover, there is a legal inhibition—which I should have mentioned before—on the non-claimant application provision being applied when a person does not hold an interest in the land in question, unless that person is a Commonwealth or state minister. The only three categories of people who can lodge non-claimant applications are people with an interest in the land or those who are Commonwealth or state ministers.

When the corporation has simply not yet acquired an interest in land, it would not have the legal standing to seek a non-claimant application, unless it were able to utilise a ministerial application for that purpose. So there is that further limitation. They all make it an inappropriate solution to the problem that Senator Campbell has identified.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to put a point to the minister on reasons why I believe the two systems should be kept separate. It is more to do with commercial reasons. The minister said yesterday during question time that the benefit of this land fund was to give Aboriginals independence and some economic benefits. He went on to say that the economic benefit might be psychological. I would like the minister to explain `psychological economic benefit', but at some other time.

PARA.TAB: The point I put to him is this. I presume that if a corporation bought land out of this fund, it may hold that land forever and a day if it wished to. That is if we are in the commercial world. To make it easy, if people buy a farm, station or whatever out of this fund, they have to make some sort of application. I will go down that line first.

Suppose a person buys a station. A few years down the track, he finds some reason why he does not want to stay on that station—perhaps he wants to move on to another one. I presume that that person would be quite free to sell that one and buy another one. But if the two systems run into each other, and someone decides to make a native title claim on that land then, whether it is successful or not, or whether it is waiting to be arbitrated upon, that would lessen the value of the property that person may wish to sell.

I go back to my first point. This fund is for commercial purposes, as well as for other psychological economic reasons which the minister has mentioned. There could be a downgrading of the value of the place if the owners wanted to move on. It need not be a station; it might be a hobby farm close to the city. If the owners decide it is not what they want and they want to move on, the value of the property, in my view, would certainly drop if someone had come in and put in a land claim. So the owners would not be able to make a commercial decision to move somewhere else, unless an unending amount of money were available.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Chairman, this amendment is an important one because it seeks to make clear the distinction between native title land and land purchased by the Indigenous Land Corporation. Those who oppose the amendment have a problem with the clarity of purpose of this legislation. If this legislation enables the Indigenous Land Corporation to purchase land which is already subject to a native title claim, it blurs the distinction between the fund, which is supposed to assist Aboriginals who are incapable of making native title claims, and the Native Title Act.

PARA.TAB: One would assume that an Aboriginal or Torres Strait Islander group which is capable of making a native title claim would have a lesser priority in calling on this fund than a group that is not. Those who oppose the amendment show that they have a grave problem with clarity of purpose.

This amendment seeks to cut through that confusion so that there is a clear distinction between those who are able to access land by virtue of a native title claim and those who are not. There are very real consequences to blurring the distinction and Senator Panizza has already touched on one of them—that a native title claim could severely depress the market value of land subject to that claim. If we blur the distinction, the following situation is quite foreseeable: an Aboriginal group makes a native title claim, the effect of that claim depresses the value of the property and maybe even makes it commercially unsaleable; that group then seeks to access the fund to pick up the property, the market value of which has been substantially reduced by virtue of the claim.

Of course, at some later stage it might be decided that the claim had no validity but this creates the potential—I am not suggesting that this will happen in a great number of cases—for dealings in land which we would regard as less than satisfactory. It creates the potential for particular groups of claimants or particular groups of people seeking to access the fund to act in an unconscionable manner. We do not believe that that is fair.

The principle behind this legislation is to enable Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander groups who cannot access land by virtue of a native title claim to be able to acquire that land and thereby achieve a sense of equality. However, if we create mechanisms which have the potential for gross unfairness, we negate the principle behind the legislation. That is what concerns us.

If this amendment is not accepted a big problem might arise for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander groups. Senator Campbell has already alluded to this but I wish to go into it in more detail. The problem is where different Aboriginal groups have competing claims to land. On Cape York Peninsula, an area with which I am very familiar, there are claims from different Aboriginal groups competing with the existing Wik claim. If one Aboriginal group in one part of the country makes a native title claim and another group seeks to access the fund to purchase some of that land subject to that claim, the result will be outright warfare between the two groups.

That sounds like an extraordinary claim, but in places such as Aurukun and Kowanyama there is on-going internecine strife between people of one skin and people of another. All this will do is exacerbate tensions. It does not do anything to solve the lot of the Aboriginal community if these tensions are allowed to continue to simmer. If these tensions are exacerbated by virtue of the provisions of the legislation and by the operation of the fund, all that this will do is pit one Aboriginal group against another.

While they are busy fighting amongst themselves, the real hope of the Australian community, which is for an advancement of the disadvantaged Aboriginal people, will be lost because all the energies are being channelled in a non-productive way instead of a productive way. That is something that concerns me immensely. It cannot but dismay anybody who visits these communities to see the strife, the tension and the violence. All we are saying is here is a way to ensure that that does not get worse, that we do not have one Aboriginal group pitted against another Aboriginal group. That is not an unreasonable request to have implemented in this legislation. That is why this amendment is critical.

The government has said that this amendment has all sorts of thorns on it. Senator Gareth Evans said that one of those thorns is that it would take too long to access the non-claimant mechanism. Unfortunately, that is something the government put in place. The government put that non-claimant procedure in place. If it would take too long to access it, that is one of the government's defects in the native title legislation and that ought to be amended. But the government does not come before the chamber and say, `We want to amend it.' It recognises, from what Senator Evans said, that there are defects in that procedure. Where is the amendment bill to deal with that problem? It is not before the chamber.

One of the other comments that Senator Evans made in relation to that, and I thought this was extraordinary, was that he believed the amendment would require the Indigenous Land Corporation to check that there was no potential claim over the land. That is not what amendment No. 3 says. This amendment says that the Indigenous Land Corporation must not hold or acquire land or enable persons to hold or acquire land where an interest in that land is subject to native title or native title rights and interests within the meaning of section 223 of the Native Title Act. This means there has to be either a declared right or a claimed right. But it would not require the Indigenous Land Corporation to go around and check whether any group believes it might bring a claim in the future.

I think Senator Evans misunderstood the amendment when he said that, and I can understand why he might have done so. But the amendment does not require the Indigenous Land Corporation to ascertain whether any group at any future point in time may be interested in lodging a claim. It only requires the corporation to check whether there is a claim or whether there is a decided interest in the land.

If Senator Evans says that it is too cumbersome to utilise the provisions of the Native Title Act to check the register, that then is a defect in the native title legislation. I do not believe that that is a valid argument against this amendment. I believe the amendment has a lot of merit, and I believe the committee would do well to support it.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will respond very briefly to a couple of the points that Senator O'Chee made. Many of the points he made were, of course, made more succinctly and equally effectively by some of his colleagues, and I do not want to re-track the ground.

PARA.TAB: As to his last point about the corporation having to satisfy itself about potential claims, that is certainly my reading of the opposition amendment because a native title right is something which exists whether or not it has been recognised through proper process or whether or not it has been the subject of a formal claim. The right is there. The question is whether or not it is acknowledged, recognised and registered in law. Either it exists or it does not exist.

TALK.START.PARA: —Within the meaning of section 223—that is to qualify.
