—My understanding is that to satisfy itself that there were not going to be problems with native title claims, the corporation would have to, for all practical purposes, not only establish what claims had actually been lodged and what rights had actually been acknowledged by the tribunal but also search out the potential for such claims being lodged in the future. That is just the way I think the law would in fact operate and oblige it to operate.

PARA.TAB: Beyond that, I want to say that I think Senator O'Chee gives insufficient weight to the commonsense factor in all of this. We have an Indigenous Land Corporation which, let us face it, will have to resolve many potential conflicts between different claimants of Aboriginal groups and communities. It will have to prioritise claims somehow with a lot of clamour for simultaneous action occurring. In the case of particular communities living adjacent to each other, it will have to make some rather tough decisions, irrespective of the applicability of native title interests to the particular situation. We do have to rely on the good sense of the corporation that will be appointed and will be representative of indigenous people as a whole to get that right.

I cannot see, frankly, that the possibility of native title right issues intruding on the situation will make life very much more complex than it will be already for the corporation in dealing with some of these issues. When we take into account the problems that can arise if we absolutely seek to exclude native title right holders from access to these funds, the issues that I spelt out at the beginning, then I think the balance comes down very much in favour of keeping the bill as it is.

As to Senator Panizza's anxieties about land being devalued by a potential native title claim and spoiling its commercial utilisation, at least in terms of an on-selling transaction, I think it needs to be appreciated that this land has a lot of limitations on its alienability, anyway. People are only able to deal with the land with the consent of the corporation.

The clear intention is that this, by and large, be land which is acquired on a more or less permanent basis. The possibility of a commercial rollover of a pastoral property or something is not excluded; the possibility for sale is not excluded. But the basic principle on which the act is constructed, by and large, is that land is being acquired for people to re-establish roots with, and to develop a relationship with, having lost that capacity through dispossession.

I do not think as a practical matter there will be too many instances of those kinds of transactions that Senator Panizza seems to regard as the norm. If a question did arise about a competing native title based claim, then it would be possible for the corporation holding the land in question to itself take advantage of the non-claimant procedure in order to clarify the situation in exactly the same way as we have argued that other kinds of property owning interests should have that right.

Again, I repeat that while the non-claimant application is certainly a cumbrous procedure in the context of the corporation and the role that the corporation will be performing, it is not a cumbrous procedure for any individual interest holder to use in order to clarify the situation about his particular patch of dirt.

In that environment we are dealing with a finite, clear-cut issue, and it ought to be able to be resolved relatively simply. It is when we have simultaneous issues crowding in on us in multiple locations potentially all around the country and the need to clear the decks, as it were, before the transaction can proceed in any one of them, that I think it is an unreasonable restriction on the proposed role of the ILC.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to respond briefly to a number of points. Firstly, I apologise if I did not pick up the minister's response to my point about the inconsistency in relation to proposed section 191U(2), that is, the Northern Territory land rights situation. I might have been on the phone at the time. If I was, I do not ask the minister to respond. I will go back to the Hansard in a few days' time.

PARA.TAB: Secondly, the point about the non-claimant route is an important debate. The minister said that the ILC may have no standing because to have standing, people would have to have an interest in the land. It is exactly the same point that arises in relation to mining companies. Mining companies cannot find out whether there is any native title around until they have some sort of permit or interest in the land, and in many cases they do not have. However, the ILC would have the option—

TALK.START.PARA: —An exploration permit is enough to give them standing.

—The trouble is that they cannot get the exploration permit until the state minister has formed an opinion that giving the permit to explore will not land the state government in a potential future compensation claim. That is one of the reasons the New South Wales government is not issuing exploration permits at the moment. It is not issuing exploration permits where there is any doubt about native title anywhere in New South Wales. I think Queensland is in the same situation. That will remain the situation until the federal government has resolved its negotiations with those governments as to the compensation agreement—which I understand is no closer to resolution than it was 15 months ago.
—That is not true; it is very close to resolution.

—That is what the government probably said back in June last year at the COAG meeting in Melbourne. I am sure Sir Humphrey Appleby would say the same thing. The ILC could establish an interest in the land quite practically by saying, in respect of a pastoral lease, `We will create an option to purchase that land. We have an intention.' From the equity point of view—and I can think of examples in the north-west of Western Australia, particularly in the Pilbara—there may well be Aboriginals who would have an interest in land, whose interest in the land from a native title right point of view has been extinguished because of past acts, and who may well be interested in purchasing pastoral leases or other property when they come up for sale.

PARA.TAB: One of the equitable side-effects of our no claimant application route for the ILC is that, if a mining company, for example, went to purchase a pastoral lease to develop a mine, that mining company would be required to place a non-claimant application. If the ILC went to purchase the same pastoral lease for the purpose of granting it to an Aboriginal organisation to run it as a pastoral lease, it would not be required to issue a non-claimant application.

Where that is inequitable for Aboriginal communities in the area who may be able to assert native title rights is that a group with a traditional link to that pastoral lease, because they may be some way away from that pastoral lease and unaware of property transactions in the region, will not know that the pastoral lease is available for sale or is about to be purchased, either by a mining company to develop a mine or by the ILC to develop it as a pastoral lease. The ILC, in good faith, may seek to buy the pastoral lease for an Aboriginal community when the potential native title claimants have no knowledge of it. The ILC could purchase the pastoral lease under the noses of people who may have the right to make a traditional—

TALK.START.PARA: —So what?

—The potential native title claimants, the people with a traditional link to that pastoral lease, will have that pastoral lease—their traditional land—sold to another group of Aboriginals who may have very good reasons for buying the pastoral lease but no traditional link to that land. I am using the Latham method: to be fair to the traditional owners, we require the ILC to put in a non-claimant application just to see if there are any traditional owners around. An Aboriginal community could purchase a pastoral lease with the assistance of the ILC and the traditional owners of that land may not even know it took place.

PARA.TAB: Senator Chris Evans says, `Who cares?' He says, `Let the ILC go and buy traditional Aboriginal lands and be blowed to the traditional owners.' I do not believe that Senator Chris Evans could hold that view. He has obviously misunderstood me and I will have to make an explanation later under standing order 191. That is an essential and equitable part of what we are saying—that it is only right and proper that potential native title claimants be aware that the ILC is sniffing around to buy some land in the area, specifically looking to buy a pastoral lease.

Potential native title claimants may well have a traditional link with that land but may never know what is taking place because the non-claimant application route that the government says is mandatory for anyone else in the world to go down to see whether there are native title claimants will not be required in the case of the Indigenous Land Corporation. I think Senator Gareth Evans is right: the ILC will use commonsense when seeking to determine these sorts of things. The non-claimant application route was put into the Native Title Act to be fair to potential claimants. What it does is say, `We're about to do something, we are about to purchase some land. Are there any claimants out there?'

As all senators who have been part of the native title debate know, some quite specific notice provisions are required to ensure that people who may have a native title claim to make are aware that some activity is about to take place and, if they have a native title claim, they should speak now or forever hold their peace.

Clearly, the government is not going to support this amendment. But I think this is one of the important provisions that the ILC might take on board as a part of its commonsense approach to determining whether there are some traditional owners around before it goes and buys someone else a pastoral lease.

TALK.START.PARA: —I understand that it is the wish of the committee that amendment No. 9 be taken separately from amendment Nos 3, 17 and 30.

PARA.TAB: Question put:
That amendments Nos 3, 17 and 30 (Senator Ellison's) be agreed to.
Question so resolved in the negative.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are dealing now with opposition amendment No. 9, moved by Senator Ellison.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The government very strongly opposes this particular clause being picked up. It is important to clarify just how potentially destructive its operation would be. Whatever the intention with which this clause might be moved, its actual effect is potentially quite serious for Aboriginal beneficiaries.

PARA.TAB: Let us take the situation where a group of Aboriginal people with some kind of incomplete native title claim to a tract of land want the Indigenous Land Corporation to buy that land for them so that they can fully and comprehensively enjoy it. Let us take the situation of a traditional group with hunting, or fishing or access rights to a piece of land—unquestionably native title rights constituting native title interests and recognised as such, let us assume, by the tribunal and a claim lodged.

Let us take the situation that I mentioned before where a group of Aboriginal people have an unquestioned native title right to one small corner of a tract of land, but want to be able to acquire the tract of land as a whole and establish a pastoral business there, or something of that kind. If this particular clause were to be passed in its present form, the Indigenous Land Corporation would be totally inhibited from proceeding with the acquisition of that land and the capacity accordingly to grant it to the very people who would be wanting it. The clause proposed to be added states:

SPEECH.PARA: In performing its land acquisition functions, the Indigenous Land Corporation must take all reasonable steps, including, where appropriate, making a non-claimant application within the meaning of section 67 of the Native Title Act 1993—

I interpolate there that the corporation would not have the capacity to make such an application technically if it did not itself, at that stage, have an interest in land. Leaving that aside, I will go on:

the . . . Corporation must take all reasonable steps . . . to satisfy itself that any interest to be acquired in land is not subject to native title or native title rights and interests within the meaning of section 223 . . .

In other words, if the corporation establishes that there is a credible native title right, either already recognised or in the process of being recognised, it would be absolutely inhibited, from the clear intention of the language of this section, from proceeding to the purchase because it would be utterly at odds with the substance of this section in that, having satisfied itself there was a native title right, it went ahead to purchase it anyway. It cannot do that.

PARA.TAB: I understand what the intention probably was behind some of the speakers on this and what perhaps has made an initial impression on some people in this chamber. If it is a matter of untangling with some clarity in advance as to what land might clearly be the subject of a native title claim and what land might clearly not be the subject of any native title claim, it would be quite helpful, I suppose, as a practical matter, for the corporation to inform itself in that way.

As a practical matter, as we said, I am sure that it would not be inclined to go willingly down the path of getting itself into a potential conflict situation between native titleholder claimants and other claimants of the kind that has been described. If it were just seen as an exercise in clearing the conceptual decks to avoid the possibility of that kind of conflict between two different groups, yes, one could see the point of it. But the clause, as it is written, has the unintended consequence—but the very real consequence—of inhibiting the kinds of transactions that I have described, for which the potential is very real in practice.

One of the big problems is the twilight zone of people with some kind of connection with land, but maybe not enough to sustain a full-throated native title claim of a kind equivalent to ownership. So that is the problem we genuinely see with this clause. I really do think that, if this clause were to be passed, it would make an awful mess of the claims and aspirations of a possibly significant group of people.

TALK.START.PARA: —I believe that the government is building a big, ugly, hairy-chested straw man in relation to its objections to this. The case that Senator Gareth Evans has just put is flawed. I will ask Senator Ellison to go to the core of that. But the fundamental principle here, particularly in light of the failure of the last amendments to be carried, is that there is now no specific requirement that the ILC cannot purchase native title land. So that has been cleared. We understand that the ILC in most of its duties will seek to give priority to the purchase of land for the benefit of those people who are not able to assert those rights. We do understand and share the view that there can be a lot of Aboriginal people who claim native title rights—it may only be a very small bundle of rights, including hunting and fishing, or just the right to traverse a piece of land—and that it is probably a matter of equity that they be assisted to buy a freehold or a pastoral lease and therefore enjoy full possessory rights. We understand that point.

PARA.TAB: What we are seeking to do here—and it is as much a matter of equity for the Aboriginal traditional owners—is to require the ILC to take reasonable steps. If we look at the wording of the legislation, we see that it simply requires them to take all reasonable steps. It does not actually require them to even do a non-claimant application; it simply says that where it is considered reasonable, they do a non-claimant application. So with regard to a situation where they are looking at buying a particular property, Senator Evans would have us believe that if they were looking to buy something in a particular area, they would have to put up a non-claimant application and it would create some sort of massive bureaucratic problem by so doing. But this actually requires that when they are buying a property they take these reasonable steps.

In many cases it may be entirely reasonable not to have to bother about even looking for native title because there may never be any native title likely in the area. But where there is likely to be native title in the area, where it is considered reasonable—that might be in the situation which I described earlier whereby there is a suggestion that there may be some traditional owners—they go down this route. Reasonable steps may well include having the normal sorts of discussions that a mining company will have anywhere around Australia. Sensible mining companies which are good corporate citizens, when they are about to do some activity in an area, most mining companies these days—I refer to companies such as Hamersley Iron, Western Minerals NL which now owns the Cadjebut mine and some of the other examples that we saw recently during the visit by the Joint Standing Committee on Native Title to north-west Australia—consult with the local communities. They get to know who the local traditional people are and they generally work very well with them.

That is the sort of reasonable step that this amendment would envisage. It goes no further than that. It does not require the ILC to go any further than that. The ILC now can take the reasonable steps, find out what sort of rights exist and then proceed under all the other principles enunciated in the body of the bill. We think that it is only reasonable that the ILC be required to determine whether there are any other Aboriginals who can assert rights in the area. That is all that this requires the ILC to do.

We consider it entirely unreasonable that the ILC would be able to go down this path without determining whether those rights do exist. As I said earlier, it is quite possible that there are traditional owners in the region or anywhere who may want to assert rights or who may need to be aware that they should assert rights. They will not have any notice provided to them unless the ILC has a specific requirement that it seeks to determine those rights. As I said, I would welcome a contribution from Senator Ellison as to the other fundamental flaw in the specific example given by Senator Evans.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to precede Senator Ellison because, if I am misunderstanding his amendment, he can clarify it for me as well. The Greens indicated in initial discussions with the opposition that they would be supporting this amendment, or an amendment of this sort, for the reasons for which it has been defended—that is, that it will clarify where different groups may be involved in having different kinds of interests in the area.

PARA.TAB: We felt it was quite reasonable that there be some acknowledgment that all reasonable steps should be taken to be satisfied as to what interests were present in the land in relation to native title. We did not realise that in our initial stages of agreement we had said that we did not support making a non-claimant application as part of the reasonable steps. Because we have not actually viewed these amendments in this form until today, I had not realised that they included that component.

We are concerned that if the phrase `where appropriate making a non-claimant application' is retained, then it would automatically delay anything for two months. It may serve the opposite purpose for which it is intended—that is, it will not facilitate clarification of interests; it may block something being done that could be effectively done. So I am sorry that I indicated initially that we would be prepared to support that. Senator Ellison may be able to persuade me that I have again misunderstood what is happening. I do not feel comfortable about the way in which this amendment is phrased.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ellison Sen C.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —Firstly, in relation to the aspect of the pastoral lease that Senator Gareth Evans mentioned, of course, it is still open for the Indigenous Land Corporation to grant the pastoral lease to the dispossessed community or individual—in this case it has to be a corporation, but if our amendments are passed, it could be that—and that part of the land which is affected by native title could be excluded and reserved and set aside for particularly that native title claim.

PARA.TAB: We are talking about native title where there is a claim to traverse the land or to hunt or fish. Those activities relate normally to specific areas. It is well known that in relation to these aspects in the past, Aboriginal people have used a tract of land—they have traditionally, historically, adopted a path they have gone backwards and forwards on, and have hunted in a certain area. That, therefore, does not take it beyond the realms of possibility of allowing the ILC to come to a pastoral lease and acquire the lease for the purposes of giving it to those people who cannot maintain native title but to excise that part of the lease where native title could be exercised.

If the Indigenous Land Corporation granted the land to community A, and community A was dispossessed and did not have native title, and community B could maintain native title over that land, the two communities could be drawn into possible conflict because, naturally, the traditional users would want to exert a claim over that land. But other Aboriginal people, perhaps from the town, the city or wherever, nonetheless dispossessed, would be in possession of that land because the ILC had granted it to them—so there is a possible conflict.

One could get around that quite easily by excising any portion of the land, saving that for the native title claimants and granting the rest of the land to those people who had been dispossessed—that is quite possible. In fact, in Western Australia pastoral leases have reservations on them. Some of those pastoral stations in the north-west allow traditional land users access to certain areas—wells and things of that nature.

What I am saying is that the acquisition of that particular pastoral lease might not necessarily be impeded, as Senator Evans said. This legislation asks the Indigenous Land Corporation to take reasonable steps to ensure that it does not run into conflict with any native title claims. For instance, native title claims are pending in the north-west. Those have been made by various groups. It would be folly on the part of the Indigenous Land Corporation to go ahead and acquire land which is the subject of those claims for other Aboriginal groups because it would bring them into clear conflict. In the section which deals with the performance of functions, I think it is imperative that the Indigenous Land Corporation have some guidance as to how it should perform its functions—and this is a very important area—so it does not lead Aboriginal groups into unnecessary conflict.

TALK.START.PARA: —How prescriptive should guidance be?

—How prescriptive should guidance be? We said that the Indigenous Land Corporation in performing its functions must take all reasonable steps, and we have included a non-claimant application as an example. The ILC does not have to do that. The legislation is not prescriptive; it does not say, `You must do this'. The legislation says that the corporation should take reasonable steps—that is, exercise some care and aforethought in granting the land.
—It says more than that; you know that. It says `satisfies itself'.

—The ILC satisfies itself after it has taken reasonable steps. The land corporation can look at a claim in an area. For example, on the outskirts of Kalgoorlie there might be an area where the ILC wants to grant land to an Aboriginal community. The ILC makes inquiries about the location and finds out that there is no possibility, or there is a very unlikely possibility, of a native title claim. It then goes ahead and acquires the land. The corporation has fulfilled its functions under this subsection because it has satisfied itself that it has taken reasonable steps. But if the ILC knew full well that this land was the subject of a claim, or that there was a claim pending by a group which had traditional ties with that land, and went ahead and still acquired it willy-nilly, it would be in contravention of this because it had not taken reasonable steps; it had ignored an existing situation.

PARA.TAB: This legislation is for those Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people who have been dispossessed, those people who cannot maintain a claim for native title. In fact, the preamble to the Native Title Act, which refers to this very land fund, states:

SPEECH.PARA: It is also important to recognise that many Aboriginal peoples and Torres Strait Islanders, because they have been dispossessed of their traditional lands, will be unable to assert native title rights and interests and that a special fund needs to be established to assist them to acquire land.

They are, very clearly, people who cannot claim native title. So if we had a community which could lay native title claim to an area, it would not need the assistance of this land fund because it has the remedy of the Native Title Act. It may be that a group cannot maintain any strong claim at all and that it wants to claim that piece of land. The land corporation looks at it and says, `Well, we have looked at their claim. It really isn't going to get anywhere. We can acquire the piece of property concerned.' But, where a claim is up and running, it would be folly to acquire that land and then grant it to another Aboriginal group.

PARA.TAB: This legislation says that the Indigenous Land Corporation has to take reasonable steps. It does not say,`You must not do this'. All it says is that the ILC must take reasonable steps to ensure that this land is not the subject of a native title claim. It is a judgment that it has to satisfy itself, not the world at large. So the ILC can say, `Well, look, there is a claim considered. But we are satisfied that this is not a claim which is going anywhere, and we can safely acquire the land and give it to this other community who are not native title aspirants.'

Senator Evans raised the example of a pastoral property where, in a section of that property, there are hunting and fishing rights, and said that that could be excised and left for the native title claimant and the rest of the property acquired for those who come from town, who can use it and operate it in a commercial sense with the other part excised.

If the inclusion of the reference to the non-claimant application is of concern to the Greens, the coalition could reconsider its stance on that. We are simply saying, `Take reasonable steps, including a non-claimant application.' That is not a compulsion; it is there by way of example. It really means, `Take reasonable steps, including that step, if necessary.' But if that is causing the Greens concern, I would be willing to defer the matter for clarification.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Chairman, there has been some discussion around the chamber and it might be possible to reach some sensible agreement on this amendment. The difficulty is not so much with the Indigenous Land Corporation informing itself as to the existence of native title competing claims and building that into the judgments that it makes; the difficulty is with the corporation being hogtied by finding that there is some, perhaps only very small or marginal, native title right and, as a result, being inhibited from doing something that it and the people of a particular area want done.

PARA.TAB: This is essentially a drafting problem and I think we can resolve it by changing the drafting so that, instead of the corporation having to satisfy itself, the basic idea would be that the corporation would have to inform itself whether these competing interests exist. In informing itself, it would be appropriate, if the corporation itself deemed it appropriate and if it were technically available, to go down the route of a non-claimant application. We could rewrite the clause as follows. The first line remains as is. It would read:
In performing its land acquisition functions, the Indigenous Land Corporation must take reasonable steps—

SPEECH.PARA: delete the word `all'—
including, where it deems it appropriate—
adding the words `it deems it'—
making a non-claimant application within the meaning of section 67 of the Native Title Act 1993, to inform itself whether—
deleting the words `to satisfy itself that'—
any interest to be acquired in land is subject—
delete the word `not'-
to native title or native title rights and interests within the meaning of section 223 of that Act.".

I think that meets the perceived need for some clarification. Given the other obvious practical constraints and the whole thrust of the legislation, which is designed, so far as is possible, to meet non-native title interests but rather the interests of other people who have been dispossessed, that would give the corporation a sufficient armory to deal with these situations in a satisfactory way. I therefore move:

PARA.TAB: Omit all words after "Indigenous Land Corporation", substitute:

SPEECH.PARA: "must take reasonable steps, including, where it deems it appropriate, making a non-claimant application within the meaning of section 67 of the Native Title Act 1993, to inform itself whether any interest to be acquired in land is subject to native title or native title rights and interests within the meaning of section 223 of that Act.".

TALK.START.PARA: —The amendment just moved by Senator Evans entirely reflects the coalition's intentions. It was, as Senator Evans said, a matter of drafting and trying not to be too proscriptive and to fetter the operation and effectiveness of the ILC. Therefore, the coalition supports the amendment to the coalition's amendment.

—The Greens are much happier with that slightly amended version of the coalition's amendment. I apologise for any confusion we may have raised, but I believe it is a very constructive outcome. I think the purpose of the clause should be to clarify and aid the fund rather than be an obstacle, so I indicate we will be supporting it.

PARA.TAB: Amendment (Senator Gareth Evans's) agreed to.
Amendment, as amended, agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ellison Sen C.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (1)Clause 3, page 2, before proposed Division 1 of Part 4A, insert the following Division:
" `Division 1A—Object and principles

PARA.TAB: " `191AA.(1) It is important to recognise that many Aboriginal persons and Torres Strait Islanders, because they have been dispossessed of their traditional lands, will be unable to assert meaningful title to those lands and that a special fund needs to be established to assist them to acquire land.

" `(2) Therefore, the object of this Part is to assist those dispossessed Aboriginal persons and Torres Strait Islanders to meet their economic, cultural and spiritual aspirations through the acquisition and management of land.

" `(3) To give effect to that object, this Part establishes a fund, known as the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Land Fund, and a corporation, known as the Indigenous Land Corporation, to facilitate the acquisition and management of land for those Aboriginal persons and Torres Strait Islanders.
" `191AB. In the performance of functions and the exercise of powers under this Part, the following principles are to be adhered to:

TAB.TAB: (a)the functions and powers must be performed and exercised in the way that, in the opinion of the person performing or exercising them, best promotes the object of this Part;

(b)if a conflict arises as to the allocation of resources, preference is to be given to those Aboriginal persons or Torres Strait Islanders who are most severely dispossessed of their traditional lands;
(c)community based Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander land bodies should be recognised and used to the fullest extent;
(d)significant regard must be had to the views of those bodies;
(e)administrative costs should be kept to a minimum and duplication of administrative capability should be avoided.".

SPEECH.PARA: Whilst looking at our amendment No. 1, perhaps we could also consider the Democrat amendment which seeks to amend the same part of that bill. If that is agreed, I will address my remarks to the Democrat amendment as well as the opposition one.

PARA.TAB: Let me say at the outset that the question of the preamble to the Native Title Act has been mentioned many times. It is from that preamble that we have the very origin of this bill. I will not recite again that part of the preamble which relates to this land fund, but that is where it comes from. It is that part which says those people who cannot maintain this native title are to be the beneficiaries under this bill. It is fairly clear, but nonetheless very important, and it is an aspect which this bill does not address. It should be at the very forefront of the bill. It should be there as a guiding beacon to any reader of the bill as to where this bill is going and what it is intending to do. I notice that the Democrats have adopted words which are similar to the opposition proposal in incorporating this part of the preamble. To that extent, I think that is a good step forward.

During the recent hearing in relation to this bill, the Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration heard evidence on this very point. A witness Mr Aden Ridgeway, who is the executive officer of the New South Wales Land Council, stated:

SPEECH.PARA: The principal consequence of moving the scheme from the Native Title Act to the ATSIC Act is that the preamble to the Native Title Act will no longer provide any assistance in interpreting the powers of the Indigenous Land Corporation.

He acknowledged that we needed to have this transferred from the Native Title Act to this very bill. At the outset, I would say that that is a most important point and one which I note that the Democrats agree with. However, the Democrat amendment does part company with the opposition's proposal. The opposition has put forward an amendment for which we owe much to the New South Wales Land Council.

TALK.START.PARA: —You owe a lot to the New South Wales Land Council.

—Yes, the New South Wales Land Council assisted us greatly in the drafting of this. I have here a letter from the President of the Aboriginal Justice Committee of the Law Society of New South Wales supporting this very amendment. In that letter, Mr Fairlie, the president of that committee, states that recently in the New South Wales Court of Appeal in Mason v. Tritton, Mr Justice Priestley referred to this preamble in the Native Title Act and said:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . in the . . . preamble set out at page 7 above, was established by Subsection (1) of Section 201 of the Native Title Act for the purpose, stated in Subsection (2) of assisting Aboriginal peoples and Torres Strait Islanders to acquire land and manage it in a way that provides them with economic, environmental, social or cultural benefits.

What he was saying there was that principles such as those contained in the preamble or the objects of an act are very important when deciding a case. He referred to the principles that are mentioned. Mr Fairlie, the president of that committee of the New South Wales Law Society, put this forward as a very important aspect to consider in how the courts will approach legislation. In his letter, he said:
The Land Fund Bill does not provide guidelines as to how money drawn from the land fund should be distributed . . . It is essential that such guidelines should be specified in the legislation.

Of course, this can be contained in the objects. I think the opposition's amendment does that commendably. What we have in subparagraphs (a) through to (e) of the amendment are the very guidelines that Mr Justice Priestley had said are important when we decipher what legislation is for. He was not looking at this particular aspect but he was saying that we must have guidelines, in effect. What the opposition said here is that, in the performance of its powers, the following principles should be adhered to:
(a) the functions and powers must be performed and exercised in the way that, in the opinion of the person performing them, best promotes the object of this Part;

(b) if a conflict arises as to the allocation of resources, preference is to be given to those Aboriginal persons or Torres Strait Islanders who are most severely dispossessed of their traditional lands;

That is, the money can only go so far and that if one is stretched, if one is a bit tight for funds, then one is guided by subparagraph (b) to look at those who are the most severely dispossessed. Subparagraph (c) of the amendment states:
community based Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander land bodies should be recognised . . .
That is, we recognise them and use them to their fullest extent. The amendment continues:
(d) significant regard must be had to the views of those bodies;
(e) administrative cost should be kept to a minimum and duplication of administrative capabilities should be avoided.

Those are very clear guidelines indeed as to how this Indigenous Land Corporation is to work. It is to make sure that it does not duplicate administration—that is, that it does not waste money on bureaucracy, on inefficiency or on duplicating functions, because if money is wasted, there will be less in the pot for the recipients.

PARA.TAB: These principles make it easier for the Indigenous Land Corporation to function. I would say, with the greatest of respect, that it is to be preferred to the Democrats' proposal. The Democrats' proposal does not go that far in its detail. The summary in paragraph (3) states that the views of the bodies concerned, the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander communities and bodies, be taken on board. It does not talk about avoiding duplication of administration, it does not talk about giving preference to those more severely dispossessed if a conflict should arise, and it does not go into the detail, I would submit, that is necessary in offering guidelines to the Indigenous Land Corporation.

The case that I mentioned at the outset was quoted by Mr Fairleigh in his letter. What he was driving at was that when the courts look at how a piece of legislation is to function, they look to what is in the legislation, what guidelines there are, what the objects are and what parameters are set. By including this in the legislation, we are making it very clear to anyone who comes after what this Indigenous Land Corporation should be doing and how it should be handling its functions.

I think that the New South Wales Land Council, after a good deal of thought, has arrived at this as a very succinct way of outlining these guidelines that the Indigenous Land Corporation has to adhere to. As I say, the preamble is an essential part. It must be included in this bill, and it is not. That is a defect, which is recognised by the Democrats in their amendment. I can only say that the coalition agrees with the first aspect of the Democrats amendment which deals with the preamble, but not the remaining part of it, and I have already outlined the reasons for that. I would commend the amendment to the committee.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Ellison says that he is indebted to the New South Wales Land Council for this amendment. I want to put on the record that we started off with a replica of that amendment from the New South Wales Land Council because we too were convinced by it and others that the bill as it stands gives no weight to the needs of those Aboriginals and Torres Strait Islanders who have been dispossessed. The fact that the word `dispossession' did not appear was an important oversight.

PARA.TAB: However, I point out to Senator Ellison that in acknowledging the New South Wales Land Council he did not see fit to take up its suggestion that all of the ILC directors should be Aboriginal persons or Torres Strait Islanders. I would be interested in his explanation when we get to that part of the bill. I agree that we do need a coherent framework for the bill. We accept that with the ILC we are creating a very powerful body and it is important to specify what it must have regard to. But I think Senator Ellison is wrong in saying that my amendment does not deal with some of the specific exceptions he mentions.

In part three of my amendment I am saying that the corporation must have regard to the existence and the views of community-based Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander land bodies. In that way, I am drawing on their expertise; I am drawing on the opportunity to avoid duplication; and I am drawing on consultation. I think I am doing it more neatly; and I think I am doing it in such a way that the need to give clear guidance does not unnecessarily restrict the flexibility that the corporation will need. I do not object to Senator Ellison's mentioning issues such as keeping administrative costs to a minimum and avoiding duplication of administrative capability. They are important but I do not think the way he has spelt them out individually is the only way to do it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The government accepts the virtue of having a preambular objects clause of this kind. There was some of this language in the Native Title Act and it is desirable to bring it across and create a context for this legislation as well. So we do not object to putting in some appropriate provision of this kind.

PARA.TAB: When it comes to a choice between the opposition version and the Democrats version, we very strongly prefer the Democrats version. It really all comes down to the presence or absence of one element in the two drafts. A lot of it is just drafting preference, amalgamating things together which are otherwise spelt out. But there is one thing in the opposition version that is missing in the Democrats version—subclause (b) of 191AB, which states:

SPEECH.PARA: if a conflict arises as to the allocation of resources, preference is to be given to those Aboriginal persons or Torres Strait Islanders who are most severely dispossessed of their traditional lands.

That is written not merely as a piece of guidance from which nothing follows other than the guidance itself; this will be justiciable. People will be able to use an alleged failure to adhere to this guideline as a basis for challenging decisions made by the corporation in the allocation of resources. With as much force as I can muster, I suggest that it is a recipe for a potentially absolutely divisive and disastrous series of conflicts—of appearing in the courts, and of generally inhibiting the capacity of the corporation to do its job properly.

PARA.TAB: What the corporation is all about is allocating resources. What it will be constantly confronted with is the question of allocation as between states and then as between competing different groups within states. If the corporation has to satisfy some legal test of more severe dispossession in order to avoid legal challenge to the decision it makes, that has the potential for the corporation to get itself into very hot water indeed. If we are just stating it as something sitting around in the abstract which the corporation ought to somehow have regard to, we might be able to live with that. But in the very tightly drafted form in which it appears here and as one of the principles that have to be adhered to, it has a capacity to drive a coach and horses through the rational administration of this.

Of course there will be resource allocation conflicts, and that is exactly why we are appointing a corporation to resolve them. It should be enabled to get on with the job, using all the wisdom, experience and commonsense its individual members may have accumulated over the years. We will certainly have regard to those qualities when appointing to the board. I know Senator Harradine has a certain disposition which says that commonsense is not something one finds in large measure in people charged with responsibilities of this kind. He may or may not be right, but I say to Senator Harradine that there ain't no commonsense in vesting this kind of weapon in those who might, for whatever reason, be minded to make life difficult for the administration of this particular new regime.

The agony of trying to make sense of the concept of more or less or most severe dispossession I do not think should be underestimated. I do not think I am gilding the lily on this one. It is something that I really feel quite strongly is creating a potential nightmare. The Democrats' recipe avoids that. It has in it, for all practical purposes, all the other components of the opposition amendment. For that reason I suggest that as a responsible legislature we ought to support the Democrat alternative.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like Senator Ellison to put himself in the place of a director and tell me how he would work out degrees of dispossession—who is most severely dispossessed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ellison Sen C.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —This bill is not set down as a guideline of how to judge that. It says to the Indigenous Land Corporation that it must take that into account. It is a principle.
—It is justiciable.

—And so it should be. The fact is that if we just say to the Indigenous Land Corporation, `Look, folks. We leave it to you as to how to run it. You get on with it,' and do not give it any principles to run by, there will be a deficiency that will lead to even greater strife. What this amendment says is that, when the budget is tight, when the money is thin—
—No, it doesn't—`conflict arises'.
—That is the only time that it would have a conflict because, as it states:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . if a conflict arises as to the allocation of resources—

PARA.TAB: Senator Kernot interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Hang on; let us take it step by step. `If a conflict arises as to the allocation of resources' clearly means that there is not enough money to go around for everyone because, if there were, there would not be a conflict. The amendment states:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . if a conflict arises as to the allocation of resources, preference is to be given to—
those people—
who are most severely dispossessed of their traditional lands . . .

That is a principle which the ILC would then apply. If we do not include that principle, the ILC will not have any guidance as to what it should do when the money is tight. The question of how the Indigenous Land Corporation would judge that would entail a great deal of agony for it, and so it should, and would have to be judged on a case by case basis.

PARA.TAB: We would not dare go further and say the corporation should measure it as to time of dispossession, the extent of dispossession, the number of people who have been dispossessed, how they were treated in the way they were taken off the land, how far away they were taken or whether or not they were put in a mission. We are not saying those sorts of things should be included in this bill because we could not possibly say that. However, we can make a judgment on the social formula, and that is the history of the group concerned.

We would naturally look at the history of dispossession as a starting point. We could look at the treatment that that group received; whether it had a healthy contact with the land which was, in a very draconian way, terminated. We might have a group which did not have as strong an association with that particular piece of land as another group. These are all aspects which we would have to judge on a case by case basis.

Nonetheless, this principle is in the legislation and is one which the Indigenous Land Corporation would have to address. If it were not there, it would have to be left entirely up to the corporation. The principle is there and the corporation applies it. We are not going to go so far as to tell the corporation how to apply it. I have made one or two suggestions but I would not dare to say that they were exhaustive. Others are more qualified than I to provide the criteria.

In the later provisions of the bill, dealing with the appointment of directors of the corporation, the government has a prescription as to who should be appointed. Care has to be taken that we address the diverse aspects of the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander communities in the appointments. We have to consider their backgrounds and their qualifications. This would allow a discretion in how to measure that principle. Nonetheless, the principle should be contained in the legislation as a guiding beacon and something that must be adhered to.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask Senator Ellison if he has considered that this might be about the politics of land councils and that it might be about a fear, held by those urban Aboriginal people who are represented by land councils or other community based land bodies, of the process being dominated by the Northern Territory and Western Australian land councils which predominantly represent more traditional people. At the end of the process, if this were to get up, I wonder whether the outcome would actually be achieving the right balance rather than attempting to tip it one way or the other?

—The question that Senator Kernot asks is a complex one indeed. If we could sort that out we could largely address the problem that faces the country in relation to Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islanders. As I have said, this bill should accommodate all those who have been dispossessed, from those living in Redfern in Sydney to those living in the remote areas of north-west Australia. This amendment is really referring to what happens when the funds get tight; that is the question.
—But the funds are tight from the beginning.
—They are tight from day one. There is a conflict from day one.
—I thought it was a generous offer!

—Exactly. Senator Evans is perhaps conceding that he has not allocated sufficient money to this, and I take that point. Certain moneys have been allocated and we will find that we will get to the bottom of the barrel very quickly. It is not a question of if, it is a question of when. When there are four, five or six applicants standing in line, and the fund can only afford to accommodate one of them, that is when this principle comes into play.

—The Greens will be supporting this particular amendment. The concerns that have been expressed by the government and by Senator Kernot that it would allow for excessive disputes and divisiveness are not appropriate. It is inappropriate to have an act without principles that give some guidance to the Indigenous Land Corporation as to the way in which it will determine the acquisition of lands. Any administrative decision should be guided by principles.

PARA.TAB: The Prime Minister (Mr Keating) said that the aim of the bill was to address dispossession. One has to ask: what is the government saying by its unwillingness to include the principles under which the distribution of the small amount of funds available will be made? Why is the government unwilling to address the criteria of dispossession?

In the kinds of concerns that have been raised by Senator Kernot and by Senator Gareth Evans—where they say, `This is really too tough a problem and it's going to be really hard to decide'—we have overlooked something. `Dispossessed' does not mean simply dispossessed. This is a land fund. It is a fact how much land people own or not. It was in discussion with an Aboriginal person yesterday that I realised that there are many creative and constructive ways of looking at this dilemma. One simply has to look at the communities in the region and see how much land they have. It is really quite easy to determine who has none and who has some. Similarly, there is a different level of availability.

TALK.START.PARA: —Who lost most.

—No, it is not a question—and that is where the concerns being expressed about it are inappropriate—of who wins the prize for being the most dispossessed. It is the priority of affirmative action to say, `Those communities that have least need to be considered before those communities that have more.' It is a principle that says, `If a group is well organised and reasonably capable of setting its own standards, there should be some kind of partiality in the direction of those who have less organisation and less capacity to organise themselves in that regard.'

PARA.TAB: There are two factors: one is the degree of land that is already in the possession of those people within that community. The other is the availability of land that comes up. So it is not automatic that any one criterion should prevail. There are two determinants: one is the kinds of lands that are available and whose interests are in those; and the other is the kinds of degrees of land that is already available. So there are ways of addressing this problem.

It is important that there be principles that govern the distribution of this. It is a very simple and straightforward thing that should be supported. I am not convinced by the arguments that have been put up so far. The Greens will be supporting the opposition amendment, which, as the opposition has acknowledged, is that of the New South Wales Land Council, which has plenty of experience in determining differences of degree in relation to those who are advantaged or less advantaged within their own area.

TALK.START.PARA: —Again we have the government making a decision to oppose a positive amendment which has the support of a wide range of Aboriginals and Torres Strait Islanders in Australia. As Senator Ellison said, this is a beacon; it is a principle—just as is the preamble to the Native Title Act, which Senator Kernot in December described as a splendid preamble. She went so far as to say that the preamble should be incorporated in the Australian constitution. Much of what is said in that preamble, which goes on for over two pages, in the Native Title Act are matters that put some quite specific requirements and principles into place. Again, they are principles that need to be interpreted.

PARA.TAB: The government has again built up a big, hairy-chested straw man and said that we will create a legal nightmare and the sky will cave in if we have this amendment as part of the preamble to this section of the act. It is simply not the truth, nor the case, that this creates any problem whatsoever. If it did, then the Democrats would not agree with the words `meaningful title', in relation to the title we are talking about, particularly in the first paragraph of this amendment, which we have both agreed on.

If the government wants to talk about legal interpretation and creating a legal nightmare, if it is proposed that putting in the words `most dispossessed' does that, it could equally say that `meaningful title' does that. We all know the reason why the words `meaningful title' are in the objects—because the government could not live with the strictness of the preamble to the Native Title Act that this fund would be established to assist those who are unable to assert native title rights. As Mr Ridgeway from the New South Wales Land Council said, the main reason why this fund was taken out of that act and put into a separate act was so that the preamble could be avoided.

The coalition's initial position was that that particular part of the preamble which has been quoted a number of times today should be exported out of the Native Title Act and put into this bill. As I said in my contribution to the second reading debate, the government has taken that part of the preamble to the Native Title Act and put a big red line through it. It is now a redundant part of the preamble. It is the most significant change to the Native Title Act which has taken place since December. The government has put a line through that paragraph.

The word `meaningful' is certainly open to interpretation. Had the words `native title' been there, as they appear in the preamble to the Native Title Act, it would have been quite clear—it would have been quite restrictive and quite proscriptive. The word `meaningful' has been placed in there because it allows some discretion. It is quite sensible in some ways because it says, `We will assist people who are unable to assert meaningful title.' With regard to the calamity that the government and the Democrats have agreed can occur in relation to the words `most dispossessed', that term represents a very fine principle—to assist those who have been most dispossessed. It does not need to be finely interpreted. One does not need to go to the High Court and argue over who is the most dispossessed. It is a principle. As Senator Ellison said, it is a beacon.

TALK.START.PARA: —But people can, as a result of putting it there.

—That is simply not the case because if that is the case they will be able to do that in relation to the preamble to the Native Title Act. The same people will be able to go to the court and argue about whether or not they have got meaningful title. If people have been severely dispossessed of their land, have applied for assistance by the ILC and have been rejected on the grounds that they have got some meaningful title, they will go to the court and say, `I've got hunting and fishing rights over this piece of land; I want assistance to buy the piece of land,' while the ILC says, `No, you've got some meaningful title.' One can argue about that until the cows come home.

PARA.TAB: So it is not a matter that will cause a legal nightmare. Every time there is an amendment which the government does not like it says that it will cause a legal nightmare. It is simply not the case. I urge the committee to support the fine objects that are incorporated in this coalition amendment. I am very pleased that the Greens (WA) will be supporting this and that a number of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander groups have publicly supported the objects that are included in this coalition amendment.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, we have heard the views of the New South Wales Land Council. I think its proposal for us to consider objects and principles is a very constructive one. I want to put the view of another group of Aboriginal people who argue that we should not necessarily prioritise in favour of most dispossessed to least dispossessed and that we should look after those who still have ties with the land through culture, heritage and customs, because they have a fear that without assistance these people will be completely cut off.

PARA.TAB: It is not as simple as Senator Chamarette suggests to look after those with less rather than those with more. People who have those ties might be seen to have more because they have occupation of some land but that does not necessarily equate to having more in everybody's understanding of the word.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is this an urgent fund or a dispossession fund?
—It is not urgent.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I guess we are all talking to Senator Harradine in this debate because there is no particular sign that the other positions will change, however much sweet reason flows across the chamber. I urge Senator Harradine to focus, in a way that Senator Ellison and Senator Campbell have not been prepared to, on the actual legal meaning of the language with which we are confronted.

PARA.TAB: I do not know whether they are just being disingenuous or whether they do not really understand the way in which these clauses actually work but the truth of the matter is that there is a big difference between the general language of a preamble or, in this instance, the general language of 191A(a) which refers to the principles of dispossession. It creates a context within which the corporation should and will operate and creates a `bias' in favour of assisting those who have been dispossessed and, arguably, those who have been most dispossessed. All of that is part of the flavour of that preambular language.

However, there is a hell of a difference between that sort of language and the kind of language found in the principal section in 191A(b). Here it is not just talking about the general things to which the corporation is to have regard; it is talking about principles that it has to adhere to, namely:

SPEECH.PARA: (b) if a conflict arises as to allocation preference is to be given to those Aboriginal persons or Islanders who are most severely dispossessed of their traditional lands.

There is a stark criterion to be employed and which is, by its very nature, testable in the courts. We all know enough about land council politics and competition within Aboriginal communities and the way in which these things have evolved so far to know that it will not be very long before this kind of provision is tested in the courts. That will create a terrible dilemma not only for the courts but also, of course, for the corporation in trying to make this thing work in practice and avoid this kind of hassle.

PARA.TAB: I point to some other problems that the corporation will be confronting if this clause goes in and which the courts will be confronting if there are contested claims. The previous clause of the bill, 191E(3), states:
For the purposes of the performance of the Indigenous Land Corporations land management functions, the Indigenous Land Corporation must have regard to the desirability of the following:-

SPEECH.PARA: among other things—

PARA.TAB: pursuing sound land and environmental management practices;

SPEECH.PARA: The corporation has to have regard to that in exercising its management functions. Over the page, 191F of the bill states:

PARA.TAB: The Indigenous Land Corporation must act in accordance with sound business principles whenever it performs its functions on a commercial basis.

SPEECH.PARA: It is perfectly possible to imagine a particular scenario evolving where it is very difficult to apply sound environmental or business principles to a particular claimant who arguably might be more dispossessed than some other claimant. There might be a more dispossessed claimant who, in the judgment of the corporation, is manifestly less well equipped to carry out the management standards that are inherent in this legislation, or to advance the sort of business principles that are also the responsibility of the corporation to advance.

PARA.TAB: The truth of the matter is that multiple criteria will be bouncing around in all these situations which the corporation will have to have regard to and somehow balance in all the circumstances of the environment in which it is created. To bring in one criterion over the top, particularly an inherently vague criterion of this kind—

TALK.START.PARA: —Under what section of the act will they take the people to the court in the first place?

—Senator Campbell is just demonstrating that he does not know how these provisions work in administrative law. If a corporation has to apply certain principles or criteria in the exercise of its decision making discretion, those who feel themselves to be prejudiced by the application of those criteria in decision making which has produced a result which goes against them can go to the court and argue as a matter of administrative law principle that the corporation has not done that which it should have done.
—Why wouldn't they go and argue that they don't have meaningful title?

—The problem is that once this sort of provision is made justiciable, the potential for endless divisive conflict is created. What is being made justiciable is a provision which has no inherent graspability. `Most severely dispossessed' is a very difficult concept to grab hold of.
—Why don't we help the court and describe what meaningful title is?

—It may cut across. As Senator Kernot has said, the corporation might have said, `We have two Aboriginal corporations competing for the last batch of dollars for the year. One of them is from a country area. They can't establish a native title claim to this land, but they have had an association with it. They are desperately keen to get the tract of land vested in them in order to establish a pastoral property, business or whatever. We have that kind of claim. On the other hand, another group of Aboriginal people in urban Redfern or somewhere can credibly claim to be even more severely dispossessed.' The corporation might say, `In all the circumstances of the case, we think the money can be more appropriately and better spent on the first group.'

PARA.TAB: The situation creates the potential for conflict. Once a legal weapon of this kind is created, the prospect of conflict is enhanced. I know enough about the way the real world operates, and has operated in this area, to be confident in my judgment about this. It cannot be wished away. Part of the contribution from opposition senators was, `We do not intend that these sorts of issues will be battled out in the courts in this way. That is not our intention. All we want the corporation to do is build this principle into its thinking.'

That is not what those senators have done. They have created a criterion which will not only be built into the corporation's general thinking, but be built into its day-to-day practical decision making operations. It will be very divisive and disruptive. That is the argument. I cannot add anything more to it.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want briefly to refute something Senator Gareth Evans implied to those of us who know less about the law. The way in which this could be tested by the courts is if it were proved that no reasonable person could have come to that conclusion. That is the burden of proof. There is no dispute that there may be differences of opinion, but when it comes to taking it to the court, the principle simply has to be shown to be reasonably in operation.

PARA.TAB: It is misleading to this chamber to imply that it will lead to endless court cases. It is simply a principle under which an administrative decision is made. It is challengeable, and it should be, because it has to keep that administrative system tuned to its guidelines. One of the most important principles—it is not just a principle—is that this is a land acquisition fund to address the dispossession of 200 years. It is quite reasonable to have a principle that can be acted on in this way.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Evans's principle might be right, but if he wants an interpretation which can be argued in front of a court people will argue who has meaningful title and who has not. They will argue that. This morning, Senator Evans has described groups of people who might have a small bundle of rights. That could not be regarded as meaningful title, so they will have to buy the freehold. We now accept that is the case.

PARA.TAB: In his last contribution, Senator Evans tried to compare a property in the pastoral region with a property in Redfern. That specifically makes the point that it is uncontestable in court. The group in Redfern could not possibly take the corporation to court and say, `Because you have bought a pastoral property here in Western Australia under a regional strategy, you should have bought this place in Redfern.' That is the principle, and it makes a farce of what the minister is saying.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am pleased that the opposition and the Democrats have moved an amendment to this legislation relating to the objects and principles. Obviously, the government has failed in this task. It is most important, as has been indicated in the debate, that there be objects of the legislation. These objects have been set out and are being proposed by the opposition's amendment. They are clear in my mind, and I need to describe them in order to—

PARA.TAB: The TEMPORARY CHAIRMAN (Senator McGauran)—Order! It being 12.45 p.m., I must now report progress.
Progress reported.

DEBATE.TITLE: EDUCATION SERVICES FOR OVERSEAS STUDENTS (REGISTRATION OF PROVIDERS AND FINANCIAL REGULATION) AMENDMENT BILL 1994

PARA.TAB: Debate resumed from 21 September, on motion by Senator Crowley:
That this bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —This is a very small amendment to the Education Services for Overseas Students (Registration of Providers and Financial Regulation) Amendment Act of 1993. Clause 6A(5) of the act reads:

SPEECH.PARA: The regulations may make provision for or in relation to exempting providers from the requirements of this section.

The section in turn refers to providers operating a trust account. In other words, at the moment they can be exempted entirely from those provisions. The amendment that the Senate is debating today changes that particular subclause to read:
The regulations may make provision for or in relation to exempting providers, either wholly or partly, from some or all of the requirements of this section.

In other words, if this small amendment is passed today, the government can make regulations that would exempt providers from part of the obligation and not simply from the whole of the obligation. The need to make this amendment has come about as a result of negotiations with which the Senate would be very familiar. Nevertheless, I will remind the Senate very briefly of the circumstances.

PARA.TAB: In 1993 after the financial collapse of a large private college, the Commonwealth was forced to fund the loss at a cost of about $2.2 million. It was decided to strengthen the ESOS act to protect further students' prepaid fees. In December 1993, legislation was passed which required education providers to have trust accounts for prepaid student fees and also to be members of a tuition assurance scheme. The detail of these schemes was to be provided in regulations that had to be in place by 30 June 1994.

The government finally tabled the regulations in parliament on 1 June, less than one month before they were due to come into effect. In response to massive industry concern, Senator Bell gave notice that he would be moving to disallow the regulations. On a motion moved by me, on behalf of the coalition, the regulations were referred to the Senate Standing Committee on Employment, Education and Training. In other words, we believed that disallowance alone did not resolve the problems and that, in fact, the Senate, through its committee structure, could contribute to what were the deficiencies in the government's proposed regulatory regime.

As a result of evidence that was presented to the committee, particularly evidence from the industry which criticised the regulations as being unworkable, impractical and unfair, there followed further consultation between the government agencies and the industry groups. On 28 June, Mr Crean announced that the government had backed down. Agreement had been reached between industry and his department and changes would be made to the regulations and to the act.

The government has since made and tabled regulations which provide for the changes agreed to with regard to the tuition assurance scheme. It is now proposed to amend the act in order that the agreement in relation to trust account reforms can be implemented by means of regulation.

The anticipated regulations which will flow from the amendment to the act will allow for payment of only 80 per cent rather than 100 per cent of prepaid tuition fees into trust accounts, with current provisions for draw-downs of a further 25 per cent on course commencement and thereafter weekly in arrears. This will take into account common industry practices, where offshore agents deduct their 20 per cent commission before forwarding the balance of the students' course fees to the provider in Australia.

The anticipated regulations will also allow for a non-refundable enrolment fee of no more than $250. This will cover payment of administrative costs incurred before the student arrives in Australia, costs which are incurred regardless of whether the student eventually obtains a visa.

These are the agreed amended regulations and they are agreed by us also. I reiterate what I said when last this issue was before the Senate, that the final negotiated agreement represents a major victory for the Senate—a victory, we would say, for the coalition in referring the matter to the Senate committee which facilitated this satisfactory outcome, and also a victory, I guess the Australian Democrats would say, for the Democrats in moving the notice of disallowance.

There is no doubt that the government, through its bungling, nearly put at risk the viability and international competitiveness of a major export industry. I hope that the government has learnt lessons from this experience. We certainly commend to the Senate the amendment which is now before the chamber, because it now enables the government to make regulations that are satisfactory.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak on the Education Services for Overseas Students (Registration of Providers and Financial Regulation) Amendment Bill 1994, which amends the Education Services for Overseas Students (Registration of Providers and Financial Regulation) Act 1991. In particular, I support the comments of my colleague Senator Hill, who outlined what has happened with this legislation and the subsequent regulations. It is a great victory for the Senate that finally we have arrived at this point. I would remind the Senate that this has taken some years—years that would not have been necessary if the government had been prepared to listen to the reasoned arguments of the Senate, in particular the Senate Standing Committee on Employment, Education and Training, and also the main industry providers.

PARA.TAB: We have finally—after two years—got to the point suggested by the industry and by this parliament. It was a rather painful and tortuous process. An enormous amount of work was undertaken by the industry and by this parliament to get to the position where we should have been in the first place. That is very surprising. It almost brought a sense of deja vu about what happened in this same area when I first came into parliament. Mr Dawkins as the minister at the time wanted to bring in draconian regulations to regulate this industry but he was blocked by the Senate; yet again, two years later, we have found the same thing happening.

One of the most heartening outcomes of all this—as I suppose often happens—was that, despite what the government was doing, the industry still managed to boom. I think that was due partly to the fact that we managed to have a deregulatory framework early on in the piece.

During the 3 1/2 years I have been in parliament, this industry has grown from a $800 million industry to one of $1,500 million. In other words, it has almost doubled in a four-year period. It was very necessary that this deregulatory framework which we started should stay. Despite that, and despite what happened in 1991-92, when we got to December 1993 the government proposed—yet again—to bring in more draconian controls, and in a way that was going to put up costs to the industry and force a lot of marginal providers out of business.

The government legislated to establish trust accounts for prepaid student fees. We all agree that protecting student fees is an excellent idea but the way in which the government was going about it was by creating a tuition assurance scheme. It could not really define it in the earlier stages but it would have needed a reassurance proposal where the students' money would have had to have been protected in a system that would have added greatly to the costs of the business.

One of the most disturbing things about the proposal at that time was that the government decided to create a regulatory framework and did not have the full details of how this tuition assurance scheme was going to be established, who was going to run it and the way in which contributions were to be collected. It said it was going to leave all this to regulation. This created a very dangerous precedent, not just in terms of educational legislation but in terms of legislation in this parliament. If we give away the right to give full scrutiny to legislation in this parliament, we are just handing the true role of the parliament over to the bureaucrats. As all members of the Senate know, if we do not put things in the act, if we put them in the regulations, they can be changed. We have a regulations and ordinances committee but its members cannot offer the scrutiny that this parliament offers. So parliament did move and, over time, has changed the whole approach to put it back into the act. That is precisely what the industry wanted.

There is enormous concern by the different groups in the education export industry. I speak particularly of ACPET, which is in the area of business education; ELICOS, which is in the business of language education; the TAFE colleges and the Australian Vice-Chancellors Committee. When this proposed change was put up originally in late 1993, there was not a great deal of consultation with these groups. When consultation did occur, it seemed that DEET was not listening. It had its own hidden agenda; it was still working on its command economy model out of the Dawkins era. It knew best. It was a top-down scheme; it was one that was not sensitive to the needs of the industry and was going to raise the costs of the industry.

The net result of all this was that we had great uncertainty and interference for the period of 18 months and that is most regrettable. The government action was widely criticised by the industry and by overseas students. They wanted a workable framework for quality assurance and safeguards of student prepaid fees but they did not want the heavy-handed bureaucratic approach that was proposed by the government. The government's proposal was going to put up their costs and take away the independence of educational providers. It was going to hamper their international competitiveness. The concern of the Senate standing committee meant that we had a referral to scrutinise this whole process. We had a series of hearings where evidence that was highly critical was presented by the industry.

An interesting innovation in Senate practice is that quite often we hold a series of half-day or one-day hearings where we bring industry representatives in and we have the government departments sitting there through it. They have to respond to what the industry is saying and then we have a round table conference to try to resolve the matter. That was not making much headway until DEET was finally mugged by the reality of what the parliament can do in terms of stopping inappropriate legislation. The combination of Senator Bell's disallowance motion and Senator Hill's referral to the committee was where the government really had a gun to its head and had no option but to cave in, back down and accept the recommendations of this parliament and the recommendations of the industry.

The effects of this bill are that the government's anticipated regulations will now allow for a payment of 80 per cent—not 100 per cent as required by section 6A of the 1991 act—of prepaid tuition fees into trust accounts.
