This is what the industry wanted. It will provide for further draw-downs from the trust accounts of 25 per cent on commencement of courses and then weekly in arrears. Again, that is what the industry wanted. It takes into account the common practice of 20 per cent of the money being retained offshore before forwarding the balance to Australia. Under the system proposed by DEET the locals would have to cover that. It also allows for a non-refundable enrolment fee of $250 for administrative costs incurred by the local industry. This very satisfactory outcome is only possible because of the measures I mentioned above, and it is a real win for Senate scrutiny.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SCHACHT
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Small Business, Customs and Construction)

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of my colleague Minister Crean I want to put a couple of points on the record about the Education Services for Overseas Students (Registration of Providers and Financial Regulation) Amendment Bill 1994 and the regulations that go with it.

PARA.TAB: The growth of Australia's international education industry depends upon the confidence that students overseas have in the quality of the courses they undertake, and the protection of moneys they invest in receiving an Australian education. The ESOS act was first introduced in 1991 following the damage caused to Australia's reputation by the financial collapse of several private education providers and consequent publicity overseas about the problems of students who lost money as a result.

During the debate on the ESOS bill in 1991, the Senate watered down the protection offered by the act to international students. The limitations of the 1991 ESOS act were subsequently exposed by the collapse of further institutions, causing over 430 international students to lose their prepaid fees. The government had to refund $1.3 million to affected students in order to protect Australia's reputation. I notice that Senator Hill and Senator Tierney did not claim any credit for being involved in watering down the 1991 act, so that we again had weaknesses which cost Australian taxpayers another $1.3 million, which is typical of the profligate attitude which the opposition has about public expenditure.

Following college failures during 1993, the ESOS act was amended in December 1993 to strengthen the protection that the act offers to international students' prepaid funds. These amendments included the requirement for providers to deposit all prepaid course money received directly or indirectly from international students into notified trust accounts and to withdraw those funds in accordance with the regulations. Regulations prescribing the draw-down requirements of funds from the trust accounts and the requirements for providers to be members of a tuition assurance scheme—TAS—were subject to notices of motion of disallowance and later referred to the Senate Standing Committee on Employment, Education and Training. The notices of motion disallowance of the regulations were withdrawn on 23 August 1994 following acceptance by the Senate of Mr Crean's proposed package of amendments.

Following the Senate standing committee hearing on regulations in June, the minister proposed a package of amendments to the legislation which addressed industry concerns about the trust account provisions in return for retaining the TAS provision in a modified form to meet the government's concerns for a safety net to protect the interests of international students.

Amendments to the regulations which give effect to these proposals relating to the TAS requirements have been made; amendments to the trust account regulations require an amendment to the principal act. Currently providers who are not exempt from the financial regulations of the ESOS act are required to deposit all prepaid course money received directly or indirectly from international students into notified trust accounts, and to withdraw these funds in accordance with the regulations.

Industry has expressed concern that these regulations, in particular the drawn-down percentages, are too strict and that the money can only be withdrawn from trust accounts after the student receives a visa. The current amendments to the act seek to provide for more flexible exemption provisions to give effect to the proposals to ensure not only the protection of international students' prepaid funds, but also that the industry is able to operate without encountering cash flow problems.

With the proposed amendment to the ESOS act, the ESOS regulations may make provisions for exempting providers either wholly or partly from the requirement to deposit 100 per cent of the prepaid course money they receive from overseas students. This amendment will enable amendments to the ESOS regulations which will exempt providers from depositing 20 per cent of the prepaid tuition fees, to take into account common industry practices where offshore agents deduct their commissions before forwarding the balance of the students' course fees to the provider in Australia. Providers will also be exempt from depositing an enrolment fee of no more than $250. With this amendment to the act, the government is confident that Australia's education and training, and export industry can grow and develop.

In conclusion, I want to say that one of the great successes in economic development terms as well as in education terms for this government over the last 11 1/2 years has been to transform education services into being a major export industry now earning Australia several billion dollars a year in export earnings, and to establish that as a major industry in Australia, adding to the economic wealth and therefore to the employment opportunities of many Australians. This bill further enhances those opportunities. The development of this industry is one of the great achievements of the present government.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.
Motion (by Senator Schacht) agreed to:
That the consideration of the bill in committee of the whole be made an order of the day for the next day of sitting.

DEBATE.TITLE: LAW AND JUSTICE LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL (No. 2) 1994

PARA.TAB: Debate resumed from 30 June, on motion by Senator Crowley:
That this bill be now read a second time.

TALK.START.PARA: —The purpose of the Law and Justice Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1994 is to amend a number of acts administered within the portfolio of the Attorney-General. The bill contains some amendments of a minor policy nature. The bill amends the Law Officers Act 1964 to allow the Governor-General to appoint a person to act as Solicitor-General during a vacancy in the office of Solicitor-General or in circumstances where the Solicitor-General is unable to perform the functions of the office. The bill also amends the Service and Execution of Process Act 1992 to provide that, apart from an initiating process or subpoena, service may be effected in certain circumstances at the address for service of the company or registered body in the proceedings.

PARA.TAB: Perhaps the most important provisions of the bill are the amendments to the Trade Practices Act: to increase the penalties for breaches of product safety and information provisions of the act and to amend the basis upon which an officer may exercise his or her powers of entry without warrant to inspect unsafe goods; further, to allow the secretary to the department responsible for the enforcement of the product safety and information provisions of the act to accept and apply to the court to enforce written undertakings in connection with matters in which he or she has powers or functions under the act; and also to allow the use of penalty infringement notices as an alternative to prosecution for failure to notify the minister of a voluntary recall of unsafe goods.

As I have said before, the most contentious aspects of the bill are probably those aspects which concern the desirability of conferring powers of entry on authorised officers of the Trade Practices Commission. In this regard the bill amends division 1A of part V of the Trade Practices Act, which deals with product safety and product information. Section 65Q of this part confers upon the minister or authorised officers the power to obtain information and documents from a supplier relating to goods which will or may cause injury.

This bill was the subject of an inquiry by the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs. Some concerns were raised which did not relate directly to these amendments but to the provisions in the principal act. The committee thought that at some future stage it would be useful for the Attorney-General and for parliament to revisit the reasons for the original provision of powers for officers of the Trade Practices Commission to have the right to enter premises in the way in which the act now allows.

I personally feel that there is an argument of justification in this area because we are dealing with public safety. We are dealing possibly with a situation where a product which is dangerous to the health of people—perhaps a toy which is dangerous to the health of children—could be released unless the manufacturer or trader concerned could be stopped at very short notice from doing so. We need to balance the civil liberties arguments that are being brought on behalf of the manufacturer with the argument of safeguarding public health. It is not an argument, in my view, that these provisions have not been used since they were introduced a number of years ago, because an emergency could arise at any moment. I believe that this chamber and this parliament would not wish to soften provisions which might prevent a tragedy in those circumstances.

I comment briefly on one amendment which has become necessary due to a drafting error in the bill. That is in group 6, paragraph 65Q(3)(b), which was intended to add, `and in order to prevent the goods in question from being concealed, lost or destroyed, or from being removed from the premises.' This is a very good explanation as to why these powers need to be exercised and why they need to be there. Unfortunately, such powers are not given by the principal act and this paragraph, if passed, would have caused a conflict and made the provisions virtually inoperable. That was the advice of officers from the Attorney-General's Department and I understand that the government is moving to remove that. While it is obviously technically necessary to remove these words, I believe that they are a good expression and a good description of why these provisions are necessary. The Australian Democrats will be supporting the bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ellison Sen C.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will just summarise, in relation to provisions, that this Law and Justice Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1994 covers the areas of legislation of the Law Officers Act 1964, which Senator Spindler has outlined, and the Service and Execution of Process Act as well. They really are quite straightforward amendments and are very sensible indeed.

PARA.TAB: The problem, of course, arises in the Trade Practices Act, and Senator Spindler has touched on the areas of concern. The Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs recently held a hearing in relation to this. It came to light that there was some concern in relation to the powers of entry that some of these officers had—powers which really were akin to police powers. I am referring to section 65Q of the legislation. In my dissenting report to that report by the legal and constitutional affairs committee, I indicated that a complaint has been levelled by the Australian Federal Police Association that, under the present act, officers concerned had these powers without having the relevant training. Mr Law, who appeared for that association, was of the view that governments should be very cautious in giving any public officers powers of police entry or powers of police seizure where they do not have the necessary training.

Members of the Australian Federal Police have that training and, indeed, are qualified to carry out those powers. Really, the section itself needs revisiting. As I understand the amendment, it limits the powers of the officers in some way rather than extending them as had initially been thought. Quite frankly, the section itself, which was brought in in 1986, ought to be looked at and we should query whether the officers concerned should have those powers.
There was also, during that hearing, some questioning of the efficacy of this amendment. The report, in dealing with the amendment to 65Q(3)(b), stated:

Evidence before the Committee indicated that there was a serious deficiency in the proposed amendment . . . Ms Johnson of the Attorney-General's Department gave evidence that the additional requirement could never be met. The amendment adds the additional condition that the entry must be required in order to prevent the goods in question from being concealed, lost or destroyed.

SPEECH.PARA: In evidence, Ms Johnson stated:
It actually makes it impossible ever to exercise the power, in our view, because the additional requirement can never be met.
Senator Spindler, who was questioning her at that stage, asked:
Would you explain that in a bit more detail, please?
Ms Johnson stated further:
The additional requirement is the protection of evidence. It says:
`. . . and in order to prevent the goods in question from being concealed, lost or destroyed or from being removed from the premises.'

That is an additional requirement before the power can be exercised and there is no power in the act to do any of those things. They cannot seize all the goods. They cannot prohibit the person who owns or has charge of the goods from doing anything with them until a few days later when the minister makes his prohibition.

So we have a situation where the section in the first instance has some deficiency in that it affords too much power to a public officer. Then we have the proposed amendment, of which we have here evidence that it is unworkable. The government should really look at this closely. It is an aspect which needs attention.

PARA.TAB: The other aspect of increasing penalties initially caused me some concern. However, I do not think that this really is sufficient to make a stand on. It is related to the penalty points that, as I understand it, the Commonwealth is now using. That is appropriate. The main concern I have in relation to this matter is the police type powers of entry that some of these officers have. That aspect needs review.
Debate (on motion by Senator Schacht) adjourned.

TALKER.NAME: Senator GARETH EVANS
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Government in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I inform the Senate that Senator McMullan will be absent from question time today to enable him to travel to Port Moresby to participate in the annual joint bilateral business council meeting. I will answer questions relating to Trade; Senator Collins will take questions on Communications and the Arts matters; and questions relating to Administrative Services should be directed to Senator Bolkus.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Transport. Does the CAA's drafted and circulated strategic plan provide for a reduction in rescue firefighting service personnel at Australia's airports? Does this mean a 10 per cent cut in rescue personnel at Sydney airport? How can the minister justify these safety cuts after the Ansett crash at Sydney airport yesterday?
—It is there somewhere.

—No, it is not. Mr President, I do not have any information specifically provided to me by the Minister for Transport on that draft management plan, so I will refer Senator Macdonald's question to the minister.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. If I can help the minister, who used to be the transport minister and should have been aware of this, the strategic plan from the CAA in September 1994 provides for a substantial cut. It is a document that has been fairly widely circulated, so I do ask the minister to bring this matter to the minister's attention. Obviously, the minister is not aware of it either or he would not be acting in the cavalier way that he is, but it is a 10 per cent reduction in fire safety personnel. I ask the minister to get the transport minister to seriously look at this proposal and not to let it happen if the proposal is to reduce fire safety services at Sydney airport and, I might say, at other airports around the country.
—I just clearly said that I would refer the question to the Minister for Transport.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy. Last Thursday, Senator McGauran referred to the Prime Minister's commitment in his drought statement of 21 September to meet with major banks to discuss their relationships with their rural clients. Senator McGauran asked the minister whether the Prime Minister had met this commitment and sought details of the outcome of that meeting. The commitment of the banks is very important to farmers both during the drought and in the recovery stage. I note—
—Is this a speech or a question?
—You will get the question now, Shortie. I note from today's press that the Prime Minister—

PARA.TAB: Honourable senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Senator Cook and Senator Hill.

—I thought I ought to mention the senator who was interested on that side. We know Senator Hill is not very interested in people who are suffering from the drought. I note from today's press that the Prime Minister, the Treasurer and the minister met with the banks yesterday. Can the minister advise—(Time expired)

—I am sure the Leader of the Opposition's irritability in this chamber today is caused by the glowing reports he had of how brilliantly Senator Alston performed in his absence in question time yesterday. Who is saying `Hear, hear!'?

PARA.TAB: I read with interest an editorial in today's Australian headed `Farmers bank on good terms'. The editorial pointed out that it is crucial to national prosperity that rural Australia be given every opportunity to recover from the worst drought in living memory. It said that the ability to cope with debt will be central to that recovery, and I agree wholeheartedly.

It is in this context that the Prime Minister, the Treasurer and I met with representatives of major banks and pastoral houses yesterday. The banks expressed the view that the government's policy settings are sound and that the rural adjustment scheme is well targeted towards assisting viable farm enterprises. In particular, the recent changes, which they noted, I must say, in exceptional circumstances RAS to a demand driven program were seen as a significant boost to the effectiveness of the scheme and its ability to deliver maximum assistance to eligible farmers.

The Prime Minister underlined the importance the government placed on the ongoing support of financial institutions to their rural clients. He also made the point that financial institutions and government must work together to ensure that viable farm enterprises survive the current drought and have the resources to manage the recovery once the drought breaks.

The government did receive assurances that farm clients would be treated responsibly and risk margins would, wherever possible, be kept to a minimum. The government is satisfied that the banks and the pastoral houses have been operating in the most responsible way possible in what are undeniably difficult financial and social circumstances resulting from the drought, and will continue to do this both during the drought and after it breaks.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Employment, Education and Training. What responsibility or obligation does the CES have to provide employers with correct details of the jobstart program? Why is the onus upon employers to verify the accuracy of the jobstart canvassing card, which is provided by the CES? Why was there no advice provided to jobstart clients immediately after the release of the Working Nation white paper on 4 May to alert them to the fact that the jobstart subsidy rate would fall on 4 July?
—I do not have any of that direct information for the senator. I will take it on notice and get back to her, I hope even by the end of question time if I can.

—Order! I draw the attention of honourable senators to the presence in the President's Gallery of members of the Select Committee on Finance and General Affairs of the parliament of the Republic of Ireland, led by the chairman of the committee, Mr John Ellis. On behalf of honourable senators, I have pleasure in welcoming you to the Senate and wish you a productive and informative visit to Australia.

PARA.TAB: Honourable senators—Hear, hear!

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Industry, Science and Technology. The minister would be aware of recent suggestions that Australia's science and research base is being seriously eroded by a brain drain to overseas countries, as our leading scientists, engineers and technologists move offshore to pursue their professional interests. Can the minister inform the Senate whether there is any basis for these claims?

—I have seen claims of this character. This is one of those urban myths. Indeed, in looking through the opposition's directional statement, The Things that Matter, it says under the heading of science and technology, `stop the brain drain of scientists from Australia.' Of course, the brain drain is a myth, and it has been a myth for a number of years. In reality, Australia has a brain gain.

PARA.TAB: I will cite the facts. Immigration data shows that in the 10-year period to 1992-93 Australia had a net influx of 28,000 engineers, scientists and academics in the science and engineering area and every year saw a net gain in these categories. The extent of this inflow can be measured by a comparison with the output of degree completions from Australian universities. The net influx is equivalent to about 18 per cent of all science and engineering degree completions in Australia for all of that period, that is, the equivalent of the annual graduate output of scientists and engineers from about eight average sized Australian universities.

The Institution of Engineers has done some further work which confirms an influx of engineers into this country. Further, the immigrant scientists, engineers and academics tend to be people with some years of experience. They are not raw graduates; they tend to be experienced scientists.

Recent anecdotal evidence shows that Australia has been one of the largest recipients of emigrating ex-Soviet scientists and engineers and, in fact, we could say that Australia is a site for international scientists to come to. But overall the impact is a net brain gain and not the illusion that the opposition has put abroad, that there is in this country a brain drain.

Mr President, some people might defend the ludicrous position of a brain drain by saying, `But we are losing quality people.' That is not true either. The normal pattern is for graduate Australians to go overseas for postgraduate work and come back, or to go overseas and find work and eventually return. Of course, not all of them come back, but the vast majority do.

There is a number of eminent Australians who have sought work overseas, obtained it, come back to Australia and contributed to enrich our science and technology base in this country. They include Sir Mark Oliphant and Harry Messel; and I have a list here of some 16 or so other leading Australian scientists, including Sir Gustav Nossal, Michael Pitman, John Stocker, Colin Adam, and Roy Green—and the list goes on—all eminent Australian scientists who have gone overseas, worked and come back, and contributed their knowledge of international science to Australia.

It is vitally important that Australians do travel abroad, so that Australia is locked into world scientific thought and debate, participate in breaking through the barriers in science elsewhere in the world and return to this country that body of corporate knowledge that enriches our scientific base.

For those opposite to claim in The Things That Matter—a document that has slipped from public consciousness, I admit—that the first thing they will do is reverse the brain drain is to attack a straw man. There was a brain drain in this country when those opposite were in power. But would they please make an effort to keep up with modern developments.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Woodley Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories and concerns the baseline studies for the Port Hinchinbrook development. I refer the minister to his media release on 1 October where he states:

QUESTION.PARA: There should be no dredging until and unless the results of the proposed baseline studies are available.

The baseline studies refer to the inshore study and the wider channel study. Does he stand by the statement, given that the Queensland minister for the environment, in explaining the two baseline studies, said on ABC radio on 4 October, `There is a second study which is a 12-month study,' which she referred to later as being `specifically to get a total seasonal approach to changes and so on'? Does the minister agree, in light of this, that there should be no dredging of the Hinchinbrook Channel for at least 12 months?

TALK.START.PARA: —As I have said in here on a number of occasions, the Valentine report, which was commissioned by my portfolio, identified four major concerns essentially relating to the marine environment and the construction of the marina at Port Hinchinbrook. The report also identified lack of information as a major problem.

PARA.TAB: The Queensland government is addressing the issue of inadequate information by undertaking two groups of baseline studies in the Hinchinbrook Channel area. The first group of studies are baseline studies adjacent to the project site and cover three aspects: a seagrass survey, water turbidity and water quality. The Commonwealth will be involved in the evaluation of the data that is produced by those studies.

The second group of studies will survey the Hinchinbrook Channel and will examine the impact of the Oyster Point development in the context of other pressures on the channel. The Commonwealth, in relation to this study, will be participating in the design of the studies and the evaluation of the data.

In my advice to the Queensland government, I indicated that I support the program of environmental baseline studies of the area that are impacted by the proposed development works and that, if properly conducted, these studies should be adequate to address most of the concerns raised in the Valentine report about the lack of information. The results of the studies will be reviewed by my department and precise details on the process, the method and the timing for the evaluation of both groups of baseline studies are currently being determined.

I cannot say whether the first group of studies will lead me to being confident that dredging will proceed. I cannot say that. My concerns about dredging will not be resolved after the passage of a certain amount of time but will only be resolved when the results of the baseline studies are available.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I thank the minister for his answers, which are always comprehensive. Given that in just three weeks there has already been a mud slick into the channel, a large amount of material slumped off the bund wall, a raw diversionary channel being built and almost clear felling of the site which will substantially increase the sediment run-off—I believe the minister has copies of the same photos that were sent to me last night and which depict these problems—does the minister believe these land based activities are also a threat to the World Heritage values of the channel?

—Mr President, the whole problem with this development is the lack of a thorough environmental impact assessment. The Valentine report, as I have mentioned in this chamber on a number of occasions, has drawn attention to the absence of information about these impacts. The baseline studies are designed to redress this situation, certainly in relation to the obligations the Commonwealth government has with this development which go mainly to the impact on World Heritage values in the area. But in the absence of the baseline studies, I am unable to comment on the impact of the land based activities.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs. What is the government's response to yesterday's bomb attack on a crowded bus in Tel Aviv? What is the government's assessment of the impact of the bombing on the Middle East peace process?

—Mr President, the government is very deeply shocked and saddened, as would be all Australians, by this latest act of terrorism, responsibility for which has been claimed by the Islamic extremist group Hamas. The attack, which the Israeli authorities believe to have been the work of a suicide bomber, as honourable senators would have seen in the press, has claimed the lives of 22 people and injured more than 40, at least four of them critically. As I said in this place on Monday, Australia obviously condemns terrorism in whatever form it occurs. This recent outrage is no exception. We condemn in the strongest possible terms those responsible for this criminal act which has resulted in the loss of so many innocent lives.

PARA.TAB: I have today sent a message to my Israeli colleague, foreign minister Shimon Peres, expressing on behalf of the government and the people of Australia our profound condolences to the injured and the families of the victims. Despite the shadow which the bombing of the bus and other recent acts of violence have cast over the peace accords which Israel has reached with the Palestinians and, more recently, with Jordan, we do believe that such setbacks will not succeed in reversing the process towards peace. It is clear that there is broad recognition among the leaders of the Middle East that terrorism must not be permitted to affect the direction and momentum of the peace process.

We welcome the fact that PLO chairman, Yasser Arafat, has unequivocally condemned the bombing and affirmed that the only response to what he has called `the enemies of peace' is to proceed with the negotiations. We welcome the fact that Israel has also confirmed that its negotiations with the PLO on extending Palestinian self-rule, including modalities for the election of a Palestinian Council, will not be disrupted although the talks have been temporarily adjourned by mutual agreement.

We welcome the fact that Jordanian leaders have condemned the attack and affirmed their view that it would not defeat the peace process, and that Egypt's foreign minister, Amr Moussa, has also condemned the bombing. We applaud the resolve of the countries of the Middle East to press ahead with their task of creating a new political and economic reality in the region, undeterred by the threat of terrorism. The agreement to be signed next week by Israel and Jordan, coupled with the progress the Palestinians have made towards self-government, places the region on the threshold of a new era of peace, stability and economic prosperity.

We remain confident that despite the complexities of the Israel-Syria negotiating track, President Assad will not retreat from the strategic decision he has made to make peace with Israel. Despite such deplorable attacks as yesterday's bombing, Australia urges the governments and peoples of the region not to lose sight of the goal of a comprehensive peace settlement, which is now almost within reach. The alternative to peace can only be descent into a perpetual cycle of violence, the horrendous nature of which was demonstrated again so graphically yesterday.

TALK.START.PARA: —I welcome back Senator Herron and congratulate him on the very important contributions he made on our behalf in Rwanda.

PARA.TAB: Honourable senators—Hear, hear!

TALK.START.PARA: —Thank you, Mr President.
—In Ireland as well.

—Yes; and I welcome my Irish colleagues. There is a critical shortage of blood products—I am sorry, Mr President; I am out of practice. My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Human Services and Health. There is a critical shortage of blood products to treat people with haemophilia in Australia, and the Commonwealth Serum Laboratories has already warned of an impending national severe shortage of blood products by December this year. In view of the immediate and current crisis, why did the Minister for Human Services and Health refer this matter to a working party to report some time next year? Further, as the Therapeutic Goods Authority has approved a recombinant factor VIII product which will substantially overcome the severe shortage, can the minister assure the Senate that people with haemophilia will have access to blood products by December 1994 to provide for a level of adequate treatment?

—Senator Herron indicated that he was out of practice. After two weeks of representing Dr Lawrence in this chamber, I am just getting into practice. I think we will have to ask Dr Lawrence those questions. I will certainly refer them to her.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Surely the minister could answer yes or no to the second part of my question, which was: can the minister assure the Senate that people with haemophilia will have access to blood products by December? Can he or can he not assure them?

—I have indicated that I think this is a matter that ought to be properly referred to Dr Lawrence. I will do that, and I will undertake to get Senator Herron a response as soon as is practicable. I am not an expert in this particular matter, and I think the proper course of action is for me to refer it to Dr Lawrence. That is precisely what I intend to do. Although Senator Herron has extended the invitation to me again, I am sure we will be able to provide a response to him quickly.

—My question, which is directed to the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories, relates to ERIN. I am not referring to the island from whence the parliamentary committee comes but to the environmental resource information network, ERIN, a unit of the minister's department from whence he recently launched a new computer based environmental information service. I ask the minister to describe to the Senate how this service will be used and how it will help achieve a national approach to environmental monitoring and education. What are the benefits of increased accessibility to environmental information of this kind?

—Since ERIN was established five years ago the service has developed dramatically, not only achieving local and national recognition but also receiving international accolades. The ERIN databases are designed to store and constantly update information on a whole range of Australian environmental issues, from climate to endangered species, from land management to information on government programs. It even provides a list of useful contacts and select bibliographies.

PARA.TAB: The service is designed to provide up-to-date environmental information to people who undertake environmental planning and decisions making tasks. The idea is that all relevant environmental information collected or obtained by any Commonwealth agency can be added to the ERIN system, allowing an enormous number of users to access an ever-growing range of data. It is just commonsense that scientists, educators, researchers, managers, concerned citizens—in fact, everyone—should learn to share as much information that is available. Knowledge in this arena is of no use unless it is shared knowledge.

The new ERIN on-line service—or EOS as it is called—which I launched yesterday, uses the latest multimedia technology to make information on ERIN's databases readily accessible to anyone who wants to use it—from school students to research scientists. The service combines database, graphics, analysis and networking technology which allows both general and specific information to be accessed extremely easily, and in a way that I think is both informative and interesting.

Now more than ever Australians will have the information that will enable them to contribute to the environmental debate; a debate which is central to our future as a nation and to the global community as well. At the launch of the Commonwealth cultural policy on Tuesday, the Prime Minister again highlighted how important it is that Australia be at the cutting edge in the development of the international information super highway. As he said last month, building the information highway is important but inventing the things that go on it is more important.

The EOS is a superb example of the type and quality of information that the super highway should include. The EOS will be available on the Internet and Australia's Aarnet, making ERIN a truly international shared resource. A quality information technology product is only as good as the quality of the information and research behind it. There is no doubt about the high calibre of scientific knowledge about the Australian environment. Our approaches, findings and solutions have global applications.

ERIN could not have achieved what it has without the close and continuing cooperation and collaboration from many groups in research, in academia, in government, in industry, and also in sectors of the community. I really think that this provides us with a window into the future. Continuing developments in technology and knowledge mean that our ability to manage and monitor our continental and global environment can only improve.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Consumer Affairs. Is the minister aware of today's press reports that the Minister for Consumer Affairs will dump the government's origin labelling legislation rather than accept amendments from the coalition and the Democrats—despite comments from the ACTU President, Martin Ferguson, that the ACTU `is concerned about the inadequacy of the government's legislation and its major thrust'; despite public statements from great Australian food processors like SPC `that government legislation was a misguided approach' and Golden Circle's `concern at the use of the "made in Australia" label'; and despite the NFF's concern that `"made in Australia" should only be used to describe goods manufactured in Australia from Australian ingredients'? Will the minister give an assurance that she will not withdraw the legislation and act against the wishes of the ACTU, Australian workers, farmers, processors and consumers?

—I am aware of the article because Senator Boswell has just passed it across the chamber to me. I thank him for that. The government has made no decision as to withdrawing the legislation, and that is essentially our current position.

PARA.TAB: However, I can understand the frustration that Mrs McHugh, the Minister for Consumer Affairs, may be experiencing at the moment. Not only is she introducing legislation which encompasses the internationally accepted definition of `made in', but she has also had problems trying to work out where the opposition is coming from. It was only a few months ago that what Senator Boswell is now proposing—the interchange between `made in' and `manufactured in'—was rejected by those opposite. The minority report of Senator Vanstone called the proposal that Senator Boswell is advancing both `confusing' and `senseless'. Given that backdrop, given the complexity of the issues, and given the fact that the opposition has not worked it out—maybe Senator Boswell is the lone cavalier on this—I can understand why Mrs McHugh is experiencing frustration.

In conclusion, my understanding is that the definition that Senator Vanstone understood, that Mrs McHugh has introduced and which the government has embodied in this legislation is one which is recognised internationally. It has that advantage as well. So, despite the array of people that Senator Boswell has mentioned, I put it to him that maybe his side has to work out its position as well.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. This side does know where it is coming from: we are on the side of the ACTU and the NFF. The government is neglecting its natural constituency. I ask the minister again: will he stand up and fight for the ACTU and make sure that the unionists, through their membership, are protected and that the jobs of people who work for the processors are looked after by the Labor Party?

—Mr President, I have actually stood up and fought for the ACTU on many occasions. I have looked around and Senator Boswell has never been there. But it is good to see Senator Boswell there this time. Let me also assure Senator Boswell that, when it comes to the jobs of Australians, on this issue and on others, we have been fighting for those as well—but we have not seen Senator Boswell behind us.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Lees Sen M.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories and it follows an answer the minister gave some weeks ago on the alleged use of drugs by swimmers at the World Swimming Championships. I bring this matter back to the attention of the Senate following an AAP article yesterday that reported the Beijing Evening News as saying:

QUESTION.PARA: Chicken soup containing medicinal herbs has been offered as one explanation for the extraordinary success of Chinese swimmers this year.

I ask the minister: as the Chinese are obviously not going to take this issue seriously, what can we do here in Australia to make sure that our swimmers do not compete again against drug-assisted swimmers? In particular, what can we do to make sure that the year 2000 Olympics are drug free for all our athletes? Finally, does the minister acknowledge that the government stands to lose large amounts of television rights money because the world's television viewers will not want to tune in to watch their athletes being beaten by drug cheats?

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I did not read the article in the Beijing Evening News. As I informed the Senate on 19 September, it is unfortunate that FINA, the international swimming federation, has not yet been as willing as other international sporting bodies to work with ASDA and its international colleagues. I am pleased to say that since that time, and following pressure from agencies such as ASDA, FINA has requested information from ASDA about its out-of-competition testing services.

PARA.TAB: Despite this latest request, it is important that the pressure on FINA to take responsibility for dealing with the issue of drugs in sport is maintained. I have written to the president of FINA expressing my concerns on this matter. I have also written to my colleagues in Canada, Norway, the United Kingdom, New Zealand and France, which are partners in our multilateral anti-doping agreement, who also might be keen to contact FINA on this particular matter.

As the World Swimming Championships are to be held in Perth in 1998, we have a double opportunity to ensure that FINA adopts policies and programs that ensure that swimming is drug free. The drug testing procedures for the 2000 Olympic Games will be formally set by the International Olympic Committee. There is no doubt that the Sydney organising committee for the Olympic Games will be able to comply with the procedures that are likely to be set.

In Australia we already have the most stringent drug testing program in the world. The Australian Sports Drug Agency and the accredited laboratory in Sydney played a key role in developing the drug aspects of the bid document that was submitted to the IOC. There will be 15,000 athletes at the Sydney games and I can give no undertaking that they will be entirely drug free. However, I will be actively encouraging international competition involving `clean' athletes.

I give an undertaking that we will apply the most stringent test procedures available to catch anyone who tries to cheat. I think we have built up a reputation as world leaders in the fight against performance enhancing drugs. Coupled with the spotlight that is going to be on Australia in the year 2000 Olympics, I think it gives us a unique chance to address these problems in the international arena. I also undertake that over the next six years we will work actively in international sporting arenas to ensure that other countries, other international sporting federations and multinational agencies such as the IOC, do take this issue seriously and take a comprehensive approach to it.

The majority of the 15,000 competitors will come to Australia at least once between 1996 and 2000, both for training and for acclimatisation. In addition, there will be a host of world championships and other international competitions held in Australia in the lead-up to the Olympics. These athletes will be exposed to ASDA's out-of-competition testing program and to its range of educational materials. I agree that the final part of the honourable senator's question is a very important issue. It is certainly an issue that needs to be addressed by world sporting bodies, including FINA.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I thank the minister for his answer, in particular for his comment that we are already working with a number of other countries that have signed the agreements. But are we getting somewhere near the day when those countries that have signed will simply say they will not take part in meets or championships at which there are obviously athletes who are not being drug tested, particularly out-of-competition drug tested? Therefore, does Australia intend to put more pressure on those countries that have signed to work collectively with us to ensure that our athletes simply do not go into competitions when we know there are two or three countries there that are not drug testing?

—Certainly we will take every opportunity that we can to influence individual athletes, national sporting organisations and other international sporting federations to take action on these issues. I think we have an outstanding record in Australia in that regard. We will be able to use the opportunity that the 2000 Olympics brings to us to convince others that an out-of-competition testing program should be introduced internationally, throughout the world. I have said before in the Senate that we will be more active in a range of multinational forums that have a role in anti-doping matters. We will pursue further testing agreements with other countries. We will keep the pressure on in regard to this issue.

—My question is directed to the minister representing the Minister for Transport. I refer to the Civil Aviation Authority's recent investigation into a Western Australian air charter operator, King Leopold Air. Is it a fact that the investigation revealed serious deficiencies in the operator's safety standards? Is it a fact that the investigation was prompted by a complaint by a Melbourne doctor who flew with the operator—a man whose complaint was described by the CAA as the `tip of a very large iceberg'? What were those deficiencies? Why were the problems not detected in the course of the CAA's routine surveillance of the operator? Why did the minister do nothing about this, notwithstanding the fact that the Melbourne doctor sent a copy of his letter of complaint to the minister on 1 August? What is the current status of King Leopold Air?
—I have got no information on King Leopold Air—nor, frankly, would I expect to have in this brief. I will refer the detail of Senator Parer's question—

PARA.TAB: Honourable senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Frankly, I do not think Senator Parer actually expected me to have that information. He wanted to get the question on the record; he has got it on the record. I will refer it to the minister and get an answer back to him.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Is this not an example of the neglect of this minister in that nothing was done? Even at this stage, the minister has not given the Melbourne doctor the courtesy of a reply.
—Ask a question!
—I am asking a question, can Senator Cook not hear? Is this not the type of neglect that the minister has been responsible for and the reason he should get out of the job and give it to someone else?
—Those assertions have certainly been made by Senator Parer; they have not yet been responded to by the minister. I will give the question to him and get a response.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs. Did the minister see in a press report yesterday that the Bishop of Dili, Bishop Belo, has denounced the Indonesian authorities for conducting a programmed, systematic plan for sterilisation in East Timor? He says that its application has already caused conflicts:

QUESTION.PARA: . . . not only in the capital, but also in several other towns such as Vikeke and Suai. They are forcing people to follow their orders by telling them that if it is the state that feeds the population, it should obey the state and not the church.

Has the minister also seen the recent article in Inside Indonesia which described the Indonesian National Family Planning Coordination Board's program as based on highly invasive coercive practices underpinned by extensive surveillance and control? What action will the government take to condemn these violations of human rights?

TALK.START.PARA: —I am afraid I have to advise Senator Harradine that I have not seen either of those reports or articles and I will need to get some further information on them before I can sensibly respond. I know there are aspects of the Indonesian family planning program which have caused Senator Harradine concern in the past. Whether those concerns are justified, or fully justified, is something on which I cannot make a judgment at this time but I will do my best to give him a detailed answer.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. That is just not good enough. These things are on the record. They are not just my concerns; they are human rights violations on the record. I refer to an agreement between Minister Bilney and Haryono Suyono, the minister for population in Indonesia, which asserted that Indonesia's program was voluntary and effective. Effective it is; voluntary it is not. Does the minister remember that this agreement said that Australian money would be provided for a UNFPA program which `will include scholarships for Pacific islanders to attend the Indonesian National Family Planning Coordination Board's International Training Program and field visits to Eastern Indonesian provinces'? Are the highly coercive practices engaged in by the Indonesian authorities and condemned by Bishop Belo the sorts of things that we want to see happen in the Pacific?

—Senator Harradine knows very well that it is no part of the government's population program support to approve of coercive strategies of any kind, of any shape whatsoever. There is inevitably room at the margin for argument about some of those programs which depend for their implementation on incentives of various kinds, and we have had arguments about that before in this context. But I do not think it is appropriate for me to try to respond in any further detail on that issue at this time. It is not part of our program to support coercive practices in the Pacific islands, in Indonesia or anywhere else.

—My question is directed to the minister representing the Minister for Administrative Services and refers to the Casselden Place property scandal cover-up, which is the subject of an Auditor-General's report to be tabled this afternoon. The minister will recall that on 5 May and 10 May, Senator McMullan and the minister, Frank Walker, refused to comply with an order of the Senate to table documents in relation to these property deals. The minister may also remember that on 21 September, he said that a $80 million loss on the building was, to quote him, `just one of those little fictions of my imagination'. Will the minister inform the Senate whether the loss on this building was indeed in excess of $100 million? Will the minister now table the documents relating to the leasing incentive packages on this building, which was actually constructed at a time when he was the relevant minister?

—Just to clear up the last point, I think the decision to build this building was made in 1987. I would love to have been in cabinet at that stage but, unfortunately, I was not—nor was I the Minister for Administrative Services. There has been no property scandal or cover up. All that emotive language makes him feel good, but out in the electorate and in this place he gets no credibility for running those sorts of lines without any substantiation. In respect of any documents that may or may not have been tabled, I have no brief on that. I will take that on board, and I am sure that when Senator McMullan comes back on the next sitting day he will be able to give the senator a full answer to that.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: Construction Delegation to India and Vietnam

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Small Business, Customs and Construction. I understand that the minister is leading a mission of senior construction industry leaders to India and Vietnam to explore opportunities for investment in new and existing markets. Can the minister provide further details about this mission and its relationship to the Asia infrastructure consortia program announced in Working Nation?
—Yes, I will be leading a construction delegation in the next two weeks to India and Vietnam.
—What else will you be doing?

—Senator Vanstone may want to bag the construction industry in Australia; she may want to attack an industry that has a turnover of $30 billion a year; and she may want to bag a program that is aimed at getting more exports for Australia from our efficient construction industry. It is typical that the opposition has no idea of the scope and ability of the Australian construction industry, which is one of our best world practice industries in Australia.

PARA.TAB: Honourable senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —It is interesting that again the interjections from the other side are directed against an industry that employs hundreds of thousands of people in this country. On this delegation, there will be representatives from the Transfield company, Clough Engineering, Leighton Asia, BHP Steel Vietnam and Kinhill Engineers, together with representatives of companies such as the Henry Walker Group, the Standard Roads Group, the Snowy Mountains Engineering Corporation, Stuart Bros and Thomson, Adsett and Partners.
—You will be leading it? You egocentric man!
—Order, Senator Vanstone! Senator Schacht, do not get baited; address your remarks to the chair.
—No, I enjoy it, Mr President.
—You may enjoy it, but it is disorderly.

—I enjoy them exposing themselves and showing that they have not the slightest interest in the construction industry in Australia. I am more than interested to see whether they keep this up, because it just shows how irrelevant this opposition is to any idea to improve Australia's export industries. Senator Vanstone shows an example of that ignorance of this very important industry.

PARA.TAB: This will be the first construction delegation to visit India. With the new policies of the Indian government, there are considerable opportunities, we believe, in road, bridge and railway construction where that government is carrying out major infrastructure initiatives. We are already the third or fourth largest investor in Vietnam. In Vietnam, as an example of our efforts and recognition of BHP, there will be an official opening of the Dai Hung oil exploration and drilling program. This is a program which, within 18 months of winning the contract and setting a number of construction records, has now got the field into oil production. That is a major advantage and example of the initiative and skill of the Australian construction industry, and one of Australia's major companies. Senator Vanstone has no interest in the advantages this brings to Australia, but it is a program that we in government are very pleased to be associated with.

Senator Vanstone may want to bag the Australian construction industry with her inane interjections, but the opposition will be judged accordingly at the next election when the majority of the construction industry will not support a bereft opposition that has not the slightest idea of any policies for the construction industry in Australia. I will be happy to report back to the Senate after I return from the visit and give those opposite another opportunity to interject for four minutes and show how stupid they are about this particular industry.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. In light of the Prime Minister's commitment to the rural community arising from the drought, does the government intend to change the income tax provisions in relation to the write-off of bad debts? This would particularly require the ability of lenders to be better able to write-off partial debt. Will the government undertake to do this?

—I certainly do not think I am in a position to give any undertaking that we would do more than look at that and respond at an appropriate time. On the whole subject of rural debt and the drought, it is the case that the Prime Minister met yesterday with the major banks and pastoral houses to exchange views and information about the responses to the drought by the government, the banks and the pastoral houses.

PARA.TAB: The Prime Minister expressed very firmly his view on the need for the banks to continue financial support to drought affected farmers, including after the drought has broken. In the current drought situation, it is manifestly very important that the banks provide flexible arrangements to meet farmers' needs. The availability of long-term finance is vital for farmers to be able to restore investment and rebuild in the recovery phase following the drought.

The perception of the government is that, on the whole, the banks and other financial institutions have adopted a reasonable and flexible approach to meeting the financial requirements of the rural sector in this period of great difficulty, particularly in situations where those farms are capable of again being profitable. We are confident that the banks and other financial institutions will remain committed to ensuring the continuation of viable rural industries.

If the banks continue to play that role in this respect, obviously the immediate problem of debt that Senator Macdonald referred to is that much more easily manageable. Nobody doubts the magnitude of the problem that the rural sector is experiencing at the moment. We will be happy to continue to keep the situation under close review. I will refer the question to the Prime Minister.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy. Recent reviews of the activities of the research and development corporations have identified a need for the government to articulate its strategic priorities to guide the research and development corporations' boards in developing their research programs. What priorities has the government identified? Have these been effectively communicated to the various industry research and development bodies?

—I have previously informed the Senate of the very substantial influence of the research and development corporation model on primary industry R&D activity. As I have informed the Senate before, the R&D model that we have in Australia is envied around the world.

PARA.TAB: Industry levies in this coming year will exceed $100 million, more than triple the $30 million contributed by primary producers just 10 years ago. The 15 agricultural RDCs will invest nearly $211 million of government and industry funds during 1994-95. A survey recently undertaken by the Department of Primary Industries and Energy has indicated that around 3,000 researchers are either fully or partly dependent on funding from these corporations. In respect of the points that Senator Cook has just made about the nonsense of the brain drain from Australia, this is more evidence for that being a nonsense.

This figure includes 430 postgraduate students, many of whom receive direct support through scholarships. These funds are allocated across the full spectrum of research activity, with universities receiving 22 per cent of total funds; the CSIRO, 23 per cent; state government research institutes, 38 per cent; and other research providers, around 16 per cent. Importantly, the traditional agricultural research focus on improving production is making room for research into other steps along the path to market. Only 56 per cent of funds are allocated to production research, whereas processing research now takes up 18 per cent; product handling research, five per cent; and storage distribution and market research, six per cent.

The DPIE survey also revealed overwhelmingly positive returns from RDC sponsored projects. Benefit cost ratios for projects undertaken by six major RDCs averaged 22:1 and ranged from an average low of 5:1 to an average high of 100:1. These results confirm that the RDC model is generating substantial and valuable research outputs through maintaining a vibrant agricultural research community and incorporating the needs now of the market into research planning.

Recent reviews—and, I might add, the RDC boards themselves—have asked for the government to clearly set out its expectation of the RDCs. I recently wrote to the chairs of all of the RDCs identifying the government's main interests to be incorporated with the demands of industry into a comprehensive research program. They are: enhancing the competitiveness and resilience of industries; developing a significant processing capacity to build on our comparative advantages; the development of industries oriented towards the demands of the marketplace, particularly those in the Asia-Pacific region; management of the natural resource base in an ecologically sustainable manner; and an integrated response to regional development and adjustment.

I have asked the RDC boards to report on the incorporation of these priorities into their research programs through their annual reports and operating plans and in the regular meetings I have had with the chairs of the RDCs. The feedback I have had to date is encouraging. This is not surprising, as the objectives that have been identified reflect the critical long-term issues that rural industries need to address to ensure their sustainability.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Human Services and Health. Is it correct that the government has rejected the advice of its own Pharmaceutical Benefits Advisory Committee, which recommended that the aids to quitting smoking, nicotine patches, be placed on the pharmaceutical benefits scheme? Is it true that these patches will potentially help thousands of smokers quit smoking and that, without PBS subsidisation, they will be out of the reach of many lower income earners, who will then be more likely to die of heart disease and cancer? Is it true that the real cost of the restrictive listing recommended is around $20 million, not the wildly inaccurate $100 million, and that there are potential savings in the health and financial areas which are enormous? Is this not another case of Labor ignoring the interests of lower income earners, except that in this case they face not only poverty but death?
—I will take Senator Woods's question on notice and refer it to Dr Lawrence.

—Mr President, let me ask a supplementary question which even Senator Faulkner can answer. Is it not true that smoking costs the Australian community $9 billion per year and some 20,000 lives? Is it not true, therefore, that a 10 per cent reduction will save $900 million a year and around 2,000 lives? Does that not constitute an unanswerable, cast-iron case for subsidising these patches?
—I understand that the answer to the first two parts of Senator Woods's question is yes, but we will get a calculator out and check it for him.

—My question is directed to Senator Faulkner, the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories. I understand the minister was involved in the opening of a new science building at Davis Station in Antarctica yesterday. Can the minister explain the significance of this event to Australia's Antarctic program?

—Yes, I am pleased to be able to tell the Senate that Australian Construction Services has completed a new science building at Davis Station. In fact, it was opened yesterday via a telephone link to the station in which I was able to—
—Why didn't you go down there and do it yourself?

—It would have been more pleasant than being here, I might say. The government, which has a long-term commitment to conducting high-quality science programs in Antarctica, decided last year to refocus the Antarctic program to support four key goals: to understand global change; to protect the Antarctic environment; to maintain the Antarctic treaty system and Australia's influence in the system; and to obtain information of practical importance in areas such as meteorology.

PARA.TAB: Scientists at Australia's Antarctic stations will be involved in some 130 science projects during the 1994-95 season. Some of the major research that is being undertaken from Davis Station in the coming season includes population studies of seals; the diet of Antarctic seabirds; the ecology of Antarctic lakes; the response of micro-organisms to climate change; the feeding ecology of zooplankton; the effects of ultraviolet light on phyto-plankton; and Antarctic geomorphology. Projects such as these are essential to understanding and protecting our Antarctic environment. The completion of the science building will provide the Antarctic Division with the necessary laboratory space to support both the summer and winter scientists undertaking these programs at Davis.

I am sure, Mr President, that you would agree with me that not enough appreciation is given by our community in general to the very dedicated work in Antarctica of our expeditioners in the Antarctic division. They certainly do labour under difficult conditions down there. They show, I think, a great commitment, and have done so for a very long period.

There is no doubt that at times a lot of these efforts go unrecognised. I am sure that you, Mr President, and other senators, as well as the whole of the Australian community, would join me in indicating our genuine appreciation for their efforts over a very long period, not only on this occasion with the opening of a new science building at Davis Station but also in our other Antarctic bases.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask that further questions be placed on the Notice Paper.

—On Tuesday Senator Lees asked me, as the representative in the Senate of the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs, a question relating to the recommendations of the Joint Health Planning Committee. I inform her that 233 bids for funding were received by the Joint Health Planning Committee prior to the committee's meeting on Tuesday, 18 October. These bids totalled $78,578,790 for the current financial year and $217,530,534 for the five years from 1994-95 to 1998-99. I table a summary of all of these bids. All these bids, whether for capital or recurrent expenditure, are directed to improving primary health and the operational effectiveness of Aboriginal primary health services.

PARA.TAB: The Joint Health Planning Committee consists of elected representatives of the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission, community controlled Aboriginal health services, the Department of Human Services and Health and a National Health and Medical Research Council nominee. The committee met on 18 October to decide on a range of priority bids to be funded. Priorities for each state and territory had already been determined by elected ATSIC representatives in each of those states.

In the light of the committee's broad base and significant experience and expertise in indigenous health needs, I am sure that both the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs and the Minister for Human Services and Health will closely consider the committee's recommendations.

The question suggests that capital works do not benefit health care. Clearly, there is a need for appropriate infrastructure if health services are to be delivered effectively. The Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs fully supports the committee's approach of considering, on a case by case basis, capital works funding as an integral component of a structural framework for the delivery of appropriate and effective health services.

I understand the committee is reluctant to recommend significant funding for the establishment of new services without appropriate planning. In the light of this concern, the committee has recommended that funds be provided for planning and feasibility studies.

However, in the first year of the program the committee has taken the view that it should focus on one-off expenditure. Also, the evaluation of NAHS will influence longer term recurrent funding decisions. For this reason, the committee will consider later this year recurrent funding in respect of new and existing services. I table the detailed list of applications made.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have been provided with answers to, I think, all parts of a question that Senator Knowles asked earlier today. The answers are as follows: the CES has a responsibility to advise employers of the details of the jobstart program when the employer comes to the CES with a vacancy and a prospective employee or when they make an inquiry.

PARA.TAB: The issue is not one of verifying the accuracy of the jobstart card but confirming the eligibility of the job seeker and the vacancy. Jobstart self-canvassing cards are an aid which job seekers can use to assist themselves in securing employment. They do not contain commitments to pay particular levels of jobstart subsidy. The cards clearly state that to be eligible to receive a jobstart subsidy the employer must always contact the local CES to confirm eligibility and to complete an agreement with the CES.
Jobstart cards in circulation prior to 4 July were progressively updated as their period of eligibility expired. The change of rates which came into effect after 4 July was widely publicised.

TALK.START.PARA: —A document has just been handed to me in relation to a question Senator Ian Macdonald asked in question time today about the draft Civil Aviation Authority strategic plan for rescue and firefighting services at Australian airports. I have been advised by the CAA that the document to which Senator Macdonald refers is an internal CAA working document which was distributed to the CAA rescue and firefighting staff and the relevant staff associations for discussion and consultation. A consultative process is in progress and no decisions have yet been taken on the draft plan.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —Earlier this week and late last week Senator Short asked me some questions in respect of the appointments to the IRT. I have further information in response to those questions and I seek leave to incorporate that information in Hansard.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

ANSWER.PARA: The process for appointments to the Immigration Review Tribunal is one consistent with appointments to other similar Government tribunals.

As Minister responsible, I make the decision on appointments before taking my recommendations to Cabinet, and then to the Governor General for a final decision. This is the procedure embraced by Section 395 of the Migration Act 1958. This procedure is standard practice for appointments to tribunals and courts.

This system, as it relates to the review of migration decisions, was recently reviewed by the Committee for the Review of the System for Review of Immigration Decisions (CROSROMD), chaired by the former Coalition Immigration Minister, Ian Macphee. The Committee consisted of Mr Macphee; Professor Julian Disney, Centre for International Public Law, Australian National University; Mr Stephen Skehill, Deputy Secretary, Department of the Attorney General; Ms Pamela O'Neil, Principal Member of the IRT; and Mr Wayne Gibbons, Deputy Secretary, Department of Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs. It reported on December 11, 1992.
This committee acknowledged and endorsed this power and responsibility of the Minister.
The Minister should continue to be responsible for recommending appropriate persons for appointment to the IRT by the Governor General in Council.

The committee also endorsed the principle that the Tribunal should reflect a diversity of skills. This principle was stated by former Immigration Minister, Robert Ray, when he established the IRT in 1989. Again, it was restated by the Macphee Committee in Recommendation 7.9.1:

The Committee notes that immigration issues commonly involve difficult assessments of an applicant's personality, capabilities and motivations and consideration of cultural and other social factors. Consequently this is an area in which it is especially important for a wide range of experiences and perspectives to be present within a review authority in order to increase the prospect of arriving at well-informed and balanced decisions.
As to process, the Macphee committee recommended that the Minister should appoint an advisory committee to provide information on the applicants under consideration.
But in doing so, it clearly stated that the Minister should not be bound by the committee's advice but should remain entitled to use his or her discretion when making final decisions.

The Minister should remain entitled, however, to use additional methods, for identifying suitable candidates for appointment and should not be bound to accept the advisory committee's recommendations.

As I informed the Senate, in the most recent round of appointments announced on 17 August 1994, I set up a panel and asked it to assist with appointments in Victoria. I also asked it to assist with the other "high volume" States—New South Wales and Queensland. I asked it to provide me with further information as to the applicants in those States. In the smaller States, where a limited number of appointments were required, I decided I did not need the panel's assistance.

The panel provided me with information on a list of people that it had considered in the three major States. The list included one person who was not interviewed—Ms Radford (NSW), a person with a distinguished career as a Federal public servant and who was working overseas. A positive assessment was made by the panel on Ms Radford's papers. Mr Karas, the incumbent Senior Member in Queensland, was also reappointed without an interview.

I am informed that all appointees made applications through the normal process. In States where I asked the panel to conduct interviews, only one part-time appointment was made without the panel's positive assessment. In NSW, only one person was assessed positively and not appointed. In Victoria, only two were assessed positively and not appointed, because of the limited number of positions. Michael Clothier was not one of these two.

In order to achieve a panel which could best advise me on the exercise of my discretion, I drew on the three most relevant areas. The panel consisted of the Principal Member of the IRT, a senior departmental officer, and one of my staff.
The senior departmental officer who I appointed, Nick Nicholls, is head of the personnel branch of the Department and was the acting head of the Department's legal branch.

Ms Pamela O'Neil has been the Principal Member of the IRT since its establishment in 1989. She was congratulated on her appointment at that time by the Federal Opposition, particularly by Senator Chris Puplick.
Given that the appointments are totally within my discretion, the inclusion of a member of my staff on the panel was both desirable and appropriate.

As noted above, I did not ask the panel to interview in South Australia, Western Australia and the ACT, due to the smaller number of positions available, and the more limited response from applicants. I made recommendations for appointments and reappointments in these States on the material before me, as is quite common with such appointments.
These appointments were made on the basis of the person's experience, qualifications and perspectives, in accordance with the recommendations of the Macphee committee.

As is evident, the discretion in all tribunal appointments is mine and I fail to see how it is possible for me to politically interfere with my own decisions! I have however, in the appointments, ensured the selection of talented, independent persons as I did with recent Refugee Review Tribunal appointments.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macdonald Sen I.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Senator Collins), to a question without notice asked by Senator Ian Macdonald this day, relating to a Civil Aviation Authority draft internal working document.

SPEECH.PARA: At least now I do have something to talk about. It was pretty obvious from question time generally that none of the ministers was able to answer any questions except those that were dorothy dixers prepared by themselves and distributed to their own backbench. It really shows the absolute contempt with which the current government treats this parliament and treats question time. It is supposed to be a time when the opposition can obtain information, but the ministers simply do not care or are not sufficiently briefed, or do not wish to be put under scrutiny at question time. One minister after the other was simply unable to answer questions put by the Liberal and National parties that were very much matters of great public importance.

PARA.TAB: Senator Collins has given a sort of answer—after question time, regrettably. He indicates that this is an internal working document. It does not seem to be too internal; there seem to be plenty of copies floating around. But it is a proposal dated September 1994, and it is one that I would have thought Senator Collins would have been aware of. Senator Collins used to be the transport minister and he has represented the transport minister at estimates committees on this side of the parliamentary building since he lost the transport portfolio. His answer to me today was similar to his attitude during estimates committees, that is, that he did everything possible to protect the CAA, to keep it from parliamentary scrutiny and to stonewall every question that tried to raise the issues that have become so current in recent days.
