Perhaps if Senator Collins had been a little more interested in the parliamentary scrutiny, if he had allowed some of my questions and those of my colleagues to go through to the CAA, some of the tragedies that we have seen in recent times may not have happened. Senator Collins's answer today again shows that he wants to avoid these questions—questions that we raise which relate to the safety of air transport in Australia.

The paper to which I have drawn attention proposes quite dramatic cuts to safety at airports around Australia. In Sydney, the proposal is to reduce the staff allocation from 68 to 62, which is almost a 10 per cent cut in the firefighting service at Sydney. In Cairns, at an airport in North Queensland which I use quite often, the proposal is to cut the staff allocation from 69 to 63, again a cut of around nine to 10 per cent.

It is worse in Launceston where the proposal is to cut the firefighting rescue service from 28 to 21; that is by seven, or almost 33 per cent of the existing personnel. Senators could imagine what that will do for safety at Launceston airport. Similarly in Hobart there is a reduction from 29 to 23 and of concern to me as well, as a Queensland senator, is the proposal to reduce the Rockhampton service and the Mackay service from 15 to 10, representing cuts of 33 per cent in the firefighting service at those airports. With these sorts of services, there is a limit below which one cannot go and still have an effective rescue firefighting service at these airports.

The fact that some of these airports are not as busy as others does not mean to say that the effort needed in the event of an emergency is not the same, whether it be a big or small airport. The way the CAA is proposing to slash the numbers of safety personnel in these regional airports particularly, but also at Sydney, shows that it has not learnt the lesson and is more intent on saving money than on saving lives. I hope that by raising that matter in the parliament, we can stop dead this proposal by the CAA to lower yet further the safety aspects of flying in Australia.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Knowles Sen S.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Minister for Small Business, Customs and Construction (Senator Schacht), to a question without notice asked by Senator Knowles this day, relating to the Commonwealth Employment Service jobstart program.

SPEECH.PARA: The question I asked during question time was why the onus was on employers to verify the accuracy of the jobstart canvassing card which is provided by the CES. The minister subsequently said that the onus has to be on the employees and that the jobstart card is not worth anything in terms of going and getting a job and obtaining a subsidy. Then why on earth have it? Many jobstart cards issued after the release of the government's Working Nation white paper are not worth the paper they are written on.

PARA.TAB: I was advised by the very same minister that all CES officers were notified immediately after the release of the white paper on 4 May about the reduction in the jobstart subsidy rate and were told that the changes would come into effect on 4 July. A constituent of mine was issued with a card on 3 June, one month later; and that card stated that it was valid for three months from 3 June 1994 to 3 September 1994. The details on the card stipulated that she may be eligible for a subsidy of $200 per week for 16 weeks. That simply was not right—and the CES had provided that card one month after the Working Nation statement was brought down.

The staff of the CES continued up to the changeover date to complete cards for their clients which advised potential employers that the cardholder may be eligible for the old higher rate of $200 per week for 16 weeks; and the card was valid for three months from the date of issue. There was no directive to notify employers or jobstart clients prior to the changes taking effect. Surely some responsibility should be put on the CES rather than that all the responsibility should be put onto the employers or the unemployed. After all, it is the unemployed who are desperately trying to seek work—and many companies are equally desperate to try to provide work.

The CES—or, more importantly, the government—is abrogating its responsibility. This has given a number of employers a very false impression and jeopardised the possible employment of a number of long-term unemployed people. The minister simply washes his hands of the responsibility for these people by saying that the advice given on the jobstart card does not commit the Commonwealth to a particular level of subsidy. The simple question is, `Why give the card in the first place?' I believe it is quite unfair, especially when the CES was aware that changes were imminent. There should have been an amendment to cards issued after the details of the changes were released to CES staff to notify the client and the potential employer that the old subsidy would end on 4 July and that a lower subsidy of $100 per week, half the subsidy for three weeks less—$100 a week for 13 weeks—would take its place.

Likewise, cardholders who received cards prior to 4 May should have received written advice of the change. It should not be the responsibility of potential employers to verify every jobstart client's cards if the client is considered to be a prospective employee. Rather, it is the responsibility of the CES to provide up-to-date and accurate information about its programs in advance of the forthcoming changes to those programs. The difference in the subsidy, quite frankly, can be the difference between an employer being able to afford someone and not. And here we are giving the unemployed a card that quite clearly is stating the wrong information!

What needs to be also looked at is the emotional aspect of this. It has been heartbreaking for this particular constituent and for many others who obviously have experienced the same problem. It is heartbreaking for those jobstart clients to come within an absolute whisker of getting a job only to find that the information they have been provided with by the CES and have subsequently given to a prospective employer is wrong. It is unsatisfactory that the government takes such an indifferent and careless attitude to the long-term unemployed.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ellison Sen C.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs (Senator Bolkus), to a question without notice asked by Senator Boswell this day, relating to origin labelling.

SPEECH.PARA: The background to Senator Boswell's question relates to the report today in the Canberra Times that the government is considering dumping its origin labelling legislation rather than amending it. What that legislation sets out to do is make sure that people cannot put `Made in Australia' on something which is not made in Australia. The reasons for that are self-evident.

PARA.TAB: The government got terribly confused as to what people understood `Made in Australia' to mean. In a recent hearing of the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs this matter caused a great deal of concern. The ACTU/Food Policy Alliance said that it was `the unanimous considered position of all ACTU trade unions, all of the country's consumer organisations, most if not all of the farmer organisations and a very large cross-section of the Australian public' that `Made in Australia' should refer to something which is 100 per cent Australian.

This government has proposed in its legislation that `Made in Australia' can mean that the goods acquired their essential character or qualities in Australia. Senator Bolkus said that this accords with international thinking. But this legislation is not designed for overseas. It is not designed for other countries. It is designed for Australia. We have to look at what Australians understand by the term `Made in Australia'.

I believe the coalition has accommodated this in its proposed amendments when it says that `Made in Australia' means that Australia was the place of origin of each major ingredient of the product and that all operations involved in the manufacture of that product happened in Australia. Senator Spindler said in his dissenting report that Quadrant Research Services found in a survey that 74 per cent of all Australians believed that `Made in Australia' should mean 100 per cent Australian.

When we proposed our amendments to this legislation, we had in mind what Australian people thought. That is really what the government is there to do. It is there to reflect the wishes of the people of Australia and not the wishes of people overseas or what people overseas might think—

TALK.START.PARA: —UN committees.

—And UN committees, as quite correctly put by Senator Kemp. This government is a slave to what everybody overseas thinks. It has to run to UN committees; it has to be concerned about what is thought internationally.

PARA.TAB: The Investigators program recently televised a survey conducted of people in the street. Most of them thought that `Made in Australia' meant just that—an Australian product. So the opposition has proposed that the definition of `Made in Australia' be tightened. Goods which are labelled `Made in Australia' should be of a higher standard so that not just anything can be classified as being made in Australia. The goods have to be dinkum; they have to be the real thing.

The Australian Democrats also had misgivings about this bill. What does this government do in the face of opposition? It runs the other way! The government will not even put the legislation forward. That is why the headline on the article says `Govt will dump rather than amend labelling legislation'. That is just typical of the government's attitude because it is dead scared of being found to have made a mess of things. I think the minister, Jeannette McHugh, needs to seriously consider her situation because all of her counterpart ministers in the state governments throughout Australia have opposed her proposals in relation to this matter. If she does not wake up to that, I think she ought to give the game away.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Parer Sen W.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the minister representing the Minister for Transport (Senator Collins), to a question without notice asked by Senator Parer this day, relating to the Civil Aviation Authority and King Leopold Air.

SPEECH.PARA: I refer to Senator Collins's non-answer to my question, which I believe is a disgrace, considering the number of air crashes we have had in recent weeks. On 1 August this year a Melbourne doctor wrote to the regional manager of the Civil Aviation Authority—with a copy to the minister responsible for Civil Aviation Authority, Mr Brereton—in which he outlined a whole lot of problems that he had encountered in flying out of Broome.

PARA.TAB: I will give a few examples. He pointed out that when the petrol switch was on, it was actually off; there was extreme vibration on take off which the pilot said was called `shimming'; the fuel gauge suddenly flicked to zero on one of the petrol tanks and the pilot had to furtively chase around and switch tanks; the pilot then informed the doctor that the reason the plane was flying so slowly was that she could not get the wheels up; she then said that they had to return to Broome, or to some other suitable airport, because she was concerned for the safety of the passengers.

The doctor had a lot of praise for the pilot. He said there was nothing wrong with her. When the plane landed it was met by fire engines at the airstrip and they had to look out the window to see if the wheels were locked down. The doctor went on to say:

SPEECH.PARA: I believe that it will not be long before there is a major disaster with this airline.

On receipt of a copy of that letter, I wrote to General Gration, the chairman of the Civil Aviation Authority. The doctor received a response to his letter from Captain Rick Davies. The doctor points out that it seemed to be a very reasonable response. Captain Davies wrote:
The complaints that you raised were quite frankly merely the tip of a rather large iceberg; I am not yet in a position to give you the feedback that I indicated that I would.
Our investigations are not yet complete. I will debrief you on what action we have taken when the matter is brought to a conclusion.
That letter was dated 26 September 1994. One has to wonder about the dating on that letter because subsequently Mr George Wood, the recipient of the original letter, wrote to the doctor as follows:
Further to our letter of 4 August 1994—
Which was an acknowledgment type letter—
. . . regarding your concerns over the operating standards of King Leopold Air . . .
As forecast by Captain Rick Davies, the Darwin District Office conducted an investigation into the matter and your triggering information was of great assistance in that exercise;

The question one has to ask is: why did the doctor have to trigger that investigation if the surveillance was being properly carried out. Obviously it was not. Why has the minister never even responded to the copy of the letter sent to him by the doctor. Mr George Wood of the CAA goes on to say:

Whilst the outcome of that surveillance is a matter between this Authority and the operator I can say that your efforts have contributed in a very positive way to achieving a satisfactory level of safety.
What an appalling response to someone who had written a letter containing a litany of problems encountered on a flight out of Broome. In his letter to me the doctor wrote:

I was very concerned about the tone of the letter taken by George Wood. I would contend it is not a simple matter between King Leopold Air and Civil Aviation Authority but would rather regard this as a cover-up.
The bureaucratic language contained in the letter would make one feel that way if one were the recipient of the letter. The letter continues:

I would appreciate if you could follow this matter up as I believe I have some right to know the outcome and to be reassured about the safety of King Leopold Air or the fact that it will not continue to fly.
He gives a perfectly responsible reason for this when he goes on to state:
One of the particular reasons for the importance of this is that I have friends who live and work in the area and also friends who go up there as tourists.

The response has been unsatisfactory. The lack of interest by the minister in this whole business, and the fact that the minister representing the Minister for Transport, Mr Brereton, did not have a brief at question time, is disgraceful.

PARA.TAB: Flying in Australia is safe. But there are cowboys—we all know about that—who, because of the minister's inaction, have caused untold damage to the majority of safe commuter operators and the general aviation industry in particular. This minister has done this great industry a great disservice. He does not deserve to continue to be the minister.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Senator Gareth Evans), to a question without notice asked by Senator Harradine this day, relating to birth control programs in East Timor.

SPEECH.PARA: In response to a very serious question that I asked about violations of human rights in East Timor and violations of human rights in Indonesia, the foreign minister of Australia got up in this chamber and, in a very dismissive way, suggested that these violations were in my own mind. The reason I felt it was urgent to get up and ask a question about this issue today was that the respected Bishop of Dili, Bishop Belo, had actually denounced the systematic program of sterilisation that is taking place in East Timor—not only in the capital city of Dili but also in such other towns as Vikeke and Suai.

PARA.TAB: The minister was also dismissive of the material which shows that the Indonesian family planning program, conducted by the National Family Planning Coordination Board, is based on highly invasive and coercive practice underpinned by extensive surveillance and control. His response to that was simply to suggest that `Senator Harradine thinks this'.

Let me remind the Senate that that is precisely what he said about the Chinese program, which is now recognised throughout the world as being the cause of gross violations of human rights in China. Here is the foreign minister suggesting that I `think' there is a coercive program in Indonesia. I know that there is a coercive program in Indonesia and he should know as well—only he is too blind to see it.
Let me remind the Senate that, as late as August 1989, in response to a question from me, Senator Evans said to the Senate:

SPEECH.PARA: The population control program that is conducted in China . . . although it has been the subject of allegations made by Senator Harradine and his ilk—
and his ilk!—
over the years—has never been one about which I have seen evidence to justify the allegations that are being made about coercive abortion, involuntary sterilisation and so on.

That is what he said in 1989. The whole world knows that in China, there were then and are now gross violations of human rights inherent in that particular program. How long will it take him to acknowledge that there are also violations of human rights in Indonesia? `Highly invasive and coercive policies underpinned by extensive surveillance and control'—those were the conclusions of an article contained in Inside Indonesia of June 1994. What is the government going to do? Is it going to cut the funds that are being paid to these violators? Australian taxpayers' money is paid to these violators of human rights to teach family planning workers in the Pacific their tricks regarding the way that they use coercion. Money has been paid. I am asking that that money be stopped. It is taxpayers' money. The ignorance of the minister is no excuse.

PARA.TAB: Question resolved in the affirmative.
Motion (by Senator Campbell)—by leave—proposed:

That there be laid on the table, by not later than 5 p.m. this day, by the Minister representing the Minister for Administrative Services, the following documents referred to in paragraph 9.78 of Report No. 4 of 1994-95 of the Auditor-General:

PROCTEXT.PARA: (a)the correspondence between APG and ACS, dated August 1992; and
(b)the correspondence from APG to AEM, dated April 1993;
in relation to incentive packages in the Casselden Place Building.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOLKUS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Multicultural Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —The reality in regard to this motion is that the numbers have been worked out and the government is in a minority position on it. In those circumstances we oppose the motion but we will not take it to a vote, in recognition of how the numbers line up. In not taking it to a vote, let me also state that there is no guarantee that the documents will be produced. As Senator Campbell knows, and as the Senate knows, this is not day one of this particular issue, or day one in terms of whether documents should be produced on this matter. There has been a long saga relating to these documents. Much of the government's case is based on the fact that we are asking an organisation which has been requested—demanded, in fact—to go commercial to produce documents which are commercial-in-confidence. And to what effect? The point of these documents is to assert—
—Two ministers have misled this parliament. You have covered up a disgraceful scandal and you are saying the Senate may not get the documents.

—Has Senator Campbell finished? The point that the youngsters over there are trying to make is that someone has misled the parliament. I suggest that Senator Spindler should take a close look at the ANAO report in terms of this question of incentive which these letters are supposed to have proved something about. The Auditor-General has made it very clear that business units did not receive incentives in the context of receiving inducements to behave differently in relation to entering or not entering into this tenancy. That is clear; it is in black and white. That is not the only reference to it in the report. If we look at paragraph 7.4 on page 9 we see reference to the fact that incentives were not paid. Once again, that reference is in the ANAO report. I quote:

SPEECH.PARA: The DAS commercial tenants were, however, not regarded as new tenants but rather were considered by AEM to have been committed by DAS at the July 1991 rates as determined by AVO.

Just before that it says that common and well-known incentives were being paid in the broader context but, as the Auditor-General makes very clear, not paid in respect of this particular contract. That is very clearly stated on page 15 of the ANAO report.

PARA.TAB: I refer to page 15, paragraph 9.17—dead bang, right in the middle of it—in respect of these particular contracts. And we have the two learned gentlemen over there looking at it very closely. What does it say?

SPEECH.PARA: The units were not offered incentives by AEM, as they were considered to be committed tenants.

TALK.START.PARA: —Read on.

—They were not—n-o-t—offered incentives, `as they were considered to be committed tenants'. In three parts to this report there are references to the fact that incentives were not granted, but we have to go through the charade this afternoon of getting documents out to assert something that is stuck in the back of the opposition's mind.

—Mr Deputy President, on a point of order: it was very important in reading those quotes that the minister did not stop but continued on. I believe that the Hansard record will be quite misleading unless the full text is included.
—That is not a point of order, Senator Kemp.

—And he knows it. The basic point is that we have been asked to produce documents to prove a particular case which runs dead counter to the conclusion of the Auditor-General. If the opposition is not going to accept the Auditor-General's report on this, why does it waste the time of this place by instructing the Auditor-General to go off and do assessments like this? The opposition is wasting time and wasting resources. Senator Spindler will come up behind the opposition now, waggling along, wanting more and more inquiries by the Auditor-General. Good luck to him as well. If the opposition is not going to accept the advice of the Auditor-General when it asks for that advice, what is this charade all about?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kemp Sen C.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs (Senator Bolkus) was entirely selective in the quotes that he gave to the chamber. I refer, for example, to paragraph 9.17. He read the words:

SPEECH.PARA: The units were not offered incentives by AEM, as they were considered to be uncommitted tenants.
Then it goes on:
With the property adjustment program payments the effective rates for the businesses approximated the effective market rate as at December 1992. However,—
and this is what Senator Bolkus forgot-

as outlined in paragraphs 9.70 to 9.74 the units also benefited from a financial arrangement costing $3.9 million. The units have not had to pay for this arrangement in their rental or other expenses.
Then Senator Bolkus did not go on to 9.19:

PARA.TAB: If the business units had been free agents in the market at August 1992, they would have been able to attract the average market incentives available as indicated by the effective rents outlined at Table 5, page 10. By this time the availability of incentives was commonly known to informed market participants. This action would have resulted in the units paying comparable market rents and removed the need for category A payments under the property adjustment program.

SPEECH.PARA: The reason why this thing continues is that Senator Bolkus comes into the chamber and is poorly briefed—and I understand that. The people that gave him this brief probably did not draw his attention to the full quotes and the full text of the Auditor-General's report. I think one other paragraph he read to us was paragraph 9.78.

TALK.START.PARA: —I never read it to you, you goose.

—This is what this motion refers to. Why is the government so sensitive about tabling these particular documents? I will read it into the Hansard record to see that we put into context what the minister was talking about. Paragraph 9.78 reads:

PARA.TAB: The classification of these arrangements as incentives was observed to be widespread within Victoria.

SPEECH.PARA: Listen to this, Senator Bolkus:

For example, in correspondence from APG to AEM dated April 1993, the benefits below were classified as incentives and in other correspondence between APG and ACS dated August 1992 as having the effect of incentives.

That gives a little bit of a different spin to the comments Senator Bolkus made. Nonetheless, we can clear this issue up quite simply. Were incentives offered? Were they paid? Did they have the effect of distorting the financial arrangements of these business units?

PARA.TAB: The government can solve this problem by tabling the letters. It is no good coming in and asserting, and then selectively quoting, that incentives were not offered when paragraph 9.78 shows that the business units themselves describe them as incentives. I put it to Senator Bolkus that it is vitally important that these particular letters be tabled to determine the veracity of what he told the chamber. I understand the Australian Democrats will support the motion of my colleague Senator Campbell. Hopefully when these documents are tabled this rather grubby matter, which has dragged on for far too long, can be brought to an end.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Before I call Senator Spindler, I just want to say that there seems to have been developing in recent days an affection for a particular animal name. I find it hardly edifying or creating respect for the chamber. I have let it pass on a number of occasions, but I shall not let it pass again.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Spindler Sen S.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 5 May this year Senator McMullan tabled a letter from the Minister for Administrative Services, Mr Walker, which assured the Senate that:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . rents were determined on a market related basis without commercial incentives.

I am sad to the say that the audit report does not bear that out. As I understand it, apparently the three tenant agencies in question were not entirely happy with the arrangements of higher rent with compensation through PAP. It seems that there is a glitch with PAP in that the subsidy rates are based on market rents which are several months old. At a time of falling rent, this meant the tenants felt that they could do a bit better out in the open market.

PARA.TAB: In turn, AEM kept them quiet by offering them a package worth $3.9 million, consisting of rent-free periods and free fit out. Such arrangements are referred to in the market as incentives. They were referred to as incentives in correspondence between APG and AEM. They were referred to as having the effect of incentives in correspondence between APG and ACS. They certainly are an inducement to the tenants to stay in the building at rents otherwise in excess of market rental, even with the shonky PAP subsidy. Yet on page 27 the report quotes the arguments from the AEM people and from DAS as follows:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . the amounts were not incentives in the context of inducing the units to undertake something that would not have otherwise been undertaken but rather represented a package of financial benefits to the units for which they did not pay.
On page 15 the report states:
No incentives were provided to the business units even though the rental rates were based on the use of market incentives.

Clearly that is doublespeak. I think we need to get to the bottom of this. The Democrats support this particular motion, but I foreshadow that I will seek leave to move a motion which will widen the inquiry to other properties which are controlled by AEM. There are at least ten of these properties which, I am told, may well be leased under similar arrangements. I think this is only the tip of the iceberg, and we need to get to the bottom of the issue.

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply—I thank Senator Spindler for his contribution. I suspected many months ago that PAP and the dealings in Casselden Place were shonky. The Senate passed a resolution seeking these documents which would prove that the arrangements at Casselden Place were effectively creating a financial house of mirrors to cover up one of the biggest property disasters that have ever occurred in Australia, particularly in the Commonwealth of Australia.

PARA.TAB: It occurred over a period of ministers. We will not give any blame to Senator Bolkus, because he arrived relatively late on the scene. It was former Minister West who kicked off the Casselden Place Building. Senator Bolkus had the pleasure of being around it for a couple of years, then Senator McMullan and Mr Walker.

The ministers who are responsible for what is indeed a cover-up—even though Senator Bolkus said there was no cover-up and scandal—are Mr Walker, in the other place, and Senator McMullan, who has the leave of this place today. There was a cover-up, because the Senate passed on two occasions—specifically on 5 May and again on 10 May—a return to order motion requiring that these documents be tabled. Those orders were entirely defied by these ministers. They told us, if I may paraphrase them, that everything was okay and they were all normal commercial arrangements. Mr Walker said in writing, and Senator McMullan said in the Hansard, that no incentives were involved. This was quite clearly stated.

The Auditor-General's report now shows that on those two occasions both of those ministers grossly misled the parliament. They said that there were no incentives, and tens of millions of dollars worth of incentives have been paid. The Auditor-General reached a conclusion on the construction of this house of mirrors and all of the financial arrangements. I do not even think high-flying merchant bankers of the 1980s such as Mr Connell, or even entrepreneurs such as Mr Bond, could have come up with such an interesting scheme.

The minimum net result is that the Australian taxpayer has poured in excess of $103 million into this house of mirrors called Casselden Place. I am reminded of the debate we are having at the moment in the committee stage of the Aboriginal land fund bill. I thought Senator Chamarette might think of that. This government is pumping $21 million a year into its fantastic new justice package so that Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islanders can buy land, and here it is pouring $103 million into its white man's land in Melbourne.

I say it is a minimum of $103 million because, quite frankly, if the government had sought to minimise its losses one, two or three years ago—or even up to a few months ago—instead of deciding to cover up this property scandal, it could still have saved the taxpayer probably tens of millions of dollars. If it had availed itself of literally hundreds of acres of empty modern office accommodation available to lease in Melbourne, it could have saved millions.

The Auditor-General's report, which will be tabled in a short while, will confirm that the government has lost $103 million. It is absolutely vital that these documents be finally tabled. It is an absolute disgrace that the minister should say, `Well, you can pass this motion because you have the numbers, but who cares? You can stuff the Senate.'

TALK.START.PARA: —I didn't say that.

—Senator Bolkus did not say it, I said it. He is saying, `You can pass this motion. You can require us to table these specific documents.' He has basically told the Senate on two occasions that he will ignore the Senate's orders to table documents. He has said, `Everything is hunky-dory. We don't need to table these documents. Trust us. Everything is fine in Casselden Place. It is all commercial. There are no special deals.'

PARA.TAB: Of course, the Auditor-General found that that was not the case, and that we have a massive property scandal. It is of WA Inc. proportions. I say that because the sin that has been committed is that two ministers, and possibly a third, are trying to cover up the proportion of those losses—and $103 million is a big loss.

It is imperative that these documents be tabled by 5.00 p.m. today. There is absolutely no practical reason why these documents cannot be tabled. They have been cited by the Auditor-General. They can be faxed to this building within minutes. There is no reason why they should not be tabled. If they are not tabled, it is a further contempt of the Senate and a further contempt of the Australian people, who should be appalled that the Labor government has poured $103 million down the sewer pipe with this disgraceful waste of money.

TALK.START.PARA: —I take a point of order, Mr Deputy President. I will not force this to a division in recognition of the fact that the numbers are against the government. As I say, we are very strongly opposed to this motion.

PARA.TAB: Question resolved in the affirmative.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to move a motion for an order for the production of documents.

PARA.TAB: Leave not granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —Pursuant to contingent notice and at the request of the Leader of the Australian Democrats, Senator Kernot, I move:

PARA.TAB: That so much of the standing orders be suspended as would prevent Senator Kernot moving a motion to provide for the consideration of a matter, namely a motion to give precedence to a motion relating to production of a document by the Auditor-General.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Motion (by Senator Spindler, on behalf of Senator Kernot) agreed to:
That a motion relating to the production of a document by the Auditor-General may be moved immediately and have precedence over all other business this day till determined.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Spindler Sen S.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That a report by the Auditor-General be laid on the table, as soon as practicable, with respect to the management of property leases under the control of Australian Estate Management: Whether that management is effective and conducted without undue risk to the Commonwealth or distortion of the relevant property market.

SPEECH.PARA: I regret the waste of time occasioned by the refusal of the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs (Senator Bolkus) to give me leave to move this particular motion. The need for it has been amply demonstrated by the arguments previously placed before the Senate.

PARA.TAB: I simply argue that this motion is necessary due to the arrogance with which the bureaucrats and the ministers concerned in the Casselden Place situation have refused to give information which has been indicated to be important. It will be shown by the Auditor-General's report that this information is critical and that the management of the properties under the control of AEM has not been handled properly. It is therefore urgent that the Senate address whether this inquiry should be widened to other properties under the control of AEM.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOLKUS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Multicultural Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —Obviously the government opposes this motion as well. I will not go through the debate that we had on the previous matter, although this particular motion has come right out of the blue. Senator Spindler has disrupted the process this afternoon by coming up with this motion. I was given five minutes notice of it, and would have expected a bit more courtesy on a matter such as this.

PARA.TAB: Let me also say to Senator Spindler that I find this a very curious motion. What we have here is the Australian Democrats—the party of `feel good, soft and cuddly and more to life than just financial management'—asking the Auditor-General to make an assessment of all these leases on the basis of one criterion alone, that is, financial effectiveness. What about social considerations? What about, for instance, in leases consideration of the fact that one may have to apply access and equity principles, social justice, child-care centres and occupational health and safety aspects? All of those things are ignored in this motion. What Senator Spindler wants to find out is where the bottom dollar goes and forget about the people.

Let me say that Senator Spindler rushed in here wanting to be bigger and better than the Liberal Party of Australia. He wants more inquiries—`Let us have lots of them'. This is not just the tip of an iceberg; this is the tip of Antarctica. He is not just talking about one iceberg and one bundle of leases. Does he know how many leases AEM is actually involved in? He would not know. But I can say to Senator Spindler that this could keep the Auditor-General going for a good century or so. This motion reflects the lack of consideration that Senator Spindler has applied to this motion. He has jumped. He thought, `Wonderful! I can get on the bandwagon as well. I want to be a big boy like the rest of them; I will move my motion.' But what about all these other considerations? What about looking at how many leases AEM has?

The reality is once again that the government will get rolled on this so we will send this inquiry off to the Auditor-General who will sit there scratching his head, wanting bigger offices now to accommodate this sort of inquiry. One never knows, he might get offices in all sorts of places around town. Senator Spindler owes this Senate a lot more. Maybe it would be more appropriate to delete all words after `effectiveness of' in Senator Spindler's motion and replace them with `the Senate'. The motion would then read, `. . . the Auditor-General lay on the table of the Senate as soon as practicable a report on the following: the financial effectiveness of the Australian Senate'.

TALK.START.PARA: —The coalition will be supporting Senator Spindler's motion. We believe that the Casselden Place property scandal has indeed exposed the tip of a massive iceberg. If the Auditor-General agrees with Senator Bolkus's contention that it will tie that office up for the next century, that is probably good for the Australian Labor Party and Senator Bolkus because it will mean it will have to renew its lease in 15 years time in Centenary House.
—I hadn't thought of that.

—That is something he had not thought about. But I am quite sure that in practice the Auditor-General, if there is any concern about that, would come back to the Senate and say, `Sorry; we don't have the resources to do this', and the Senate may seek to reword the motion.

PARA.TAB: The Casselden Place scandal and the accompanying cover-up are a national disgrace which require further action. The coalition is considering bringing forward a motion in a fortnight's time which will ask the Auditor-General to conduct a cost-benefit analysis of how the Commonwealth should most efficiently extract itself from the Casselden Place disaster. There is certainly a number of policy decisions and financial considerations there. So at this stage I foreshadow that motion.

The whole question of incentives paid to Commonwealth tenants and interdepartmental payments requires this sort of investigation. It applies to a whole range of Commonwealth buildings across Australia. As people who read my annual Space Waste report will know, the Commonwealth has a massive property holding. In fact, it occupies space in Australia equivalent to the size of 43 MCGs side by side, if that can possibly be imagined, which would be great if there were West Coast Eagles in every one of them.

But I will just say that this matter of incentives is important. The interpretation of how they are handled is a matter that has been considered by both the Australian Taxation Office, which has clearly defined what incentives mean and referred to the matter, and indeed the Department of Finance has gone into some detail about these incentives. So this is a massive matter which has come into the realm of public administration.

This inquiry will be important not only in locating other Casselden Places—which I hope will not be found because the Australian taxpayers will be even more horrified than they are today—but certainly in leading to an uncovering of what is one of the biggest property scandals, one of the biggest financial disasters, of this Labor government in its 11-year history. If this is the tip of the iceberg, we need to dive down under the water to see what is down there to ensure that this does not happen again.

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply—In answer to the comments of the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs (Senator Bolkus), we are addressing the financial transactions and financial accountability of the government. The task need not be monumental. We are prepared to have the Auditor-General look at leases—whether they conform to market rents and whether any incentives have been offered—and use that as a trigger for further investigations if necessary.

—Mr President, by way of clarification, I can say that the government will not force this to a division although we are very strongly opposed to the resolution, as I made very clear in my earlier comments.

PARA.TAB: Question resolved in the affirmative.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to give notice of a very brief motion of disallowance.

PARA.TAB: Leave not granted.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: United Nations International Conference on Population and Development

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOLKUS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Multicultural Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to make a statement relating to the outcome of the United Nations International Conference on Population and Development held in Cairo between 5 and 13 September 1994 and to move to take note of the statement.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Deputy President, I informed this house on 24 August 1994 of the objectives which the Australian delegation would be pursuing in Cairo at the United Nations International Conference on Population and Development, in response to a question from Senator Margaret Reynolds. I would now like to report to parliament on the outcome of that conference and draw attention to the part Australia played.

PARA.TAB: Australia's paramount concern at Cairo was that consensus be achieved on a strong, forward looking document. This was important because of both the critical goals contained within the draft program of action and the importance we place on the United Nations process of consensus in advancing international reform. In fact, the agreement reached at Cairo has been a triumph for the process.

The major themes of the conference had the potential to generate controversy—potential which was fulfilled—but there was also a strong possibility that the conference would split irreconcilably along north-south or religious lines. Such a split did not occur and Australia played its part in ensuring that agreement was reached on the widest possible range of issues and, just as importantly, that the program of action which emerged was indeed forward looking, that it built on, rather than withdrew from, previous agreements and that it could be placed clearly within the framework of internationally accepted human rights.

Two major advances in thinking have now occurred since the earlier UN population conferences, in Bucharest in 1974 and Mexico City in 1984. The first is that population growth is seen as a global concern. The second is that population is no longer seen as a problem which can be tackled in isolation from social and economic conditions, particularly those which limit the power of women to control their own lives.

One of Australia's major objectives at Cairo was to promote agreement on strategies for empowering women, strategies to enable them to enjoy equally with men the full range of human rights. The program of action translates the principle of female empowerment into a range of practical actions involving: greater educational and employment opportunities for women and girls; making marriage an equal partnership; taking steps to protect women and girls from physical abuse and exploitation; and enabling women to participate fully in decision making at all levels of society.

The program of action, in prescribing gender equality, calls on men to take greater responsibility for their actions and to assume an equal share in the raising of children. The document recognises the importance of families within society and urges governments to support them. It also acknowledges that there is variety in the forms which families may take. Australia, as a nation which accepts cultural diversity, was active in promoting this principle.

Mr Acting Deputy President, some countries sought to limit the obligations under the program of action by seeking to place religious, ethical and cultural considerations on the same plane as national sovereignty and universally recognised international human rights. Australia was one of a number of countries which worked to preserve the balance between these considerations to ensure that human rights were not compromised.

Australia was also concerned to ensure that differences in views about contraception and abortion amongst member nations were not permitted to prevent agreement on strategies critical for addressing important issues of sexual and reproductive health. Although the Holy See and a small number of other states entered reservations in respect of chapters on sexual and reproductive health, wide agreement was nevertheless reached on a number of important new concepts in sexual and reproductive health encompassing not only physical wellbeing but also fulfilling human relationships.

One of our major objectives was to achieve agreement on a program of action which would support the internationally agreed right of men and women to have the information and the means to determine the number and spacing of their children. Agreement was reached not only on the need to ensure the widest availability and choice in safe and acceptable family planning methods but also on the need for adolescents to have access to appropriate information, services and counselling.

The program of action enshrines the principles of freedom of choice and non-coercion in family planning programs but takes a strong position on making available the means to exercise that choice. It seeks to address problems such as the maternal and infant mortality associated with high risk pregnancy and to minimise both the spread of sexually transmitted diseases and the need for abortion by making family planning and primary health care services as widely available as possible. For the first time, unsafe abortion and its consequences have been acknowledged as a major public health concern which governments are urged to address.

As I mentioned earlier, there is now widespread recognition that, to be successful, population programs need to integrate development and family planning objectives, and to include strategies for addressing the social and economic disadvantage so often associated with high levels of population growth. The program of action adopts such an integrated approach and Australia was pleased to contribute to this conclusion through the independent inquiry into population and development, which was made available to other delegations.

The program of action commits both donors and developing country governments to closing the gender gap which exists at every level of the education system in the developing world. There are 130 million eligible children who are not enrolled in primary school and 70 per cent of these are girls. Education is essential to the social development of countries and the dignity and wellbeing of their populations. Lack of education, particularly for girls, exacts a development cost in terms of lost opportunities to slow population growth, raise incomes, productivity and the quality of life.

That said, improving basic education, particularly for girls, is not a simple task and it requires action in a wide range of sectors, including particular efforts in training teachers and strengthening institutions. Australia will be seeking to increase funding in the education sector. We have already significantly increased assistance to health and population programs. Our task will be to design effective, culturally appropriate assistance that consolidates the efforts already being made by developing country governments.

The program of action recognises that significant additional resources will be required to translate the goals of Cairo into reality. The Australian government will be endeavouring to do its fair share.

There was also agreement to allocate resources for broader reproductive health concerns in addition to family planning programs. They also include maternal health, prevention of sexually transmitted diseases, including HIV and AIDS, and basic actions for collecting and analysing population data. This approach is consistent with Australia's development assistance programs which focus on women's empowerment, their health and education as essential to population programs.

Although it is important that population and development issues be pursued in concert, it is also important that governments develop policies which embody the principle of sustainability. Another important objective for the Australian delegation at Cairo was that of securing continued commitment to the principle that all economic activity, in developed and developing countries alike, should be environmentally sustainable. Australia was one of a small number of countries that pursued sustainable development issues consistently throughout the preparatory process and during the conference itself.

I am happy to report that the program of action builds on the international agreement reached at the United Nations Conference on Environment and Development. It does this by reiterating the importance of the concept of sustainability and strengthening language on the relationship between production, consumption and population. No less than five of the 15 principles adopted by the conference highlight the significance of sustainability in ensuring the future wellbeing of the world's population.

The concerns of indigenous peoples are important in the context of a program of action which deals with development and population. At Cairo we argued for explicit recognition of the needs of indigenous peoples in the program of action, not just because they comprise marginalised and disadvantaged groups in many societies, including our own, but because as they are custodians of values which reflect a uniquely durable relationship with the environment. Indigenous peoples often have a cultural and spiritual attachment to the environment which goes beyond economics, and which could be threatened by unsustainable development and some forms of population growth.

Australia was very active at the preceding preparatory committee meetings in New York in strengthening references to indigenous peoples throughout the text. It also managed to have a principle on indigenous peoples accepted within the revised draft set of 15 principles considered in Cairo, despite the number of draft principles having been reduced from 33, none of which dealt with indigenous peoples.

Australia, along with many other nations, is now pleased that a principle was adopted in Cairo which calls on member nations to recognise and support the identity, culture and interests of indigenous peoples and to enable them to participate fully in the economic, political and social life of the country. The program of action also calls on governments to respect the cultures of indigenous peoples, to enable them to own and manage territories, protect and restore natural resources and ecosystems on which they depend and to take these into account when formulating national policies.

Some difficult migration issues had to be addressed at the Cairo conference and it was important to achieve a balance between the need for national sovereignty, and recognition of the needs of refugees and migrants and the contribution that they can make. One issue that emerged with unexpected force in Cairo was the question of the right of family reunion. Few countries have recognised the benefits and desirability of family migration more than Australia. However, Australia and many other countries including the other traditional countries of migration, were not prepared to concede a right, particularly when its application to family groups was uncertain.

Australia was happy to be able to play a key role in brokering a solution calling on countries to recognise the value of family reunion and to reflect it in their legislation, as we have done in Australia, and which refers to Article 10 of the Convention on the Rights of the Child. This requires member nations to deal humanely and expeditiously with applications for family reunion between parents and children and to respect the right of exit.

I would now like to turn briefly to the future. Member nations are committed to regularly assessing their progress towards implementation of the program of action and reporting on a periodic basis. Many of the goals set out within the program are ones to which Australia has already given high priority and the targets are more than met. In other areas, Australia meets standards at a national level but needs to continue to address the needs of particular groups, such as indigenous peoples, people in rural and remote areas and people from non-English speaking backgrounds.

Australia needs to position itself early in ensuring that it meets, or more than meets, the objectives of the program of action. I have therefore initiated a detailed examination of the program of action. I would expect to make further statements on the results of this review early next year.

I would like to place on record my appreciation of all those who contributed to Australia's success at Cairo particularly Ambassador Butler, Richard Woolcott, parliamentary members of the delegation, officials from government agencies, representatives of non-government organisations and particularly my colleagues from this place, Senators Reynolds, Bourne and Harradine for their interest in going to Cairo and participating in the discussions there. I move:
That the Senate take note of the statement.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I welcome the minister's statement on the Cairo population conference which was held during early September. It was the third such United Nations conference, the others being held in 1974 and 1984. The conference addressed the issue of the burgeoning world population. It now stands at something like 5.7 billion people, which is up from just 2.5 billion people in 1950, and it is expected to grow to 7.3 billion by the year 2015, even if growth rates can be limited. The United Nations currently projects a world population of 10 billion by the year 2050; however, with policies implemented by governments to limit population growth, it hopes for a stabilising figure of close to eight billion or a little less. Senator Harradine will correct me if I am wrong.
—I don't know where you are getting your figures from.

—The conference was basically premised on an acceptance that high world population growth as it is is harmful to world development, and that one of the ways to improve human wellbeing is to limit or restrict the rate of world population growth. It is worth noting, and I make this as an observation, that whilst Senator Bolkus and the Australian government agreed with this premise in a global sense, as I understand it, they specifically rejected it in a national Australian sense. That is, they rejected limiting Australia's population growth and the concept that such growth inhibits rising living standards in countries such as Australia.

PARA.TAB: The relationship between population growth and development appears to present a conundrum that many participants at the conference had difficulty coming to terms with. There is still a wide range of views and research findings on the possible linkages between the rate of population growth and the rate of development and depletion of resources.

While not wishing to go over all the arguments here, there is evidence to support the view that in the developed world there has been a positive rather than an inverse relationship between population growth and economic growth. Whether that relationship continues today, and to what extent it applies to the developing world or parts of it—if at all—is obviously a debatable and highly contentious issue. That was one of the important subjects of the conference.
Newsweek magazine described the conference agenda as follows:

SPEECH.PARA: Imagine political correctness married to UN-committee-speak, and you'll get the flavour. The plan stops just short of urging governments to get in touch with their feelings, but has plenty of other absurdities.

Although the opposition could have attended in the same way that Senators Reynolds, Bourne and Harradine did, I do regret that the government did not see fit to actually invite the coalition to have a formal representative on the delegation. Viewing the conference from afar as an observer Cairo seemed in many ways to be dominated by feuds over birth control and abortion.

PARA.TAB: On the one side there was the Vatican lined up with the Islamic groups, and on the other side there were the liberal Western and most developing countries. The former grouping was opposed to artificial limits on births. The latter was supportive, to varying degrees, of national and international action to limit births and hence the population growth rate. There were shifting sands, obviously, as the conference went on. Senator Bolkus weighed into this debate by criticising the Catholic church over its pro-life stance by saying that its insistence:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . would not only cause human misery but would challenge the very commitment to humanity which forms an essential part of all such faiths.

If we do not, as a society, take an essentially positive pro-life approach to humanity and society, then I really wonder where our society in a civilised world will go. I think that is a matter of very grave concern. I know others will comment on that. Time magazine summed up the conference outcome as follows:
More power to women, fewer mouths to feed—the UN conference reaches consensus: gender equality is a key to curbing population growth.

In the end, no country at Cairo voted against the final draft position, although, as the minister pointed out in his statement today, the Holy See and a small number of other states entered reservations in respect of the chapters on sexual and reproductive health. The final position was one which emphasises individual human rights. It seeks, as the minister said, to empower women by better education, access to health care, and greater equality under the law in all societies—aspects with which the coalition would agree. The stress on education was also a very important point.

PARA.TAB: The final report calls for governments to commit $17 billion by the year 2000 to curbing population growth. I will be very interested to hear just how much this government has committed Australia towards contributing, particularly when I note that the government claims to:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . have more than trebled the resources it devotes to international assistance.
The minister's statement is notably vague on this commitment so far as Australia is concerned.

PARA.TAB: While broadly accepting the conclusions of the conference as practical and constructive, I am concerned about the relative lack of attention that was paid to the development side of the conference. For instance, what weight was brought to bear on those undemocratic regimes around the world which suppress their people, and which were importantly represented at the conference? What direction was spelt out for opening up undeveloped and developing nations to investment and economic advancement? Those equally, if not more, important areas for improving the wellbeing of our fellow world inhabitants are left to forums like GATT and others when troubles arise.

It would have been very helpful, to say the least, if the conference had expressed unanimous support for guaranteeing universal freedoms and liberties—social, political and economic. I hope that the next world conference on population and development will pay attention to these matters because they go to the very heart of the liberty and wellbeing of people. After all, population is all about people. It cannot reasonably be claimed, in my view, that these issues are irrelevant in such a conference. The wellbeing of people in the broadest sense should be at the centre of our international attention.

In this context, I would like to remind the Senate very briefly of the coalition's broad policy position on international population and development issues as enunciated by successive coalition foreign affairs spokesmen. We support measures fundamental to the alleviation of hunger, poverty and environmental degradation. We support Australia's ongoing overseas aid contributions to these measures.

We believe that some of the best international work on the relationship between population, development and environment is being done by international organisations like the World Health Organisation and UNICEF. These agencies often also draw on the knowledge and assistance of Australians in the biomedical, social science, demographic, scientific and medical fields. Some of the programs aim at reducing maternal and infant mortality, reproductive health issues and nutrition. The coalition also supports actions that facilitate voluntary access to safe family planning as an essential aspect in meeting global human development needs, especially improved health for women and children.

We believe that one of the best ways to discourage unsafe and harmful practices is to provide these voluntary programs but we are categorically opposed to any form of coercion in family planning issues, whether in terms of the methods used or in attempting to adhere to government targets, as may be the case for example in the People's Republic of China. As a coalition, we would certainly ensure that no Australian aid, either directly or indirectly, is used for these latter unacceptable purposes.

We are also fully supportive of international measures to increase education, housing and employment opportunities for the less fortunate, consistent with development and environment aims. In his statement today, the minister referred to what he described as some difficult migration issues addressed at Cairo. I notice that my time is about to expire so, as the minister did, I seek leave to have my last few words incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.

In his Statement today the Minister referred to what he described as some difficult migration issues addressed at Cairo, including in particular the question of the right of family reunion. Let me say that the Coalition supports the Government's approach at the Conference—an approach similar to that of many other countries—that while we recognise the benefits and desirability of family migration, we cannot concede it as an automatic right. I would stress however, that the Coalition remains strongly committed to family reunion and to humanitarian assistance. At the same time, we recognise the rights and the responsibilities of Governments to make decisions about their borders and the flow of people across them.

The Coalition is proud of its role over the past half century in formulating, implementing and supporting policies that have made Australia such an outstandingly successful diverse immigrant nation with an overriding sense of unity and commitment. We continue to support an ongoing and positive immigration program which respects Australia's national interests and the interests and needs of potential migrants, including in particular families, refugees and those in need of humanitarian assistance.

TALK.START.PARA: —I see that we do not have very much time left in this debate so I apologise to Hansard beforehand if I should speak rather quickly. However, I have very copious notes which can be referred to. On behalf of the Australian Democrats, I am pleased to express our full support for the contents of the program of action which was tabled today by the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs (Senator Bolkus). I was fortunate to have attended, as a member of the Australian delegation, the United Nations Conference on Population and Development which took place in September this year in Cairo. I was particularly fortunate because those of us who went were afforded a rare opportunity to meet and discuss with a wide range of groups and individuals from around the world the increasingly important and interrelated issues of population, development, the environment, human needs and social responsibilities.

PARA.TAB: With a world population presently around 5.7 billion and increasing at a rate of over one billion per decade, the international community had an almost overwhelming task of putting in place a program of action which would genuinely address these issues. One of the more startling statistics quoted by United States Vice-President Gore was that it took 10,000 generations to reach a population of two billion; and two more generations to double that figure. Across the whole spectrum of participants from national governments in the developed and developing world alike, to multilateral institutions such as the World Bank and to smaller non-government organisations, there was a general acceptance that without global efforts to slow population growth, science and technology would not be able to redeem the future from poverty and hunger.

The success of the conference owes much to the efforts of one woman in particular, Dr Nafis Sadik, General Secretary of the United Nations Population Fund. Dr Sadik is an extraordinary woman whose vision and personal energy are inspiring. It was largely because of her exceptional efforts that so much was achieved in Cairo. On the whole, the program of action is a realistic plan which, if acted upon, should effectively address the population and development challenges the world now faces. It is especially reassuring to find that the issue of what form of development we pursue is given serious attention in the program of action. This is one of the most vital issues the world faces in the next decade.

The real threat of course is the overconsumption patterns of the industrialised world—and that includes Australia. One of the more startling statistics given great emphasis in Cairo is that even though the industrialised world makes up only 22 per cent of the world's population, it consumes two-thirds of all resources and generates 75 per cent of all pollutants and wastes. So the issues for us in Cairo were much more complicated than a mere desire to bring world population numbers into a suitable balance in accordance with nature's capacity to cope.

There is also the need to address the runaway consumption of resources in the industrialised world and the development patterns that nations pursue. Population by itself is not the problem; rather it is the balance between population and resources. It is the unequal and the uncontrolled use of energy resources that makes life unsustainable. The program of action correctly recognises that the way we use resources in the environment has significant implications in terms of population policies.

Serious attention was also given in Cairo to the importance of integrating women into all future development activities, in order to meet population and development challenges. Women as heads of households, as educators and, particularly in the developing world, as the majority of the world's farmers—a fact often overlooked—have enormous potential to reverse the process of environmental damage and to limit population growth.

It is crucial that governments adopt the recommendations contained in the program of action which are based on the principle that successful population programs target the role of women in both the decision-making and implementation programs. Poverty and the low status of women are among the primary causes of rapid population growth and environmental degradation. Women are particularly dependent on children for economic security and thus they often feel forced not to limit their families, even though they might otherwise wish to do so. Rural women, in particular, are often forced to adopt environmentally destructive practices in their daily struggle just to survive—for example in such things as firewood collection. The world's poorest people have the least ability to engage in alternative economic activity.

In response to these interconnecting issues of poverty, overpopulation and environmental degradation, this Cairo program of action has successfully focused on the need to empower women and to provide women with the necessary resources through technology, training and education. Australia has an enormous responsibility to now ensure that our aid projects give increasing emphasis to women's issues and in particular to empowering women. I trust that the government will move to recognise this in next year's overseas aid budget. In particular, this will require substantial increases in the funding provided to family planning, health and education activities for women.

The Australian Democrats welcome the government's commitment to promoting non-coercive population polices as part of Australia's various overseas aid projects. One aspect of the program of action relating to family planning that deserves special mention is the recognition that it is just as important to include men in such projects as it is to include women. As the program of action makes clear, increasing men's responsibility for family planning increases the chances for success of all such programs. The twin objectives of empowering women and enlightening men to act on their responsibilities will lead to tangible results in the long term.

Another aspect of the program of action which we thoroughly welcome is the principles relating to the special roles and needs of indigenous peoples. The recognition which is afforded to indigenous identity, contributions and requirements represents a welcome progression in the international community's identification of the role of indigenous peoples. This is especially so because there was wide acceptance of the view in Cairo that indigenous peoples are generally among the most disadvantaged in the world today—and they deserve very special attention.

In the time left to me, I would like to mention my fellow members of the Australian delegation, all of whom very obviously were committed to achieving the best possible outcome and were prepared to work very hard and for very long hours to accomplish that goal. The atmosphere at such conferences is always tense and is usually quite difficult. To the credit of all members of the delegation, we were able to work together to achieve the best possible results under considerable pressure. I thank the minister for allowing me to be part of the delegation and I thank all the other members of the delegation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reynolds Sen The Hon M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I welcome the opportunity to speak in this debate. I would like to pay tribute to Minister Bolkus and Minister Bilney for their role and to acknowledge the role Australia played at the Population and Development Conference and in the lead-up at the preparatory conferences. I would also like to pay tribute to my colleagues in the chamber, Senator Bourne and Senator Harradine. Four women in particular—Marion Powall, Ros McGovern, Lois O'Donoghue and Dianne Proctor—played a very significant role and worked very hard throughout the conference. I think it is appropriate to mention them today.

PARA.TAB: As Senator Short said, the media tended to focus on the negative aspects of the debate in Cairo. However, the majority of us who were there, notwithstanding moments of extreme frustration at times in terms of the debate, would have come away very optimistic. Debates on any subject at United Nations conferences can appear to be rather protracted. One can see that there is a lot of rhetoric. One can ask where all this is leading. The conference, in my opinion, was very positive. It certainly has put firmly on the agenda the question of empowerment of women and the issue of women's reproductive rights. I am optimistic that Cairo will be seen in future years as the turning point in regard to issues relating to the population and development debate.

I accept Senator Short's reservations about resource allocation. I think it is true that, while there was much debate about many issues and countries agreed with the final action plan, the issue of how this plan is to be funded remains yet to be determined. I think this is unfortunate—
The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Childs)—Order! It being 4.30 p.m., we will proceed to the consideration of general business.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave for Senator Reynolds to be allowed to complete her speech and for Senator Harradine to speak for his allotted time.
—The coalition is disposed to agree to that.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate. In relation to the need for a focus on resource mobilisation, I think it is true that a number of us felt that more might have been achieved in getting absolute commitment from many nations in regard to resource allocation. What influenced this was the fact that the United Nations Social Development Summit is to be held in Copenhagen next March, and it was opportune for some countries to argue that this question of resource allocation in relation to the development issues should be included in that debate rather than finalised at Cairo.

PARA.TAB: I would like to conclude by focusing specifically on the resource mobilisation issues. We were all impressed with the delegate from Ghana, who said that we must curb the appetite of the developed world, which has become bloated from overconsumption. When we talk of population and development, we must remind ourselves of the inequities not only between north and south and between nations but within nations. The quality and success of population and development programs depend to a considerable extent on how strategically a country allocates its resources among various sectors. This, in turn, depends on the social, political, economic and cultural realities of the country and its population policy and program priorities. Parliamentarians attending a forum prior to the population and development conference which I had the opportunity to attend said:

SPEECH.PARA: We accept the responsibility as elected representatives of the people to translate public support for population and development activities into the most beneficial distribution of budgetary, human and administrative resources. We take note of the strong international consensus on the need to mobilize significant domestic and external financial resources and endorse the estimated resource requirements set forth in the draft Programme of Action. Additional resources to population and development programmes should be made available by shifting resources, especially from defense expenditures.

PARA.TAB: We therefore pledge to work to enact legislation to increase domestic funding for population and development programmes, as appropriate, and call upon the international community to provide the resources required to implement activities . . . At the same time, efficient use of existing resources is also important and should be pursued through such measures as decentralization, peoples' participation, a focus on target groups and an increase of national capacities.

SPEECH.PARA: I found that one of the very interesting features of the parliamentarians forum was the call to action. In relation to United Nations agendas, I think it is important to recognise that there is not only a government role but also a parliamentary role. The Australian government has recognised this on a couple of occasions by including parliamentarians in delegations. I think this is a practice that should be more widely adopted by many countries.

PARA.TAB: If the Program of Action is to be implemented to match the rhetoric that we all heard during the debate at Cairo, it will take parliamentarians across the political spectrum to closely monitor the activities of all governments to ensure that they always practice what they preach. It is very easy for countries to send along key government spokespeople to say what they believe should be the case in terms of a program, but it is what happens when we return to our respective countries that is important. Therefore, I would like to read a part of a document entitled Call to Action, which is from 300 parliamentarians attending the special preparatory conference prior to Cairo. It states:

Given our role in the civil society as representatives of people, we parliamentarians are uniquely placed to implement the ICDP Programme of Action, as adopted at Cairo, at the national and subnational level and to introduce a new concern for the planet and for humankind for the pursuit of national policies of our governments. We call on parliamentarians everywhere to:

SPEECH.PARA: —enact legislation to enable Governments to formulate and implement national population policies and programmes specifically, improvement of the legal, social, economic and cultural status of women;
—appeal to Governments which have not done so to sign the Convention on the Elimination of Discrimination against Women . . .
—establish mechanisms for parliamentarians to monitor and evaluate such policies and programmes on population;
—approve budgetary provisions to increase financial resources allocated to the implementation of population policies and programmes . . .
—generate public support among constituents for the mobilization and allocation of domestic resources . . .
—create greater awareness among policy makers and the general public about population and development issues, within the global context of sustainable development;
—promote the active participation of local governments, community groups and non-governmental organizations, especially women's groups, in implementing the Programme of Action as adopted . . .

I commend one of the first actions that has been taken as a result, and that is an initiative of Minister Carmen Lawrence, who has initiated a family planning review in Australia headed by Murray Coleman. I think that indicates that here in Australia we are acting on the Program of Action. We must take a number of other initiatives.
