I endorse particularly the comments of Senator Bourne in relation to the priorities of increasing the recognition of women in our overseas aid program.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —First of all, I place on record my appreciation and that of my colleagues for the very fine assistance we were given by the Australian embassy in Cairo and the Australian officers in Cairo. They worked under very difficult conditions and very long hours, and we were very appreciative of their help.

PARA.TAB: I went to the conference as a delegate in the hope that, by so doing, the draft declaration could be improved. I had studied the draft declaration prior to going there and had identified five or six particular areas which I felt required improvement. That improvement could well have been adopted. In the ultimate, I attempted day after day to raise those particular issues within the delegation, and some sort of excuse was always given that these matters could not be discussed at the particular time I raised them. The issues I wanted to raise related to human rights abuses in population programs.

Where there are target driven programs they are inherently coercive. My concern with the views that were being expressed was that the document should contain something more than just a simple statement about coercion. I believe that the declarations in the document about non-coercion required enforcement, and that such enforcement requires sanctions of those contravening human rights. Very often we will hear a country say, `We are not coercive. This is the work of some of the family planning workers and cadres that are over-enthusiastic'. We see gross violations of human rights—particularly women's rights. If we ask, `Can we visit these people in jail? How much are their fines?', we are told, `No, definitely not'. These people are allowed to do what they like. We need sanctions.

I was attempting to have included in the document the provisions that member countries should ensure that criminal sanctions, including imprisonment and fines, are applied against persons who induce participation in family planning and population programs by applying coercion, whether psychological, physical or economic, or who misrepresent the nature and effect of the birth control devices or drugs being supplied, or fail to ensure the free and informed consent of program participants. I do not have the time to go into it now, but there should be disciplinary action. Population programs found to have contained involuntary measures should not be funded.

The second matter related to consumer protection. I believe that member countries should ensure, by domestic legislation, that all population family planning should include an earmarked funding measure, separately administered by independent consumer protection and legal aid bodies to guarantee that recipients of birth control drugs and devices are properly and fully informed of health risks or side effects, and that legal aid is available to individuals and consumer groups to enable them to exercise their rights to due and impartial judicial process where any harm or damage from birth control drugs or devices is alleged. I can give honourable senators information on the consumer protection aspect.
On the question of development, the government had been saying that the Ahlburg report was to be used in Cairo as a guide. The Ahlburg report said:

SPEECH.PARA: If the Government seeks to improve the economic position of the poor, the largest and quickest impact will come from the most direct policy instruments available. Among such instruments are policies to increase access of the poor to land, credit, public infrastructure, and services, particularly, education and health.

I tried to raise these matters in the delegation day after day after day. I also tried to raise the question of finance. A draft program—which was finally endorsed; pretty quickly, I might add—required US$17 billion by the year 2000, US$18.5 billion by the year 2005 and US$20.5 billion by the year 2010. As far as Australia is concerned, in addition to the threefold increase in that area now, it would translate to a further threefold increase by the year 2000 and over fourfold by the year 2015.

PARA.TAB: This is taxpayer money. I was trying to assess how this was devised. I knew there had been meetings. I had seen documentation of meetings of people who would largely be beneficiaries of this huge amount of money. I also knew that our delegation brief was such that we did not favour the approach to resources in the Cairo document. I kept asking, `When are we to examine that matter?'. As a member of parliament, I believe that I had a responsibility to do that because it involved taxpayers' money.

On the Wednesday, I had been to the NGO forum where women from a number of countries were giving evidence to a tribunal hearing evidence on the dramatic effect of birth control drugs and devices. It almost made the tears come to my eyes. On the Wednesday afternoon I went back and said, `When are we going to discuss this?' Ambassador Butler said, `It will have to be later on. We really do not know how the program will proceed'.

That was too much for me and I made a bit of a scene. Subsequently, we had a discussion about what I had been trying to bring up. The ambassador undertook to see a number of delegations. Later he reported that he was not able to get support for the proposition. I asked him what delegations he had seen and could I speak to them. He refused.

I came away from the meeting feeling that it had been a waste of time because I believe that members of parliament were not able to express properly thought out views, particularly on matters which dealt with finance. That was a crucial question. I was extremely disappointed. I believe that these meetings should be open to any member of parliament who wants to go. The government did not pay for my expenses.

Time is running short, but I want to say two more things. Tensions did occur amongst the Third World delegates. Only seven pages out of 114 pages were devoted to development. Development was nearly ignored. Tensions did emerge. The minister may not have heard them, but if he had been there on Saturday afternoon and evening he would have heard them. The tension exploded over the issue of family reunion migration. That was an issue where the delegates let off steam because they were concerned. One could hear them talking about the fact that development was ignored in this international conference on population and development. (Time expired)
Debate (on motion by Senator Foreman) adjourned.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I table Auditor-General Audit Report No. 4 1994-95: Special investigation into Casselden Place building: Melbourne: Department of Administrative Services.

PARA.TAB: Debate resumed from 22 September, on motion by Senator Margetts:
That the Senate take note of the document.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Private Interests of Ministers and Parliamentary Secretaries

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to continue my remarks later.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted; debate adjourned.
Debate resumed from 22 September, on motion by Senator Panizza:
That the Senate take note of the document.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to continue my remarks later.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted; debate adjourned.
Debate resumed from 22 September, on motion by Senator O'Chee:
That the Senate take note of the document.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade

TALK.START.PARA: —Some of the problems with this report are directly attributable to the terms of reference of the report. This is the report entitled Subsistence to Supermarket, Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade. The unit was asked to report on the potential opportunities for agricultural and food exports Australia could exploit and to assess how well we are exploiting them and how we could exploit them better. With a brief like that, certain issues will be overlooked or ignored.

PARA.TAB: The report notes that South East Asia has moved from a basically self-sufficient peasant economy to a formal economy, with a transformation of the agricultural sector to a more concentrated, mechanised agriculture increasingly dominated by agri-business.

What is not noted is the social consequences of these changes. It is assumed that the changes are good—more money, a better society. In many cases, the formalisation of rural economies and transformation of agriculture has had the effect of seeing people driven off the land into urban slums. This cannot be seen as an improvement. In some cases, people have been driven off through economics; in others, they have been driven off at the point of a gun.

The World Bank, in a recent report, concluded in a survey of six east Asian economies that Thailand had not made major inroads into the reduction of poverty during the 1980s. It noted that Thailand's incidence of poverty was as high as Indonesia's, although the average gross national product per capita was 250 per cent higher. This is because development is uneven. The rural populations are simply not benefiting from it.

Again I focus on Thailand because it is frequently held up as a special success, even among the ASEAN nations. On page 5, the report notes the regionalisation of production, citing Thailand as an example. Thailand, it states, is starting to invest in production outside its borders. This bears closer examination.

An example cited is the Thai development of forestry production in Indochina and Myanmar. What does this mean? The situation has arisen because Thailand has so heavily exploited its own forest resources that the government was forced to act to ban logging. It is actually not quite a reasonable description of reality in Thailand.

The Khor Jor Kor relocation program involved the army moving villagers at gunpoint from forests to rehabilitate them. Rehabilitation consisted of clear-felling the forests and planting eucalypts for the Japanese pulp industry. Strong rural activism, widespread protests at these actions, at the murder of resisting villagers and at the arrest of monks who were protesting against these moves, and international pressure have all resulted in a review of the program, particularly after the overthrow of the Suchinda regime in late 1992. The program has been replaced by a royal project, however, which many Thais feel is equally bad. Another royal project involves the clear-felling of the last stand of native pine forest and the relocation of hill tribes in north Thailand.

In spite of such efforts to undermine the logging ban, logging—especially the logging of teak—has slowed markedly in Thailand. Thais, unable to exploit their own forests, have turned to the massive extraction of forests in neighbouring nations, particularly Myanmar and Cambodia. The stripping of Burmese forests has had a devastating impact on the Karen people and is a source of many of the problems within Myanmar. Huge volumes of teak are taken every year, with no consideration of sustainability.

The removal of Cambodian forests has involved the active assistance of the Khmer Rouge. In the face of the sanctions put on Cambodia in 1992, timber traders volunteered to assist in peacemaking. They cited their longstanding trading relations with the Khmer Rouge as giving them a good understanding with that group. At the time, the government showed its position by massively upgrading roads and border checkpoints to allow an additional 50,000 cubic metres of timber to pass to Thailand before the sanctions were put in place.

The sanguine statements of this report mask a grim reality of environmental and human exploitation. There are a number of other issues I wish to raise in connection with this report regarding its implications. I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macdonald Sen S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the document.

SPEECH.PARA: This committee was set up under the National Resources Management (Financial Assistance) Act 1992, which came into effect on 24 December 1992. The committee makes recommendations to the government on matters concerning natural resources management and investigates and reports to the Commonwealth on matters referred to it concerning natural resources management. It acknowledges that landcare is a broad-based community concern that affects each and every one of us. Through its composition, it acknowledges that landcare is very much made up of a community based organisation, a community based movement, for both farmers and non-farmers, and that the wider community needs to be involved in the development of landcare policies and programs.

PARA.TAB: We are over halfway through the decade of landcare and much has been done. Over 1,000 landcare groups operate across the nation and their work is to be applauded. The committee is of importance in providing the community's view on landcare to the government. It should be encouraged in this task.

TALK.START.PARA: —I also rise to speak on the report of the National Landcare Advisory Committee. This report is worthy of notice. The NLAC has a wide role in advising government on the important issue of landcare. Landcare, within the scope of NLAC's brief, also includes water care, and is not restricted to agriculture but includes rangeland, forestry and urban environments. It can advise, as various groups can make submissions, but the government need not take that advice or even pass it on.

PARA.TAB: We do not doubt the good intentions of the government on landcare. The government has been very supportive of the need for it and takes the issue seriously. We regret that the advice usually stays within departments and that the ultimate fate of initiatives is decided by cabinet and a small group of people concerned with fiscal management. The consideration of reports such as these is one of the few times the parliament actually hears from the NLAC.

We note with some satisfaction that the NLAC is recommending several measures we have supported for some time. Section 2.2.5 suggests that more positive incentives are needed to encourage the adoption of landcare. I mentioned a number of such initiatives in my speech the other day supporting Senator Coulter's amendment to tax bill No. 3, suggesting that donations of natural heritage should be given the same treatment as donations of built heritage.

Section 2.2.7 suggests a strong coordination and integration of all measures at all tiers of government. Section 2.2.2 specifically notes the need for work with local government. Section 2.2.9 echoes my suggestion that banks should be required to consider the management practices of farms or stations when giving loans, especially in regard to landcare. Section 2.2.11 notes that there are many options to mix an economic return with conservation by shifting to high value, low volume products and through properly managed tourism. Sections 2.2.8 and 2.2.10 highlight the ongoing problems of land and water degradation. Under section 2.3, the NLAC makes more explicit the need for urban landcare and suggests a separate body to counter the perception that landcare is only about agricultural farms.

It is clear from reading this that landcare is more than this. It concerns rangelands—for instance, pastoral leases. The issue highlighted in section 2.2.3, the involvement of Aboriginal people, relates in many cases to pastoral leases and to the fact that in some states there is reticence to declare a pastoral lease held by Aboriginal people as no longer viable, converting it to some other title, and therefore eliminating the requirement for it to be run on a pastoral lease—something that can damage the environment while increasing the management costs.

The whole area of pastoral leases is of concern. Some of those concerns have been voiced regarding the desertification convention. The concern for water care is also important, and really taking that up a notch in terms of programs regarding water conservation, protection of waterways, rural sewerage programs, fringing vegetation and so on, could have major benefits to Australia, particularly if some consideration for water conservation in relation to drought was incorporated into the program.

Something that has not been tackled by the NLAC but has been recommended by this chamber is that the NLAC should consider examining landcare in the context of climate change. What defensive strategies are possible and available? Are there ways to minimise risks to both land users and the land? Are there any areas or practices that can be identified as particularly important for either affirmative or preventative action? In conclusion, we hope that the general support for landcare will translate into an even stronger political will than the government has yet shown.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.PARA: The Australian Wool Realisation Commission is the body that was given the unenviable task of selling down the wool stockpile to meet the repayment schedule required by the government after the collapse of the reserve price scheme in 1991. The AWRC took over the Australian Wool Corporation's $2.7 billion debt and the 4.6 million bale stockpile, warehouses and related property.

PARA.TAB: The AWRC's main task was to discharge the debt in accordance with the specified seven-year repayment program by disposing of the stockpile. Its task was made extremely difficult for a number of reasons: firstly, the overhang of the immense amount of wool in the stockpile—over one year's production was there; secondly, the set repayment schedule; thirdly, the necessary transparency of the AWRC's operation, which made its business decisions extremely difficult; fourthly, the 1993 global recession; and, fifthly, all of these, combined with a high level of wool production, made the method of stockpile reduction and debt repayment a non-viable combination. It became essential for a change in stockpile disposal policy as a result of this. The government's Garnaut committee recommended that the AWRC be replaced by Wool International, a new body which has the responsibility of disposing of a fixed quantity of wool until privatisation, targeted for 1997.

Within its charter, the AWRC operated as best it might, and can take some credit for reinstilling confidence in buyers and processors of wool that the stockpile will be managed commercially and responsibly. I commend Mr Bob Richardson, the Managing Director of the AWRC, for the way in which he carried out his role. His commitment to the job and his knowledge of the wool industry were recognised by his appointment to head the new body, Wool International.

The wool industry is suffering from the drought, with the added burden of four years of prices that have made it impossible to have any fat to meet the present crisis. However, the conservative stockpile reduction schedule now set by Professor Garnaut, coupled with the world lifting out of recession and, more importantly, a confident wool trade, indicates that at last there is hope for this very great Australian industry.

At present the stockpile has been reduced to 3.5 million bales and forward selling has reinforced the optimistic approach to wool's future. The worry faced by the industry now is the very capacity of the Australian industry to survive this drought and to meet customer needs and expected increases in demand. The worry is that wool production will fall dramatically in 1994-95, although the clip forecasting people suggest that at this stage only a small fall is expected. I do not believe this. I would be surprised if there was not another substantial rise in the market indicator price in the next 12 months. That will make it very difficult to give the confidence that the trade requires and a permanency in supply.Certainly, a substantial increase in price is something the industry can do without.

One thing is clear: the stockpile reduction method must not be changed, and I do not believe it will be. Wool growers can be confident that Wool International is performing well. They can look forward to a valuable equity in 1997 when Wool International is returned to them in the form of shares. It will be a very happy day.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

Debate resumed from 18 October, on motion by Senator Spindler:

TALK.START.PARA: —The annual report of the Anti-Dumping Authority is a short but interesting report. Dumping refers to the practice of selling goods at a price which is less than the normal value of such goods in the country of export. About 70 per cent of trade is dumped.

PARA.TAB: The authority also deals with trade in goods which has been subsidised. Measures taken to counteract subsidies are called countervailing measures. Dumping and subsidies are seen as unfair trading designed to open markets to other nations through unfair competition. A duty is applied to such goods to counteract this attempt to distort the market. This is what the Anti-Dumping Authority does.

An issue then arising is whether anti-dumping laws are mis-used by nations as a trade barrier. Australia has been noted as a nation with a very active anti-dumping regime, and this has been the target of criticism in the trading community. This is partially because few other nations have anti-dumping laws, frequently because tariff and other duties are more dominant. We have followed the practice of unilaterally stripping away virtually all tariff barriers, which makes us more susceptible than other nations to dumping and subsidy.

The issue of anti-dumping gains greater prominence with the conclusion of the Uruguay Round of GATT and the establishment of the World Trade Organisation or WTO. From now on, it is not nations but the WTO that will decide on anti-dumping and countervailing measures. As noted in pamphlets from the ministry for customs, this will result in technical but significant changes to our anti-dumping regime. There is also the issue that the Uruguay Round agreement imposed limits on the use of countervailing duties to defend against subsidised food and agricultural exports.

The authority notes that anti-dumping cases diminished mainly because ICI was not bringing cases of dumping of chemicals before it. Indeed, inquiries have declined since 1991-92, although reviews of customs decisions are up. The report on page 2 notes the scope of complaints in the past, with enormous actions being brought against some 20 different countries. It notes that fewer claims occur but does not indicate whether this is the result of less dumping globally, the presence of a regulatory regime resulting in fewer attempts to dump in Australia, a stronger position of our industry leading to less concern with the level of dumping and subsidy, or whether there is some other reason that companies feel it is not worthwhile to pursue dumping and subsidy issues.

This is because the Anti-Dumping Authority is essentially reactive. It does not monitor trade or attempt to identify dumping, relying instead on the private sector to make claims. The authority therefore has little understanding of why a reduction of claims is occurring, or whether they might increase. Opinion in the authority is that dumping has not decreased at all, and that the decline is a result of the attitude of both major parties against regulation of trade, and the more outward looking approach of business with global economic recovery.

Clearly the behaviour of nations in deciding to subsidise, or companies deciding to dump, is going to involve factors other than statistical trend. They relate to international, national and corporate economics and the trade regulatory regime. This latter is a particular issue in light of the new WTO procedures for dispute resolution. In the past, the GATT required a unanimous vote of contracting parties. Under the new WTO it will be significantly easier to deem an anti-dumping or countervailing duty as impermissible. Along with lack of detail about the cause of reported changes, there is no real projection of the consequences of change in the international regulatory regime.

I would like to bring up a final issue in the context of this report. One of the primary proposals for environmental regulation is that the lack of environmental controls leading to environmental devastation in order to hold prices down is a sort of subsidy. It is therefore suggested that countervailing duties could be used, with the money collected hypothecated to environmental rehabilitation. The Greens would support such a move, which would need some support from international trade organisations. Currently, or in the next few weeks, the WTO, the United Nations ESCAP, the OECD and UNCTAD are all having meetings of committees set up to examine the relationship between the environment and trade or development, and to consider means of regulating trade and development to slow global environmental degradation. We will be watching closely for new regulations that affect anti-dumping and countervailing legislation; we will also be watching the Anti-Dumping Authority itself. I suggest that other senators do likewise.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation

TALK.START.PARA: —Yesterday I spoke of my concern about the evidence that was given at the Perth hearing of the inquiry into funding in CSIRO for agricultural research. I spoke about the fact that I saw two major reasons for less funding being available for general research, including agricultural research. One of those concerned what I believe to be the `commoditisation' of knowledge and information. This seems to be having the impact on individual scientists working within CSIRO—and this can be extrapolated to many of the universities throughout Australia and throughout the world—who are each working on trying to reinvent the same wheel.

PARA.TAB: Scientists might be working in the same department but cannot speak to each other because each is working on a privately funded project. Because of the nature of the patenting system, intellectual property concerns and so on, they cannot speak to each other about the work they are doing. They may be working in opposite directions but it may be that they are inventing the same wheel. It is also the case, it would seem, that a great deal of the time now spent by scientists involves chasing around after patents. Quite a considerable amount of time was talked about—perhaps up to 25 per cent. So we are having scientists dealing with areas with which they are not familiar.

We also have the problem that scientists who are not as familiar and as skilled in dealing with such issues as intellectual property may be putting public money into particular areas, and being done over by the process and the fact that other people are picking up their ideas and then patenting them, meaning that other people have the exclusive right. How does one patent an idea? How does one know that it is some person's idea and not another person's idea? How does one then restrict the use of those ideas in other places? This is having a real impact on general research here and in other countries.

The other major point that I felt came out in that hearing was that in the attempt to require CSIRO to find a higher proportion of private funding, we perhaps have lost a lot of the impact of what CSIRO was established to do. What in fact happens, according to those people who gave evidence, is that a great deal of scientists' time is used chasing private financing, putting in submissions and so on. That means that actual research time is reduced. It also means that the people who commission research by CSIRO, and who then get fairly substantial tax deductions for doing so—so in reality it is mainly the taxpayer who has paid it; and I have said this in the past—have a very high proportion of control over what research is done.

It was estimated at this hearing that 30 per cent of private funding can result in 70 per cent control over the research that is being done. This means that more specific research, applied research, is being carried out for particular bodies, not necessarily for agricultural bodies or organisations that have the public good at heart. So it means that more and more resources are being pulled away from general research in a whole raft of areas, including the environment. This is a great worry, because we begin to wonder whether CSIRO, being pushed to get a greater and greater proportion of private funding, is actually wasting research money. A great deal of this is involved in management.

Therefore, we have to really rethink whether or not we do need pure research. There is clear evidence throughout the world that it is pure research that leads to the most important discoveries in our society, not specifically targeted industrial research. We have to think about whether we want to be the clever country, or whether we want, for the sake of privatisation, to ruin this opportunity.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.PARA: When I looked at the annual report, I noted that at item 2.13 and 2.14 the Electoral Commission talked about compliance investigations and also investigations and prosecutions of actions relating to elections in previous years. I have been looking at these reports for some years, and I was hoping to have my memory refreshed in relation to an action which I recall being mentioned in the parliament about commissioners investigating some irregularities alleged to have occurred in relation to the Australian Democrats—I think it was in the New South Wales division.

PARA.TAB: I was hoping that this report may have indicated the results of that investigation and whether any proceedings had been instituted against the Australian Democrats or any other persons in relation to those investigations. It may well be that the investigations are not yet complete. It may be that they are complete and action has been taken or they are complete and the commission has decided to take no action. One way or another—because it was a fairly important matter, and I understand there were some fairly serious allegations—I hoped that the commission would have reported upon it in this particular report.

I move on to another matter which relates to the redistribution of electoral boundaries in Victoria, Queensland and the Australian Capital Territory. I am pleased to say that because of the continuing growth in my state of Queensland we have been allocated yet another federal seat, and the redistribution has concluded in my state. One of the roles of the Electoral Commission is, of course, for the preparation and production of redistribution maps and reports. I note at page 30 of the report that the commission is also charged with the responsibility of making the community aware of:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . as much information as is necessary to enable active and informed participation in the electoral process.

In the Queensland redistribution, there was a reasonably minor alteration to the boundaries in the electorate of Herbert, which are based on Townsville in an area where I have my office and adjacent to an area where I live. I found it very difficult to get information of exactly where that boundary went. Certainly, maps were published in the newspaper but they can be, of necessity, only very broad maps. From the broad maps published, it did not look like there was much change in the electorate. It was only a couple of days before the objections closed that someone suggested to me that there was to be quite a dramatic change in the electorate, one which may or may not have had quite significant electoral consequences.

PARA.TAB: At almost the eleventh hour, I then tried to get copies of where the boundaries went—which streets they covered, which suburbs they cut in and which suburbs they cut out. I regret to say that it was rather difficult for me to find out where exactly the boundary went. I did eventually get on to an officer in Canberra, whose name I wish I could remember because he was very helpful. He went out of his way to find out the information and he sought authority from various people, which seemed a bit strange to me, but in any case I eventually did get the results.

When I saw them, I realised that there was quite a dramatic change. I was concerned that the public of Townsville had not been told that part of their city was being cut off. A couple of suburbs in the southern part of the Townsville City Council were cut off, taken out of the Townsville based electorate and included in the Dawson electorate, which is based upon Mackay, some 400 kilometres to the south.

Unfortunately, the people involved were not aware of it. I immediately tried to make them aware of it by using the media. I put in an objection myself, but it was a bit late for most of the people to understand what was happening. I was concerned about that. As it turned out, the Electoral Commission did hear objections. It did not take any notice of mine,

SPEECH.PARA: nor the objection of more than 250 petitioners who were able to lodge a petition in those last couple of days.

PARA.TAB: As a result, unfortunately, the city of Townsville is now cut in two, with a couple of the southern suburbs taken out of the Townsville based electorate and put in with Mackay, 400 kilometres to the south. I noticed that the honourable member for Herbert, Mr Ted Lindsay, supported the application, because he thought the two suburbs being cut out were conservative voting electorates, and he did not want them in his electorate. (Time expired)
Debate (on motion by Senator O'Chee) adjourned.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: O'Chee Sen W.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the document.

SPEECH.PARA: This report is an interesting document. It is a bit of an arcane document, because not a lot of people take a great deal of interest in the operation of the Bankruptcy Act. The Bankruptcy Act is very important because it is one of the instruments of public policy which is used to enforce some sort of decent behaviour in business dealings. It is important, therefore, that the act operates properly.

PARA.TAB: The report is also interesting because it gives very good statistical breakdowns of bankruptcies by state, age, industry classification, cause of bankruptcy and so on. One of the disturbing things that I noted was the large increase in bankruptcies in Tasmania, which grew by more than 11 per cent. More disturbing than that was the age distribution of people who became bankrupt in Tasmania in the previous financial year. Of the 656 people who became bankrupts, 285 were under 34 years of age. Ninety of them were aged under 25. That means that 43 per cent of bankrupts in Tasmania were young people. That is substantially above the national average.

It would appear, from looking at other statistical information, that the principal reason for the non-business bankruptcies would tend to be unemployment. That shows that it is the young people who are suffering. It is interesting that not just unemployment is being visited upon them, but also bankruptcy. That is a terrible stigma to have when one is a young person, because it basically means three years taken out of a person's life—three years in which they cannot start to buy a house or proceed to accumulate assets, all the normal things that people do at that age.

We must pay attention to how we run the economy to ensure that that level of failure is not visited upon young people. There are other ways out, but one of the problems is that young people generally do not avail themselves of the provisions of part X of the Bankruptcy Act and become debtors under administration. The flow of information to them is not sufficient, and generally they do not have a lot of assets to put up for a deed of arrangement, a composition or something like that. So there is an unfairness which we are perceiving at the moment. I hope that it is something which will change over time.

The other aspect I want to comment on—and I commented on this last year—is funding under section 305 of the Bankruptcy Act. Funding under section 305 is intended to provide money for trustees to run legal actions in the estates of bankrupts where there are no assets. As honourable senators would appreciate, the best way for crooked bankrupts to ensure that they do not get pursued is to not leave any money in their estate. The trustees get appointed to a state with no assets; therefore, nothing can be done to realise funds to pursue the bankrupts for whatever unsatisfactory behaviour they indulged in.

Section 305 was intended to provide funding for that but it is interesting to note that the number of applications approved under section 305 has steadily declined from a peak of 237 in 1986-87 to 41 in the last financial year. The estimated cost of those 41 applications was a mere $302,000.

If we compare that with the receipts of the registered trustees, which were some $54.6 million last year, and the receipts of the official trustees, which were some $28 million, it is very clear that the official receiver has received several million dollars in charges on the realisations that trustees are forced to lodge with the official receiver. Yet nothing substantial has come out of section 305 funding. It was always intended that the charge on realisations that the trustees must lodge was substantially to fund section 305 of the Bankruptcy Act. Yet a mere $302,000 was the estimated cost and the rest has been snaffled.

I note from the report that the Inspector-General in Bankruptcy states that the operations of the Insolvency and Trustee Service of Australia are substantially funded by the taxpayer. I believe that they are also very heavily subsidised by those realisations and they are funded by creditors. But even to the extent that they are funded by the taxpayers, ITSA's operations are very important. As I said, part of the process of implementing public policy is ensuring that people who indulge in unsatisfactory business conduct do not get away with it. I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the document.
I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the document.

SPEECH.PARA: I am interested in the Department of Defence report for 1993-94 for several reasons. One is the fact that consultants were employed by the department during the year at a cost of $53.3 million. One particular consultant is a company called Malindoqueen, a consultancy that cost the department $174,000. That company was the subject of a question that I put on notice to the Minister for Defence, Senator Robert Ray, from whom I received a reply this week. As the Australian reported:

The Minister for Defence, Senator Ray, has ordered a top-level inquiry into a government contract awarded to a private company to obtain sensitive information about priorities in Indonesia's defence expenditure.
The move follows questions raised by the Federal Opposition about the company's operations and its level of access to classified Australian defence security material.

Senator Ray has asked the Inspector-General in Defence, Mr Frank Harvey, to investigate the nature of the government contract granted to the Australian company, Malindoqueen Consultants, between July 1993 and June this year.
The Minister is believed to be concerned that his department awarded the sensitive defence contract to Malindoqueen without receiving appropriate high-level approval.

I further understand that the department was using Malindoqueen to ascertain the Indonesian navy's interest in purchasing high-powered submarines from Australia. It seems extraordinary that the information for which Malindoqueen was paid $174,000 to get was not available through Australian defence attaches in Jakarta. Was that because the information was not readily available?

PARA.TAB: I will seek leave later to table a letter from Mr Mike Waller, First Assistant Secretary of the Industry Involvement and Contracting Section of the Department of Defence, supporting an application for residency from the director of Malindoqueen. He says that, under the its contract, Malindoqueen is required to `introduce the department to higher Indonesian defence circles and obtain information about priorities in Indonesian defence expenditure'. Surely if that were public information it would be readily available. Is this an attempt to get information through the back door or some other way?

Mr Waller went on to say that the work being done for the Department of Defence was of `undoubted strategic importance to Australia'. So what is this all about? I can inform the Senate that today I put on notice to the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Senator Gareth Evans) this question:

SPEECH.PARA: I refer to the reply to my question on Notice No. 1687 by the Minister for Defence in which he reveals he has ordered a top-level enquiry by the Inspector General in Defence into a contract by his department with a company called Malindoqueen which the Minister for Defence has directed should not be renewed.

Was the Minister for Foreign Affairs aware of the nature of this contract, which has been described by Mr Mike Waller, First Assistant Secretary of the Industry Involvement and Contracting section of the department of Defence, in a letter to the Department of Immigration supporting an Australian residency application by a director of Malindoqueen, as requiring Malindoqueen to "introduce the department to higher Indonesian defence circles and obtain information about priorities in Indonesian defence expenditure"?
Was the department of Foreign Affairs ever advised by the Department of Defence that it was employing, since July 1993, a foreign national to obtain, at undisclosed cost—
I have since discovered that the cost was $174,000—
confidential details of Indonesian defence spending priorities that were not available to Australian defence staff at the Australian embassy in Djakarta?
Was this an operation whose objective was to offer bribes or other inducements to Indonesian officials and are such activities condoned by the government and the Department of Foreign Affairs?
To what extent does this kind of activity put at risk our friendly relationship with Indonesia and what is the Minister doing to prevent such diplomatically embarrassing events recurring?

I hope that the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Senator Gareth Evans) will be able to answer that question very soon because it is not something that should be hanging over the department's head. I seek leave to table the letter to which I referred.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to continue my remarks later.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted; debate adjourned.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Parer Sen W.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the document.

SPEECH.PARA: I would like to take this opportunity to say a few words about the Australian Tourist Commission and to congratulate it on the work that it does. The job of the commission is to market Australia overseas as a tourist destination. Tourism is probably the most competitive market in the world. In Australia we have benefited enormously from the work of individual entrepreneurs, theme parks and resorts, all working hand in glove with the Australian Tourist Commission. They are a good combination.

PARA.TAB: Tourism has really developed right throughout Australia—in my own state of Queensland, from Cairns down to the Gold Coast and into the northern parts of New South Wales. However, it should borne in mind that while even with all that effort we get only one per cent of the world tourist trade, from our largest single market, Japan, we pick up five per cent. Yet there is an impression in the community that we get all the Japanese tourists, which is of course far from true.

The Australian Tourist Commission does a first-class job. The people who work for it are dedicated. Over the last couple of months I have had the pleasure and the honour of meeting some of them. I met up with wholesalers and airlines representatives in places such as Taiwan and Japan and they all spoke very highly of the work done by the Australian Tourist Commission.

There are, however, a couple of hiccups on the horizon, and I think they should be mentioned. The first is that there is growing interference by the Minister for Tourism (Mr Lee) in the work of the commission. Tourism is these people's job and they are measured by the results they produce. Increasingly, they are getting notes, allegedly from the minister, demanding reports be made. This is taking up an inordinate amount of time on work that should be done competing against other countries to get foreign tourists to Australia.

The other concern I have, and I looked for this in the report, is that in my travels overseas I found that key people from the Australian Tourist Commission were leaving and going into the private sector. The reason is that the government has not seen fit to give flexibility to the Australian Tourist Commission to retain these people. They have been a very valuable asset to this country and it is important that their expertise not be lost simply because of the inflexibility of this government.

The other thing that I want to mention—this was raised in recent days at the Japan-Australia Business Cooperation Committee by a range of people, including the chairman of the Australian Tourist Commission—is that tourism here may be in jeopardy because of a lack of accommodation. It was pointed out by Mr Iwasaki that Australia must address its dramatic accommodation shortage. He also said that it may be dangerous for Australia to become too conceited over having such rich resources in tourism. The well-known Japan Travel Bureau urged better planning of accommodation.

Everyone has known that this problem has been looming for the past couple of years. The demand is apparent, and the question is often asked: if the demand is there, why are these resorts not being built? There are a number of reasons and all of them can be sheeted back to the government.

One of the reasons is the difficulties encountered by people who want to build resorts. This is because we have governments prepared to listen to vocal minorities whose threats throw the development of projects into jeopardy at the expense of the communities and regions concerned, and at the expense of employment in those regions. We have seen these sorts of blockages. Recently there was one at Byron Bay, and now there is the one at Port Hinchinbrook.

In addition, there is the plethora of taxes imposed by various governments on an industry which is labour intensive. If our industry is going to pick up in a market which, as I mentioned earlier, is the most competitive market in the world, and employ these people, particularly the young people, these barriers must be turned around.

All these factors send out terrible signals to financial institutions, which have been a bit nervous anyway in recent times, and prospective investors. Many businesses and organisations, such as the ATC, have spent a lot of time and money promoting Australia as a destination for overseas tourists. Unless these impediments are addressed, we as a nation will suffer and the real jobs which this industry has the potential to create will not eventuate.

TALK.START.PARA: —I concur with and support the remarks made by my colleague Senator Parer, who is the shadow minister for tourism and a person who is very much aware of what is happening in this industry. I certainly support Senator Parer's remarks about the accommodation shortage. I speak from experience in Far North Queensland, where there is a real shortage in Cairns.

PARA.TAB: Senator Parer was correct when he said that governments—federal, state and local—have to look very seriously at the impediments they place in the way of these increased tourist activities. At particular fault is the federal government for the way it taxes the tourist industry and small business and for not being game, because of its close connections with the ACTU, to make industrial relations as flexible as they should be. Is it simply not able to do what it knows needs to be done in that regard?

I also want to make the comment that the Australian Tourist Commission could almost be called the New South Wales Tourist Commission because the seven of its 10 board directors come from New South Wales, the majority from Sydney. Of the other three, one comes from Queensland, one from Victoria and the head of the department is in Canberra.

That seems incredible to me. It is a bit like the grants for elite artists; the good artists seem to live only in Sydney. Apparently the people who know anything about the tourist industry seem to live only in Sydney as well.

Whilst I concede that the board and the commission do a good job in promoting Australia, I do not understand why the board members could not come from other parts of Australia and lend the expertise and regional knowledge they would have to that board. I am not suggesting that the current incumbents are not competent and good at their job, but I am sure that there are persons equally qualified and who could make an equal contribution to tourism promotion who live in other states and other cities besides Sydney.

I also wonder why, if this government is at all interested in regional development and decentralisation, the headquarters of this commission have to be in Sydney. Why can they not be in Ballarat, Bendigo, Port Lincoln or Perth? Why not in Mackay, Ballina, Coolangatta or Tweed Heads? Why not in Nowra, Alice Springs, Cairns or Townsville?

These days these sorts of offices could be established anywhere. The support mechanisms are available in most Australian cities and, of course, with communications the way they are, there does not seem to be any real reason that this type of organisation, particularly one dealing with tourism, could not be established in another city around Australia. If that were to happen it would be a tremendous boost for regional development, it would be a tremendous boost for decentralisation and it would create a lot of activity in some other town.

I ask the government: why Sydney? Why does everything have to be concentrated in Sydney? Is it because the minister, who is known to be one of the movers and shakers in the New South Wales Right, comes from Sydney? It is quite interesting that this minister is also the minister in charge of the arts, and he seems to have a fixation with Sydney and cannot see beyond the harbour shores when picking the best artists for grants and the best people to put on the board.

I note that the board travelled about a bit last year and moved out of Sydney to Brisbane and Melbourne. But again I wonder why it cannot move a bit further afield? Why not have some meetings in Cairns, Nowra, Ballarat, Perth or perhaps Darwin? It would seem that that would be an appropriate way for this Sydney-based organisation to show that it is taking into account the interests of other tourist areas in Australia.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 13 October, on motion by Senator Gareth Evans:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the document.

TALK.START.PARA: —The third report of the Senate Select Committee on the Functions, Powers and Operations of the Australian Loan Council was completed and tabled in December of last year. As the final report notes, the Senate inquiry proceeded on the twin assumptions that the Loan Council process itself was in some disarray, and that it was in the public interest that the facts surrounding the so-called Victorian loans affair be revealed.

PARA.TAB: The committee's report made a total of six recommendations, and it is heartening to note that the government, in its response, has acknowledged the worth of each of those recommendations. During my time on the Senate committee, I took considerable interest in the question of accrual accounting, and the implications of that concept for accountability in government and transparency in public sector transactions. For those reasons, I particularly supported the committee's recommendation relating to the adoption of accrual accounting as a matter of priority by all state and federal governments and including Loan Council disclosures.

In an important submission to the committee, Professor Bob Officer and Mr Saul Eslake from the Victorian Commission of Audit pointed to the deficiencies of current government accounting where accrual accounting was not used. They pointed out, for example, that accrual accounting would help in reducing the opportunities for window-dressing budget results by shifting cash transactions around balance dates.

Accrual accounting is considered a superior method of accounting as it results in accounting measurements based on the substance of transactions and events rather than merely on cash received and disbursed. Accrual accounting results in better financial information, better performance measurement, better asset management, better debt management and a clearer picture of a government's overall financial situation.

In its response to the committee's report, the government makes the point that the Loan Council itself could only move to an accrual system when all its members had done so on a consistent basis. I understand that considerable progress has been made on the move towards full accrual accounting by commonwealth departments and agencies, with the latter being able to report on an accruals basis fully by the end of this financial year. In addition, each state and territory has moved along this road to varying extents. My plea today is for all states and territories to give urgent attention to this matter and to fall in behind the commonwealth in this very significant reform of public accounting methods.

Further recommendations related to uniform reporting requirements, auditing of reports and the making of such reporting requirements legally binding on the Commonwealth and the state and territory governments through an amendment to the financial agreement. Again, I am pleased to note that many of the underlying aims of these recommendations have been achieved by the signing in February of this year of the new financial agreement and the introduction of complementary state and territory legislation.

I welcome many of the recent reforms to the operations and guidelines of the Loan Council. The important principles of greater disclosure and improved accountability, which I have already spoken on earlier, are of great significance. The Australian public requires and deserves greater accountability in all aspects of government sector operations. After all, it is not the government's money that is at risk, it is the money belonging to the Australian taxpayer. Public sector activities, whether they be current spending, capital spending or the sale of government assets, should all be totally transparent and subject to the most comprehensive guidelines possible.

I hope that the start that has been made on reforming the operations and reporting guidelines of the Australian Loan Council are only the beginning of a more extensive overhaul of all public sector operations which will ensure the best value for the taxpayers' dollar.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Debate resumed from 12 October, on motion by Senator McKiernan:
That the Senate take note of the report.

TALK.START.PARA: —This report is very welcome indeed. It is very thorough and detailed, and it pays a great deal of attention to the shortcomings of the citizenship act as it now is and the amendments that need to be considered by government. I believe that a very important first step has been taken. I wish to comment on two particular aspects of the report. One of them is the area of education and information for citizenship, and the other is the dual citizenship concept which the report recommends should be available to Australians.

PARA.TAB: I find that the recommendations dealing with the educational information program are extremely well targeted and worth while—for instance, calling for an increase among all Australians of the awareness and understanding about the rights and responsibilities of citizenship. Further, it seeks to introduce in the Australian schools curriculum a course on Australian institutions and history, the rights and responsibilities of Australian citizenship and the principles and values of Australian society.

In some ways this is an extremely important emphasis. We all agree that people coming to this country need this information and, to a greater or lesser extent, efforts are made to provide them with that information. But during the last decade or so, I believe that citizenship education has been sadly lacking in our school system.

I speak at schools quite a lot in Victoria. I have spoken to about 200 different schools in the last two or three years on the workings of the Australian Parliament. I believe that this is extremely important because I think the old adage that we get the government and the leaders we deserve is very true. If we ask people to vote in the political system without knowing the system and how it works, and the consequences of making certain decisions, I believe the concept of citizenship becomes somewhat of a mockery. I have found during those visits to schools, particularly during the last year or two, that class sizes have diminished. Politics or civics or whatever we want to call it—and there are different names being used for these various courses—have been made elective subjects. They are not part of the core curriculum, and fewer students apparently opt for these courses.

Earlier reports have been submitted to the Senate. One is called the Education for active citizenship 1989, which makes very strong recommendations that the Commonwealth initiate a national program in education for active citizenship. I regret to say that this recommendation, in my view, does not appear to have been taken up. There is really no evidence that our education system has responded to that challenge. I think that committee made a very good contribution to that debate. I note that Senator Paul McLean from the Democrats was a member of that committee, and it was chaired by Senator Terry Aulich. I believe it is a great pity that that recommendation was not taken up.

There was another report in March 1991 called Active citizenship revisited. Once again we have a recommendation. The committee recommended that school systems identify, publicise and support existing citizenship education initiatives and encourage their extension to other schools. Once again, I believe that suggestion was not taken up. It was a suggestion very strongly supported by the Australian Democrats, and I note that Senator Robert Bell and Senator Cheryl Kernot were at various times members of that committee.

I welcome very much this recommendation that was made once again in this report that is now before the Senate, entitled Australians all: enhancing Australian citizenship. I hope that this time the education system and the people who make decisions in the education system as we move towards 2000 will take some note of it and that these recommendations will be implemented.

I recall that some years ago, when I first became aware of the appalling ignorance amongst young people of how they can participate in the political process as citizens, I wrote to the then Minister for Education in Victoria, Joan Kirner. I received a reply saying that she agreed with me that it should be made part of the core curriculum—that all children should have the benefit of history, should know the duties, responsibilities and rights of citizenship and should have the opportunity of finding out how they can take part in the political process. She said, `But I have Buckley's of getting it implemented. I am sorry to say that I would not get it through.' I hope that this, the third report, will be treated better and that this recommendation will now be implemented.

The other matter I wanted to raise in relation to this report concerns dual citizenship. I believe that generally speaking in the global community we are moving to a stage where nation states are diminishing in importance and where we more and more see ourselves as global citizens. In a sense, this is reflected in what is happening in Europe. We might soon, instead of having individual countries, have a united Europe. That is fine and welcome and probably would be a very constructive influence for achieving lasting peace and for economic matters, trade and so on.

However, there is one situation where dual citizenship could produce a problem: when, much to all our regret, a country gets involved in a conflict. If a person has dual citizenship, and it is a dual citizenship that implies or constitutes some allegiance to a country with which Australia may be in conflict, how is that resolved and would it be that, automatically, these people would be interned?

This leads me to the thought that, while we should allow people to enjoy the benefits of dual citizenship and the privileges this might offer in other countries, we should also, very importantly, make it quite clear that an Australian citizen, first and foremost, owes allegiance to Australia, that this must be the overriding commitment, and this is so because that was the last declaration of allegiance that was made by that person. I believe this concept will be discussed and debated in future. It is a sound development. Above all, we must be certain that we are building a national identity which depends on the commitment of all citizens to this country of ours—Australia.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Debate resumed from 13 October, on motion by Senator Margetts:
That the Senate take note of the report.

The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Childs)—The President was scheduled, in accordance with the provisions of the Audit Act 1901, to present the following report of the Auditor-General: Report No. 4 of 1994-95—Project Audit—Special Investigation into Casselden Place Building, Melbourne, Department of Administrative Services. Leave was granted for Senator O'Chee to table this report earlier this afternoon.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I thank the Senate for its indulgence. This is the report, of course, that reveals the scandal relating to the Casselden Place Building in Melbourne, where the federal Labor government has lost $103 million of taxpayers' money. This has been the subject of a return to order by the Senate earlier this day when Senator Bolkus, the Minister representing the Minister for Administrative Services, was required to table by 5.00 p.m. this day three specific documents referred to in section 9.78 of the Auditor-General's report.

PARA.TAB: As all honourable senators would be aware, it is now 10 minutes past six and these documents have not been tabled. So the Senate can quite rightly ask: why is the government continuing to seek to cover up this scandal in Melbourne? That is the question that all honourable senators should be asking this government.

Not only does this report reveal that the Minister for Administrative Services, the Hon. Frank Walker QC, misled this parliament by saying in a letter addressed to Senator McMullan and dated 4 May that no incentives were provided to the occupants of Casselden Place when the Auditor-General's report shows that incentives were offered, but it also proves that Senator McMullan misled the Senate and therefore the parliament when he reiterated the statement made by Mr Walker. Those two ministers are condemned for misleading this parliament.

They are further condemned for continuing the cover-up of a property scandal of the proportions of WA Inc. conducted under the auspices of a federal Labor government. It is probably appropriate that this scandal took place in the city of Melbourne at a time when Premier Cain and then Premier Kirner were in charge and were losing hundreds of millions of dollars a year of Victorian taxpayers' money.

The cover-up has now been further compounded by Senator Bolkus who, in responding to the motion that he be required to table these three letters—letters that have been cited and referred to by the Auditor-General in confirming that the department called these financial inducements incentives—said that we can pass the motion if we like but we should not count on getting the documents.

That is the contempt that Senator McMullan has for this chamber. It has been compounded by Senator Bolkus. It was also compounded by Mr Walker when he said that the Senate is not entitled to this information. It is a contempt of this parliament but, more importantly, it is a contempt of the people of Australia who expect that a federal government will not only run its operations on sound business principles but be accountable for the expenditure of taxpayers' money to the people through the parliament. This government has shown absolute contempt for the people of Australia in, firstly, wasting hundreds of millions of dollars in this case and, secondly, refusing to allow the Senate and the parliament of Australia to properly scrutinise the government's financial dealings.

In rising to speak about this report tonight I specifically want to say that Senator Bolkus stands condemned for not complying with the order of the Senate to table these three letters. This is a continuation of a cover-up of a multimillion dollar Australian Labor Party financial mismanagement scandal. These ministers have continued to defy orders of the Senate and have misled the parliament now on two or three occasions about, firstly, the size of the loss; secondly, whether incentives were involved—the Auditor-General said they were; and, thirdly, the dealings within the building. Senator McMullan said that those dealings were all commercial and were all at arm's length and there was nothing to worry about. This Senate has uncovered a multimillion dollar scandal involving the federal Labor government.

I believe we should take quite seriously the actions of a minister who misleads this parliament. It is now quite clear that both Mr Walker and Senator McMullan have misled the Senate on at least one occasion—quite possibly two. The Senate should regard the behaviour of these ministers as most serious breaches of their ministerial responsibility. Senator McMullan is away at the moment, so he cannot defend himself. But, when the Senate resumes in a fortnight's time, he should certainly be required to make an explanation as to, firstly, why he keeps continuing to cover up the scandal and, secondly, why he misled parliament.

Failing a proper explanation of these matters, I can see absolutely no reason why Senator McMullan and Mr Walker should not resign their positions as ministers. This should be regarded as a most serious breach of their responsibilities. Either they misled the Senate knowingly and, therefore, created what should be a hanging offence for a minister; or, if they did so unknowingly, they breached their ministerial responsibility because they certainly should have been responsible for the actions of their department—particularly bearing in mind that the Senate has raised these matters over a period of many months and all we have got as a response from the government is a covering up, just a continual refusal to table the documents.

TALK.START.PARA: —If you'll sit down, I'll table them. Is it a deal? Mr Acting Deputy President, I table the documents requested just a few moments ago.
