TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —I make this statement pursuant to the order of the Senate agreed to on 12 October 1994, which sought the tabling of nominated documents relating to the Australian National Line. This statement is further to my statement presented to the Senate on 17 October 1994.

PARA.TAB: A number of the documents sought contain commercially confidential and sensitive material relating to the businesses of third parties and/or ANL's current operations and business relationships. Release of these documents would be potentially prejudicial to the ongoing commercial operation of ANL and its business partners. Likewise, some documents contain records on the internal workings of government relating to confidential discussions on the privatisation process.

Given that ANL is now being restructured with a view to future sale and that this process is ongoing, release of some documents or parts of some documents at this stage before a sale is achieved is not viewed as consistent with the public interest. Accordingly, some documents have been withheld. Those documents to which exclusions have not been applied are tabled for the information of senators.

The documents sought and the government's responses are as follows. Firstly, minutes of all meetings between Asset Sales Task Force B and ANL management, meeting as the consultative committee. These have not been provided for the reasons outlined above. Secondly, minutes of all meetings between Mr George McGuiness, Managing Director of ANL, and task force B in relation to ANL as a going concern. No such minutes are held by the Department of Transport. Thirdly, a copy of the ANL management's critique of the Price Waterhouse/Salomon Brothers report. The Department of Transport does not have this document. Fourthly, all correspondence, file notes and internal memoranda between Mr McGuiness and the Secretary to the Department of Finance and the Secretary to the Department Transport between 1 January 1994 and 1 September 1994. Attachments to some of the correspondence sought have not been provided for the reasons outlined above. The Senate should be aware that the Department of Transport may not be in possession of all the documents sought.

Fifthly, ANL Chairman Mr William Bolitho's records of meetings with the Minister for Finance, the Minister for Transport and the secretaries to those departments between 1 January 1994 and 1 September 1994. Documents held by the Department of Transport are tabled. Sixthly, a copy of the brief or terms of reference given to Price Waterhouse/Salomon Brothers by the Asset Sales Task Force B. The Department of Transport holds copies of the draft requests for proposal issued by the task force on assets sales B for the business adviser and accountancy consultancies for the ANL due diligence process. These documents are tabled.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I thank the minister for his courtesy in sending me a copy of the document so that I could have a look at what he was going to table. I appreciate that. However, a lot of the documents which the Senate requested are not being tabled. The government is claiming commercial-in-confidence for a lot of the documents. I find this absolutely extraordinary. This is about a company—ANL—that the minister said on 22 August could not be given away. The Senate was seeking documents relating to the relationship between the minister and the company prior to 22 August. At that time the government's judgment was that the company could not be given away; that it was worthless. I fail to see why documents relating to a relationship between the minister and that company should not be tabled.

PARA.TAB: A couple of weeks ago we had correspondence between the minister and the company tabled. Those documents quite clearly show that there was a not very healthy relationship between the minister and the company. The minister's handling of this whole operation since early this year has been poor. That is why the Senate wanted to see the documents—to find out what had been going on. For the government to complain that these are commercial-in-confidence documents that will affect the operation of ANL, when it said on 22 August that the company was worth nothing and we wanted documents prior to then, does not make sense.

The Senate should note that in February this year the government changed the articles of association of this company, whereupon the government insisted that any decisions that affected the potential sale value of the company had to go through the minister. That meant that from February the minister was, in fact, in charge of the company and was directly responsible for what happened. The documents previously tabled clearly show that the minister was not responding to management, so there was a lot of responsibility lying on the minister's plate. He obviously was responsible for the poor shape of the company when he made the claim on 22 August that the company could not be given away. I express the strongest displeasure to the government for not tabling these documents in the Senate.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of Senator McKiernan I present the 14th report of the Standing Committee on Publications.

PARA.TAB: Report—by leave—adopted.

DEBATE.TITLE: EDUCATION SERVICES FOR OVERSEAS STUDENTS (REGISTRATION OF PROVIDERS AND FINANCIAL REGULATION) AMENDMENT BILL 1994

PARA.TAB: Consideration resumed.
Bill agreed to.
Bill reported without amendment; report adopted.
Bill (on motion by Senator Collins) read a third time.
Consideration resumed.
Clause 3

DEBATE.TITLE: ATSIC AMENDMENT (INDIGENOUS LAND CORPORATION AND LAND FUND) BILL 1994

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to speak to amendment No. 1 that has been moved by Senator Ellison to the ATSIC Amendment (Indigenous Land Corporation and Land Fund) Bill. Prior to the luncheon adjournment I said that it was noteworthy that the government had failed to include in the bill not only the objects of the legislation but also the principles of the legislation. I think it was Senator Campbell who pointed out that, in a judgment handed down in New South Wales, it became evident that the objects of the Native Title Act were quite important. That point needs to be noted: the government did not include in the bill the objects of the legislation, much less the principles of the legislation.

PARA.TAB: The question then arises as to whether the objects and the principles as proposed by Senator Ellison are to be supported, or whether the objects as outlined by Senator Kernot should be supported. At least the opposition, the Democrats, the Greens and I all believe that the objects of the legislation should be in the bill. I also happen to believe that the legislation should outline principles which should be adhered to. The government has indicated, through Senator Evans, that the major concern that it has is with new paragraph 191AB(b), which reads:

SPEECH.PARA: (b)if a conflict arises as to the allocation of resources, preference is to be given to those Aboriginal persons or Torres Strait Islanders who are most severely dispossessed of their traditional lands;

If we are going to have the objects as outlined in the opposition's amendment, it therefore follows logically that we should have some principles to be adhered to. The principle outlined in 191AB(b) seems to me to follow logically from the objects. I refer the Senate to the fact that the background of Senator Ellison's amendment states:

It is important to recognise that many Aboriginal persons and Torres Strait Islanders, because they have been dispossessed of their traditional lands, will be unable to assert meaningful title to those lands and that a special fund needs to be established to assist them to acquire land.

Correct me if I am wrong, but I think the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) stated something similar. I do not know whether it was in those precise terms, but he certainly stated something similar. He certainly used the words `dispossessed from their lands'. The next paragraph goes on:

Therefore, the object of this Part is to assist those dispossessed Aboriginal persons and Torres Strait Islanders to meet their economic, cultural and spiritual aspirations through the acquisition and management of land.
Those words also echo in my ears as not being original, but are understood and accepted by most of the community. The next paragraph indicates:

To give effect to that object, this Part establishes a fund, known as the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Land Fund, and a corporation, known as the Indigenous Land Corporation, to facilitate the acquisition and management of land for those Aboriginal persons and Torres Strait Islanders.

If we recognise the fact that, because Aboriginal persons have been dispossessed of their traditional lands, certain things flow in order to assist those dispossessed Aboriginal persons meet their economic, cultural and spiritual aspirations through acquisition and management of land, there should be no opposition, in principle, to meeting the economic, cultural and spiritual aspirations of those who have been most severely dispossessed.

PARA.TAB: If we are talking about the results of dispossession or if we are talking about assistance, as distinct from justice, then we really have to ask: who are those most in need? We hear this from the government all the time. It talks about those who are most in need. If we accept the objects proposed by Senator Ellison and Senator Kernot and if we accept that, because they have been dispossessed of their traditional lands, we need to meet their economic, cultural and spiritual aspirations, there seems to be no logical reason to oppose, in principle, the proposition contained in 191AB(b).

We then get to the practical situation. It has been put by the minister, and others, that this provision will cause untold delays and will eat into the already limited amounts that have been earmarked for the fund. It has been put to me by people, for whose views I have the utmost respect, that acceptance of the amendment would undoubtedly lead to irreconcilable conflict and division amongst Aboriginal communities and scarce resources having to be channelled into challenging and defending board decisions which would, in practice, also have the effect of paralysing the ILC.

I have to accept that that is a possibility but, in my view, that sort of possibility has to be put into the scales. The other scale contains the principle of social justice and the principle of natural justice. In my view, it comes down to those principles. If there are Aboriginal persons who are aggrieved by decisions of the ILC, surely they should have the assurance that the allocation of resources has some sort of priority; that those who have been most severely dispossessed of their traditional lands will get some sort of priority.

If, in the final analysis, after the bill has been passed and after the ILC has been in operation for some time, a situation of the nature that has been suggested arises, the parliament can revisit this matter. But the mere suggestion that these sorts of things may occur does not counterbalance the important principles of social justice—that is, giving priority to those most in need—and natural justice, which enables those persons in the ultimate to have some say about the prioritisation of resources. Under those circumstances, it is my view that the amendment moved by Senator Ellison and supported by the opposition and the Greens deserves the support of the Senate. I will be supporting that amendment.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have listened very carefully to what Senator Harradine has said. I understand very well what has led him to come to his conclusion. However, might I make one more attempt, using his own frame of reference and argument, to persuade him that maybe this just is not the better course to follow.

PARA.TAB: First of all, on the question of the basic principles and the logic, as it were, of having the clause expressed in these terms, might I just suggest that, when we look at the basic theme of the background provision in the objects clauses that we agree on, the reference is to assisting those who have been dispossessed as distinct from those who have not been dispossessed. That is the theme, the flavour, the language and the content of those clauses.

If you are translating the substance and effect of those clauses into the principles listed over the page, the logical transition is a principle expressed in the following terms: if a conflict arises as to the allocation of resources, preference is to be given to those who have been dispossessed rather than those who have not been dispossessed. That is as far as the logic of the language of the preamble goes. There is a logic in translating the language of the preamble into the language of principles, but the logic of the preamble only goes so far as to say `preference to the dispossessed'. As such, it is, in a sense, a reflection of the earlier debate that we had. If there is a choice between buying land for someone who might be able to establish a native title claim to it, who has maintained continuity of association and physical possession of it, if it is a choice between using land fund money for that purpose and using it for those who have been totally dispossessed and do not have any of that kind of relationship, there should not be a choice at all. There is no harm in the statute reflecting that. I suggest to Senator Harradine that that is as far as the logic takes him, in terms of his own chain of reasoning, if he wants to move from the language of the preambular objective to the language of principle.

We then come to the question of practicality and how this can be made to work in practice. Senator Harradine used the language `by comparison with those most in need', making the point that we are used to talking about those most in need. We are used to quantifying need; we are used to calibrating need; and, from a social justice perspective, so we should. Senator Harradine is saying that this is an analogue of that—that those who are most dispossessed should be given preference in exactly the same way as, in other social policy situations, we give preference to those who are most in need.

The difficulty that I would like to put to Senator Harradine and ask him to seriously consider is that the notion of dispossession is not quantitatively ascertainable in the same way as the concept of need is ascertainable. We all know how need can be calculated—by reference to income, by reference to assets and criteria of that objectively ascertainable kind. But how do we determine who is more dispossessed than someone else? How on earth do we begin to calculate that particular kind of equation? The basic distinction, logically and in practice, is really only between those who, on the one hand, have been dispossessed and those who, on the other hand, have not been dispossessed, who have maintained their association and relationship with a particular piece of land.

I suppose there are some criteria that one could begin to contemplate as applicable here. There could be the criterion of duration. A person could be more dispossessed if it is a longer period in time since his or her father, grandfather or other ancestors had that kind of possessory relationship with the land in question. I suppose that could be applied, but how does that translate into a social justice need? How do you say that someone who has been off the land for less than a generation is somehow less deserving than someone who has been off the land for three or four generations? I am not sure that there is a translation of the one concept to the other.

I suppose there could be a locational criterion. One could say that people out in the bush, in Moree or somewhere, are perhaps less dispossessed than people living in Redfern who have become totally absorbed in a city culture rather than in a rural culture which at least has some affinity or relationship with land, even if it is not the possessory relationship that was associated with original occupancy of the country. But it is a pretty tough criterion to apply to the fringe dwellers of Moree as compared with the urban dwellers of Redfern to say that the Moree people—I am just taking them as an example at random—have to miss out because in a conflict situation they are less dispossessed than people in Redfern.

This, I fear, is the kind of calculation that you are forced into if you put a principle in these terms in the legislation and make it justiciable in the way that this is. When you create the potential for the courts to wrestle with these sorts of problems, obviously you create all the problems that Senator Harradine adverted to that have been put to him about litigation, divisiveness, claims upon resources and so on.

If this were a clear-cut criterion, like the criterion of need, which was quantitatively ascertainable, applicable and calculable, then I would have a lot of difficulty in arguing with the way it has been put. The truth of the matter is that it ain't quantifiable in that way. It is a matter of impression. It is a matter of judgment. It is a matter of waiting around to determine what the courts are going to identify as the relevant criteria of dispossession. While we are waiting for the courts to tell us, one heck of a divisive environment will build up as people see the potential to argue their way through by using this particular clause.

It really is a very serious point that we are concerned about here. With every respect, knowing that we are about to plunge into an area of acute uncertainty and acute divisiveness, I do not think it is good enough to say that we can revisit this in one, two or three years time. From the outset, this legislation is going to get off on the wrong foot if we have this particular provision here.

I do not mind the other principles that are laid out there being set out in the way they are rather than in the way that Senator Kernot outlined. At the end of the day there is not an awful lot of significance to be attached to that, but there is a great deal of significance to be attached to this. I ask Senator Harradine, using exactly his own frame of reference and exactly his own chain of reasoning, perhaps to rethink his position on this.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to make an appeal to Senator Harradine too. With the best motivation, we or the majority of this Senate may make a mistake. I started at exactly the same point Senator Harradine is at now. I had proposed to take forward that form of amendment myself. But having spoken with some Aboriginal people—and I acknowledge it is not an inclusive list but neither is anybody else's who is contributing to this debate—I have come to the view that we are making a mistake to attempt to categorise dispossession.

PARA.TAB: In the hours since we adjourned this debate, I have had phone calls and a couple of faxes from Aboriginal people whom I do not know who seem to have found out we are doing on this matter and who are saying, `Please don't do this to us.' One of them said, `We cannot define dispossession in varying degrees, as dispossession is still 100 per cent dispossession'. I fear more though the divisiveness that exists. We can look at the case of ATSIC with its limited funding and we can see the divisions that are caused in communities when decisions have to be made. They are made on need and they are made genuinely, but we can already see the incredible amount of divisiveness that has come from this sort of process.

It really worries me that, in seeking to pass this amendment in this form, we are creating a capacity for an unnecessary layer of division in Aboriginal communities. We are adding a layer of divisive politicking which we can do without in Aboriginal communities. Goodness knows, it is hard enough at the moment with the limited amount of money that is supposed to address all their needs. I feel so strongly about this that I am going to register my view that we are making a mistake by calling a division. I give notice of that.

TALK.START.PARA: —One way through this is to suggest we defer the item to consider the points that have been raised and whether there are any other drafting options that might be available on further consideration that would meet some of Senator Harradine's concerns, but not plunge us into the tangle that I am concerned about.
—Twisting your arm, are they?

—You win some and you lose some in these sorts of debates. I am genuinely concerned that this could cut through and genuinely destroy what those of us of goodwill and good intention are trying to achieve with this legislation. It is not a matter of crude politicking.
—Is that a reflection on the rest of us?

—It is not meant to be a reflection on the rest of the committee, no. I am seeking the contribution of senators accordingly, perhaps by way of a deferral on this. I think the answer is clear-cut but if some further discussion could make it more easily resolvable, let us try that rather than try to bash it through in the next half hour.

—Everyone around this chamber will understand that over many years I have had a deep and abiding affection for and interest in the Aboriginal people. It goes back to my youth. If people want to know where I am coming from, I suggest they read the speech that I made at the time of the reconciliation vote in 1988. If they really want to know where I come from, let them read that.

PARA.TAB: I have been trying to look at this bill objectively by withdrawing myself from what I think Senator Kernot described as the layers of politics, though I am not ignorant of the fact that there are divisions. But when examining the objects of the legislation and the principles that are to be adhered to, one should approach the question on the basis of objectivity.

One might say that that is a foolish thing to do, that it is burying one's head in the sand and that it will ultimately mean undue divisions and irreconcilable conflicts. As I said, that may turn out to be the case, it may not; but that does not counterbalance the issues of social justice and natural justice.

The words that Senator Gareth Evans used when addressing the chamber seemed to be supporting what I was saying. He was saying that, if one makes some logical transition between the objects of the legislation and the principles to be adhered to, the transition relates only to those dispossessed and those not dispossessed.

I would have thought that it is, therefore, an a fortiori argument that it is between not only those dispossessed and those not dispossessed but that there also has to be some priority among those who have been dispossessed and those who are most severely dispossessed.

TALK.START.PARA: —What does that mean?

—That is a very good question. Senator Ellison, I think, made some comments about that. Somebody has to make the decision. If this is passed, the ILC will have to make the decision. I will tell Senator Evans what it might mean. If we look at this part of the legislation, it says that the object is to assist those dispossessed Aboriginal persons and Torres Strait Islanders to meet their economic, cultural and spiritual aspirations through the acquisition and management of land. That presupposes that somehow the economic, cultural and spiritual aspirations of those persons have been affected by dispossession. If those aspirations have been affected by dispossession, they have been affected more seriously by more serious dispossession.
—But what does more serious dispossession mean? Does it mean city versus country? Does it mean duration? What does it mean?

—What I am saying is that the qualification is in the economic, cultural and spiritual aspirations. It presupposes that dispossession of these Aboriginal persons has resulted in the damaging of their economic, cultural and spiritual aspirations.
—Are you to have a contest between my spiritual aspirations versus those of the guy down the road?

—Ultimately, there will be discussions as to how that has occurred and what the results have been. That then comes into the question of social justice. The government attends to those most in need all the time in legislation.
—Then you have clear-cut criteria.

—That is what this is saying. Otherwise, we do not have anything and do not attend to the problems of those most in need. I believe, in this particular case, that what Senator Ellison's amendment does is to require the ILC to adhere to that principle.

PARA.TAB: On the question of natural justice, if we do not have any principles, then it will be an arbitrary decision made by the ILC. Should we, as members of parliament, just agree that the ILC should make arbitrary decisions without regard to certain principles? Obviously, there are things that the ILC has to have regard to and they were mentioned by Senator Evans in his address to the chamber prior to lunch. They relate to various terms and conditions, financial questions, and so on. All of those things, by virtue of the particular provisions of the act, will need to be observed by the ILC.

For my part, I am voting for this particular measure on the grounds of social justice and natural justice. People who consider that they have more of a claim, if you like, on the fund—and bear in mind that this fund is established for people who are dispossessed under the native title legislation, and there may be two or three groups that have a claim to a particular piece of land—will have that claim decided on certain grounds. This ought to be decided on certain grounds, and I believe the proposal that has been put forward by the opposition and the Democrats at least requires this principle to be observed by the ILC.

Having done that, in accordance with the principles of natural justice, it would enable—because, as has been said, it is justiciable—those people who feel that they have a more appropriate claim to the funds to seek, in the first instance presumably from the ILC, the basis for its decision and, in the final instance—and I hope it does not occur very often—would enable them to go to court to have their view on this particular principle tested.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not want to unduly delay the Senate, but it seems to me that quite fundamental errors are in danger of being perpetrated here simply because we are not stopping and giving enough thought to the sheer practical difficulty of defining in a non-arbitrary way what it is to be more dispossessed than someone else. It seems to me that there is a clear-cut distinction between those who are dispossessed and those who have not been dispossessed, which we can all readily understand. But once we start getting into the business of drawing distinctions between those who are more and less dispossessed, then we are inevitably back in the realm of a centrally arbitrary choice because there are no obvious criteria that one can point to.

PARA.TAB: Senator Harradine pointed to the language of the preamble in terms of economic, cultural and spiritual aspirations and suggested that might be an appropriate touchstone and that we measure the degree of dispossession by the measure of economic, cultural and spiritual aspirations which have somehow accumulated as a result of the severance of a person's connection with the land. But how on earth does that work in practice? How does it serve the end of social justice, to define it in those terms?

Most Aboriginal people, as we all know, in Australia live in urban areas. They are unequivocally dispossessed in the sense that their forefathers of long ago lost their links with their traditional land. I do not know how we can measure their economic, spiritual and cultural aspirations. There are ways of measuring their level of attainment. By and large, people living in urban areas have far greater economic opportunities and socioeconomic status than their fellow Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people living in remote parts of Australia. The urban people might be more dispossessed, but in many ways they have many more opportunities for social advancement such as higher status, recognition and self-esteem.

How on earth does one say that the cause of social justice is better advanced by giving the nod to them in a conflict situation? Unless we can define it with some precision and clarity in the way that the concept of need can be defined with a degree of precision and clarity, it honestly seems to me that it is an almost impossible task that we are vesting in the corporation and in the courts. As a result, we are giving aid, comfort and encouragement to those who are going to be only too keen to take advantage of every bit of uncertainty that has a litigious quality about it to test the water.

That is the reality of the situation as we know it. I cannot put the case any differently or any other way, but I do ask Senator Harradine to use his own criterion of social justice, which I fully and absolutely share. I know where he is coming from; I share that particular starting point. It is just that when we translate that into the terms of this particular legislation, I do not think we get there for the reasons that I have tried to spell out.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I find it odd. Here is the minister saying that it is so difficult to determine how people have been affected in economic, cultural and spiritual aspiration ways, but the whole point about it is that the minister himself is going to vote for the very thing. In Senator Kernot's amendment it says precisely that. Senator Kernot's amendment, to be supported by the government, states:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . the principal object of this Part is to assist those dispossessed Aboriginal persons and Torres Strait Islanders to meet their economic, cultural and spiritual aspirations, and to further their capacity for self-determination, through the acquisition and management of the land.

We are taking about economic, cultural and spiritual aspirations, and we have to realise that the government is going to vote for this amendment. The ILC will have to make some sort of assessment of that. That function will be there so it will have to make that assessment.

PARA.TAB: As Senator Kernot says, they have not gone that extra step about the most disposessed. If they are going to have to define the situation in the ILC, after they define it they will have to look at that when they are considering who is, therefore, most dispossessed.

We get down to the final analysis—the fear. I understand this. I am not altogether ignorant of the internal politics of the situation. I understand that that could be a result. But if it is the result, if it has clogged things up so much that there are irreconcilable differences and if there is enormous litigation on this matter, then we can reconsider the matter. There can be amendments and so on.

I come back to the point that I am voting for this amendment not only because of the question of social justice but also because of the question of natural justice. Senator Evans said, `You are just taking an arbitrary approach'. He is saying that this is arbitrary, but his approach would be open slather arbitrary. At least we are setting down principles. If there are no principles, then the ILC acts in a completely arbitrary fashion. As Senator Evans said, there is nothing much more to say about this at this stage. The proof of the pudding will be in the eating, I suppose.
Question put:
That the amendment (Sen Ellison's) be agreed to.
Question so resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ellison Sen C.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (2)Clause 3, page 3, line 8, at end of proposed section 191B, add "in accordance with the object of this Part".

This amendment is consequential on amendment No. 1. It provides that in section 191 there is implementation `in accordance with the object of this Part'. It is fairly self-evident that this is a necessary drafting provision which flows from the passing of amendment No. 1. I do not think I need to waste the time of the Senate, unless there are any further queries.

TALK.START.PARA: —It would help the practical applicability of this if Senator Ellison were prepared to say not so much `in accordance with the object of this Part' but `in furtherance of the object of this Part'. Does that sound a reasonable drafting suggestion?
—I think so, yes.
—I move:

PARA.TAB: Omit "accordance with"
Substitute "furtherance of"
Amendment (Senator Gareth Evans's) agreed to.
Amendment, as amended, agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chamarette Sen C.M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Deputy Chairman, is it possible for the Greens to go first with the next series of amendments, with Senator Ellison's approval? We regard the opposition's amendments and ours as virtually interchangeable, with the exception of opposition amendment No. 50, which the Greens are not supporting, and our proposed amendment F9. I believe the government will be supporting our definition of a trust in amendment F9. With the opposition's permission, I request that we go first.
—I agree with that. Perhaps we could proceed on that basis this evening and also when we return to continue.

—I thank Senator Ellison. Amendments F1 to F9 relate to Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander corporations. Under the bill, the ILC can carry out its land acquisition functions only for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander corporations. The Greens (WA) believe that Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people should be able to own land as they see fit and that the bill is far too restrictive on this issue. Acquired interests in land may be granted to Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander corporations, Aboriginal persons, Torres Strait Islanders or trustees of Aboriginal or Torres Strait Islander trusts in the amendments that we are putting forward and I understand this is almost identical to the amendments of the opposition. We believe that Aboriginal people and Torres Strait Islanders should be treated like other citizens and be allowed to hold their land as they see fit. We believe it is an act of paternalism to do otherwise. I move:

SPEECH.PARA: F1.Clause 3, page 3, proposed subsection 191D (1), lines 19 to 31, omit the subsection, substitute the following subsection:

PARA.TAB: " `191D.(1) The land acquisition functions of the Indigenous Land Corporation are as follows:

SPEECH.PARA: (a)to grant interests in land to:
(i)Aboriginal or Torres Strait Islander corporations; or
(ii)Aboriginal persons; or
(iii)Torres Strait Islanders; or
(iv)trustees of Aboriginal or Torres Strait Islander trusts;
(b)to acquire by agreement interests in land for the purpose of making grants under paragraph (a);
(c)to make grants of money to:
(i)Aboriginal or Torres Strait Islander corporations; or
(ii)Aboriginal persons; or
(iii)Torres Strait Islanders; or
(iv)trustees of Aboriginal or Torres Strait Islander trusts; or
for the acquisition of interests in land;
(d)to guarantee loans made to:
(i)Aboriginal or Torres Strait Islander corporations; or
(ii)Aboriginal persons; or
(iii)Torres Strait Islanders; or
(iv)trustees of Aboriginal or Torres Strait Islander trusts; or
for the purpose of the acquisition of interests in land.'
Note 1 :"Interest in land" is defined by section 4.
Note 2 :"Aboriginal or Torres Strait Islander corporation" is defined by section 4.
Note 3 :"Aboriginal or Torres Strait Islander trust" is defined by section 4.".
Clause 3, page 4, proposed paragraphs 191D(3) (a) and (b), lines 1 to 14, omit the paragraphs, substitute the following paragraphs:
"(a)pursuing a policy of:
(i)acquiring interests in land and granting the interests to:
(A)Aboriginal or Torres Strait Islander corporations; or
(B)Aboriginal persons; or
(C)Torres Strait Islanders; or
(D)trustees of Aboriginal or Torres Strait Islander trusts; or
(ii)in cases where the Indigenous Land Corporation grants money to:
(A)Aboriginal or Torres Strait Islander corporations; or
(B)Aboriginal persons; or
(C)Torres Strait Islanders; or
(D)trustees of Aboriginal or Torres Strait Islander trusts;
for the acquisition of interests land—acting in in as the agent of the relevant corporations or persons in connection with those acquisitions;

PARA.TAB: except where the circumstances make the pursuit of such a policy impracticable or inadvisable;

SPEECH.PARA: (b)in a case where the Indigenous Land Corporation acquires an interest in land for the purpose of making a grant of the interest to:
(i)Aboriginal or Torres Strait Islander corporations; or
(ii)Aboriginal persons; or
(iii)Torres Strait Islanders; or

PARA.TAB: (iv)trustees of Aboriginal or Torres Strait Islander trusts; or that grant being made as soon as is practicable after that acquisition.".

SPEECH.PARA: Clause 3, page 9, proposed paragraph 191J(1) (b), lines 28 to 32, omit the paragraph, substitute the following paragraph:

PARA.TAB: "(b)the Indigenous Land Corporation or the subsidiary as the case requires, considers that it no longer needs to hold the interest for the purpose of making a grant of the interest to:
(i)an Aboriginal or Torres Strait Islander corporation; or
(ii)an Aboriginal person; or
(iii)a Torres Strait Islander; or
(iv)a trustee of an Aboriginal or Torres Strait Islander trust;
within a reasonable time after that acquisition.".

SPEECH.PARA: Clause 3, page 10, proposed paragraph 191N(2) (a), lines 29 and 30, omit the paragraph, substitute the following paragraph:

PARA.TAB: "(a)the acquisition of interests in land for the purpose of making grants of those interests to:
(i)Aboriginal or Torres Strait Islander corporations; or
(ii)an Aboriginal person; or
(iii)a Torres Strait Islander; or
(iv)a trustee of an Aboriginal or Torres Strait Islander trust".

SPEECH.PARA: Clause 3, page 11, proposed paragraph 191P(4) (a), omit the paragraph, substitute the following paragraph:

PARA.TAB: "(a)the acquisition of interests in land in the regional area for the purpose of making grants of those interests to:
(i)Aboriginal or Torres Strait Islander corporations; or
(ii)Aboriginal persons; or
(iii)Torres Strait Islanders; or
(iv)trustees of Aboriginal or Torres Strait Islander trusts;".

SPEECH.PARA: Clause 3, pages 12 and 13, proposed section 191S, line 33 (page 12) to line 33 (page 13), omit "body corporate" (wherever occurring), substitute "person".
Clause 3, pages 13 and 14, proposed section 191T, line 34 (page 13) to line 21 (page 14), omit "body corporate" (wherever occurring), substitute "person".
Clause 3, page 14, proposed subsection 191U(1), lines 24 to 39, omit "body corporate" (wherever occurring), substitute "person".

TALK.START.PARA: —The government opposes these amendments. It is an issue to which we have given a lot of serious consideration. At the end of the day, the government finishes with the position from which we started; that is, that the very nature of traditional Aboriginal title, Aboriginal concept of ownership, has always been communal in character.

PARA.TAB: When trying to do something to redress centuries of dispossession, both material and spiritual, and trying to recreate not simply an economic base for people who have been denied it but a base for recapturing some pride, dignity and spiritual reaffirmation of values of land ownership and so on, it is important so far as possible to get back to the core concepts of ownership which are part and parcel of the Aboriginal tradition. Those core concepts are unequivocally and unquestionably communal rather than individual in character.

There is the further consideration that what we are trying to do is provide genuine benefits to communities rather than to individuals. There are an awful lot of individuals whose needs one wants to attend to and assist and, of course, all the welfare programs—health, education, housing and so on—are very much geared to individuals as well as to groups and communities. In the particular context of what this legislation is all about, the primary focus, thrust and direction is towards trying to recreate, or help recreate, a sense of community and respond to community needs rather than individual needs.
The TEMPORARY CHAIRMAN (Senator Chapman)—Order! It being 7.20 p.m., according to sessional order, I shall report progress.
Progress reported.
The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Childs)—Order! It being 7.20 p.m., I put the question:
That the Senate do now adjourn.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tonight I would like to speak about Prime Minister Keating's `phoney feminism' and its alleged benefits to the political process. The recent motion to create a quota of 35 per cent of candidates to be preselected in `winnable' Labour Party seats has been celebrated by many community groups but, most notably, by ALP women.

PARA.TAB: Any proposal to get more women into parliament at both state and federal levels should be applauded and, more importantly, acted upon. We desperately need to break down the barriers which prevent 51 per cent of the voting population from gaining appropriate parliamentary representation, from helping to shape our society, from improving legislation and from acting as representative voices for the communities they represent.

The real sadness in all of this, of course, is that Paul Keating, our Prime Minister, has failed to see—or chosen to ignore the reality—where these barriers to entering parliament are. He has made loud, self-congratulatory noises—the media and other interest groups have swallowed them—about removing barriers within the preselection process, a place where there are few, if any, real barriers to be removed. Perhaps he has done so to suit his own purposes, but certainly within the Liberal Party there are really no barriers to women within that preselection process itself. If a woman stands and has merit, she is, in 1994, just as likely, if not more likely, to gain successful preselection from a group of candidates.

Liberal preselectors are urged to preselect a woman, and have been doing so for some years now. Much of this has been due to a number of Liberal women who have worked tirelessly towards achieving equality of opportunities for women. In particular, I mention Chris McDiven, who is an example, both of herself and in her achievements, of what the ALP should be trying to emulate.

It is a sad reflection of ALP preselectors that they are lagging behind the other parties in affirmative action for preselection of candidates; and sadder still that they need a compulsory quota and not just an active reminder to achieve this. Paul Keating is removing the wrong barriers. I say to Mr Keating: preselection is not where those real barriers to women are. The real barriers are those factors which keep women from even entering the preselection process in the first place. The barriers are often socioeconomic and relate strongly to women usually being the prime child carer within a family unit.

The barriers which exist for potential women candidates without children are similar to those preventing many men entering politics: there is no job security, the hours are often long, overtime is often relentless and unpaid, the job satisfaction is low and, for many, the travel, particularly to Canberra, can be prohibitive. But where a woman is the main child carer, the barriers to entering politics, particularly at a federal level, are overwhelming.

Federal politicians often have very limited time with their children, reducing their involvement with child rearing, since even evenings and weekends are often occupied with community and party functions, even when parliament is not sitting. I commend the federal parliament and the New South Wales state parliament for the changes to the sitting hours, such that politicians of either gender can have something approaching a more normal family life.

All this applies to a man who is the primary child carer, and this group in our community should not be overlooked. In addition, of course, it should be acknowledged that even where a parent is not the prime carer, that person does miss out on family life by entering politics.

So, you see, Paul Keating is removing the wrong barriers and, worse, he imagines that those barriers are there only for women. The quota system he is introducing is an artifice. He does nothing to improve the journey of women who enter politics. Quotas themselves mean that preselection may not be on merit, and that in itself is demeaning and insulting to women. Real equality is a long way off but we are going towards it. Do not let us go for the short-term goal of phoney equality because the community would always wonder whether a woman had been preselected simply by virtue of her gender. That would further erode the very slim confidence people have in their parliamentary representatives.

Liberal philosophy has always been one of equality of opportunity, regardless of race, age, socioeconomic class or—relevantly here—gender. Clearly, we need to make sure that, in whatever walk of life she chooses, a woman has the same options and opportunities as her male counterpart. Those are the attitudes which will also blast away the so-called glass ceiling.

There is another significant problem to be addressed—a problem largely of the Prime Minister's own making—which deters women, and also a large number of men, with all the qualities for public life from seeking a parliamentary career. That is the contempt—that is not too strong a word—in which many politicians are held, largely as a result of the gratuitous personal denigration, gutter language and general poor behaviour exhibited by our joke of a Prime Minister. As I understand it, our personal responsibility ratings are now sinking to the same level as that of the reptiles of the press.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I raise a point of order. Senator Woods said `joke of a Prime Minister'. The senator knows full well that standing orders preclude reflections that extreme, in terms of the toing and froing that goes on here, on members of the other House. I ask him to withdraw that comment.
—I would ask that you withdraw it, Senator Woods.
—I will withdraw it and I will try to keep a straight face.
—You will withdraw it unconditionally.

—I withdraw it. Of course, this is a deterrent to women and men, and is a single-handed achievement—if that is the right word—on the part of our Prime Minister. What needs to be done is not the ALP's tokenism but real action. Providing appropriate child-care facilities and other support, such as changes to the taxation system so there is genuine support for families, would give women a genuine choice of whether they go to work or not.

PARA.TAB: This could be achieved through income splitting or any one of several other options. The option itself is not crucial but it is vital that something real be done to overcome what are real barriers preventing many people—men and women—from moving into public life. The ALP's puny and insulting stunt—an artificial quota for women—is not the answer. Without that quota—but by actively seeking quality candidates for preselection—the non-Labor parties will soon have 50 per cent female representation. That will be achieved on merit and without recourse to the phoney and patronising form of alleged feminism. That will be the ultimate triumph—a system where real equality does exist and where merit alone is the basis for entry into public life.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Woodley Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise tonight to speak on a matter to do with the report of the Senate Select Committee on Whistleblowing. I am not going to speak for very long but I want to table some documents which I delivered today to Senator Bolkus, representing the Attorney-General (Mr Lavarch), and Senator Vanstone. I have further copies here for the chamber.

PARA.TAB: It is an issue which, I believe, continues unresolved within my own state of Queensland. I note that yesterday Senator Jocelyn Newman tabled a letter from the Queensland Premier which answered some of the concerns of the Senate Select Committee on Whistleblowing. I would like to quote from the Premier's letter because I believe it raises a very important issue. In his letter the Premier says:

SPEECH.PARA: In respect of allegations raised by Mr Lindeberg concerning the lawfulness of redundancy payments made to Mr Coyne by the Department of Family Services and Aboriginal and Islander Affairs, and the lawfulness of the destruction of documents relating to the Heiner Inquiry, the CJC concluded that there was no official misconduct involved.

I believe that the Senate Select Committee on Whistleblowing was correct when it pointed out to the Queensland government that there were apparently unresolved whistleblower cases in Queensland. I believe that one of the problems has been that much of the documentation available both to the Queensland government and to the CJC has not been considered.

PARA.TAB: The Senate select committee did have some of that documentation before it. In fact, when the Premier says that there was no official misconduct involved, I believe that some of the documentation has not been considered, and that is the best construction I can put upon that particular paragraph within his letter. I will be seeking to table a number of documents which I believe the Senate needs to have before it and to have on the public record.

These documents include a transcript of a radio interview between Mr Lindeberg and Haydn Sargent on ABC radio in Brisbane which contains, I believe, an update of the issue that was the subject of concern of the Senate Select Committee on Whistleblowing, and that is why that document needs to be on the public record. There is also a letter from Mr Lindeberg to the police commissioner which includes an attachment which is the agenda of a meeting held on 12 October. This letter raises matters with the police commissioner, who is in the process of conducting a further inquiry into possible criminal offences, and simply transfers to the police commissioner further information. I do not believe it prejudices the inquiry in any way but simply gives to the Senate information which assists its inquiry. There is also a letter from the Attorney-General to Mr Lindeberg about an FOI request which he has, and his reply to the Attorney-General. I seek leave of the Senate to table those documents.
Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —The other day in this place Senator Spindler raised a matter in relation to a part-time Comcar driver, Mr Dennis Reid. I thought it appropriate to make sure that the facts in this matter were very clear. Mr Reid did in fact write a letter to the paper in Queanbeyan, which letter was critical of me. That is nothing new, because I get a lot of that correspondence myself. Occasionally I see it put in the paper, and that is part of the democratic process.

PARA.TAB: Unfortunately, Senator Spindler misses the point. The point about Mr Reid is not a point of free speech; it is a matter of trust. Comcar drivers perform a particular role which requires a high degree of trust. All of us in this place and in the other place would understand that, or at least I would hope they would understand that. Comcar drivers, by virtue of their occupation, are privy to all sorts of conversations, both on the telephone and between members of parliament or members of parliament and their staff.

The difficulty I have with Mr Reid is that I can no longer trust that what he hears in a car in which I am present will remain private and secret. That is the great difficulty and the difficulty I outlined to Comcar administration from the very start.

I did not raise this matter with Comcar to attack Mr Reid. I have a very real concern that this man does not understand the particular position of trust in which he is placed. By his actions he has shown that he is willing to be partisan in a public forum. I do not believe that I can sit in a car which Mr Reid is driving and have a conversation with one of my colleagues secure in the knowledge that that conversation will not be repeated outside the car.

Lest Senator Spindler or anybody else is under some misapprehension that this is some sort of party political attack on Mr Reid, let me make it very clear: I know many Comcar drivers in Canberra and Brisbane very well. Many of them, I know, are members of the Labor Party. Some of them, with whom I get on very well, are branch officials of the Labor Party, but that is not an impediment. They adhere to a very strict rule that whatever they hear in the car is absolutely confidential, and they do not make a habit of going public about their view on this, that or the other.

In Mr Reid's case, that has not been adhered to. I know that many Comcar drivers, particularly the permanent Comcar drivers, are absolutely disgusted with Mr Reid's behaviour. The indications of support I have had about this from permanent Comcar drivers would, quite simply, astound Senator Spindler if I were to be so indiscreet as to outline them. I do not intend to do that because I intend to observe the same sort of trust and privacy which I expect Comcar drivers to observe.

Let me make it very clear that Mr Reid's behaviour is thoroughly unacceptable. What is more, it makes it very difficult for any National Party member or senator to sit in a car which Mr Reid is driving and have any confidence that what is heard or said in that car will remain confidential. That is the grave difficulty which I have and which some of my colleagues have with Mr Reid performing the functions of a Comcar driver. It is more than Senator Spindler merely running off and saying that it is a matter of free speech. It is not a matter of free speech; it is a matter of being trustworthy and being seen to be trustworthy.

Not only were Mr Reid's comments in the paper erroneous and frivolous; they showed that he could not display that he was a trustworthy individual. That was what disappointed me. I think the standards of conduct that we expect of Comcar drivers are no higher than the standards of conduct that we expect and receive from many of the parliamentary servants who work in this building, be they chamber attendants, attendants in the corridors, clerks or staff in the Black Rod's Office or other people who serve us very loyally.

That is the standard that must apply. Mr Reid has shown that he cannot abide by that standard of conduct. That is why I made the complaint, that is why I believe that the complaint is correct and that is why I would have grave reservations about Mr Reid continuing in his employment as a Comcar driver. Certainly I would not hop into a car if he were behind the wheel.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The government, in its enthusiastic rush to republicanism and in expressing its anti-British bias, has apparently decided that British pioneers of our nation are no longer acceptable for recognition. To establish this, I refer to a letter from the Minister for Defence, Senator Robert Ray, in reply to a request from the Illawarra Historical Society to have the navy's new hydrographic office in Wollongong named the Matthew Flinders Building. The Senate will be well aware of the fact that Matthew Flinders did have some role in establishing what the coast of New South Wales was like, apart from anything else.
—Tom Thumb, wasn't it?

—Two hundred years ago, in 1796, Matthew Flinders and George Bass sailed in a very small boat, the Tom Thumb. They landed at Towradgi, just near Wollongong, and after some time there are said to have spent the night on the leeside of Windang Island at the entry to Lake Illawarra. The Illawarra Historical Society was hoping to celebrate that occasion in a couple of years time because it does represent 200 years of European settlement in the Illawarra. That voyage was significant, too, in terms of the discovery of coal because on that voyage Bass and Flinders observed coal sticking out of the escarpment.

PARA.TAB: Unfortunately, the request that such a renowned figure in maritime history should be remembered by having the hydrographic office in Wollongong named after him was much too offensive to the republican push for it to be acceptable. The response from the Minister for Defence has been that this matter has been discussed with the Hydrographer RAN, who has advised that there are currently no plans to name the building, which will be identified simply as the Australian Hydrographic Office, Royal Australian Navy. But Senator Ray then adds:

SPEECH.PARA: However, should consideration be given in the future to the naming of this building, in accordance with current policy the name selected will be more appropriately that of an Australian who has made a significant contribution to the knowledge of our maritime environment.

So poor Matthew Flinders does not rate because he was a Pom. I have never heard anything more absurd. This is taking republicanism ad absurdum. Because Flinders was an Englishman, he cannot be recognised. I am one of the millions of Australians who are very proud of their British heritage. My late mother was English—although I must say that she did not support an England cricket team unless it had a Yorkshireman in it.

TALK.START.PARA: —Quite right.

—That is right, even though I have a continental European name. The fact is that a policy decision that Matthew Flinders cannot be recognised because he was not an Australian is an affront to the great bulk of Australians who are proud of their British heritage. I do not know what the republicanism push is all about if this is the petty way it reflects itself. Surely the government can do it a little better than that.

PARA.TAB: I want very briefly to mention another matter which relates to the response Senator Gareth Evans gave me on Monday about the $2.2 million mansion of the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) which he intends to lease out for rent in order to pay the enormous mortgage bill that he will face. As the Senate is aware, I am planning to put a motion before the Senate in respect of that principle of prime ministers being required to answer to somebody for actions of that kind. Senator Evans said:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . it is perfectly reasonable to anticipate this particular transaction—
that is, the purchase of the $2.2 million house—
being paid for with the sale of his existing Elizabeth Bay Road property, which is worth in the order of $1 1/2 million as a result of the upgrading that has been done to it.

That is Senator Evans's assurance to us. He is telling the Australian people, `Do not worry. The Prime Minister won't go massively into debt. He will make $1 1/2 million selling the property because of the upgrading that has been done.' That is not upgrading that has to be done; it has been done. Laurie Oakes, who obviously finds it impossible to recognise that there is a matter of principle involved in this, said:
The property owned by Prime Minister Keating in Elizabeth Bay is worth at least half of what he has signed up to pay for the new residence.
That is the $2.2 million residence. In other words, Oakes says it is worth at least $1.1 million and Senator Evans says $1 1/2 million.

PARA.TAB: That is curious because the property two doors away recently sold for $750,000 and certainly its exterior condition is better than that of Mr Keating's property. In October 1993, the property next door sold for $660,000. I do not know how Senator Gareth Evans thinks that the recent sale of a property identical to Mr Keating's for $750,000 will magically double the price of Mr Keating's property because of what he has done to it. The $1 1/2 million Mr Keating is hoping to get for his property sounds like some sort of mates price again.

Quite frankly, I think the real estate industry would be very interested to know how one could acquire such kindly benevolent purchasers who are so far out of line with the price of properties that are very similar or near identical. In a speech he made on 17 October, Senator Gareth Evans assured us that:

SPEECH.PARA: Mr Keating knows enough about the property market in Sydney to be able to make his own judgments about these things and about the affordability of this particular transaction.

That is fine. If Senator Gareth Evans is relying on Mr Keating's information about the property market, maybe he has the expectation that, because of the government's policies over the next few years, inflation is going to be so enormous that that kind of upward rush in housing prices may well take place. Maybe the Reserve Bank is correct in pressing for an increase in interest rates if the Prime Minister's own actions indicate that he is of the view that there will be a huge surge in housing prices.

PARA.TAB: I might remind those who have been saying that if the Prime Minister spends more on his house on Elizabeth Bay Road it may well sell for more than $1.1 million, that that would involve the actual expenditure of money and, presumably, the Prime Minister would have to get that money from somewhere. So in effect it does not make any net difference to the ultimate cost to him of his $2.2 million mansion. If people really want to try to defend the Prime Minister on this matter, it would be a good idea if they stopped relying on hyperbole and wishful thinking and just looked at what sorts of prices this kind of property has actually been sold for.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kemp Sen C.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yesterday I dealt with a matter of public interest which dealt with a wide variety of issues concerning the review announced by the Hon. Frank Walker, QC into the Australian honours system. In the course of those remarks I quoted from an article in the Canberra Times of Saturday 15 October, which reported that the chair of the inquiry, Ms Claire Petre, was a member of the Hon. Frank Walker's staff when he was Attorney-General in New South Wales. The article states:

PARA.TAB: The Minister for Administrative Services, Frank Walker, announced yesterday that a review committee of eight members is to be chaired by Clare Petre, a senior officer in the NSW Community Services Commission. Ms Petre is a board member of the Administrative Review Council and has previously worked in journalism, in social service and on Mr Walker's staff when he was NSW Attorney-General.

SPEECH.PARA: This statement was not challenged by Mr Walker or anybody else. Four days after that article appeared, on Wednesday, 19 October, I mentioned that, inter alia, we had to read about Claire Petre being a former member of Mr Walker's staff in the Canberra Times.

PARA.TAB: Mr Walker has informed me that this is not the case. I am happy to accept his advice, but it is a pity that Mr Walker, assisted by his

SPEECH.PARA: large staffing resources, was not faster off the mark to correct the article in the Canberra Times when the matter first arose. In this way, the error could have been avoided. I checked with the Canberra Times today and it has confirmed that no effort was made to correct the statement made in the Saturday report to which I referred. In my remarks on the matter of public interest relating to the Australian honours system, I raised a wide range of issues and I look forward to Mr Walker and the committee starting to address them.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Senate adjourned at 7.50 p.m. until Monday, 7 November 1994 at 2.00 p.m.

PARA.TAB: The following documents were tabled:

PROCTEXT.PARA: Australian National University Act—Statutes—Nos 233-235.
The following answers to questions were circulated:

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Foreign Affairs: Grants to Trade Unions or Community Groups

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs, on notice, on 24 August 1994:

PARA.TAB: (1) Has the department, or any of its agencies or statutory authorities, approved or made available any grants, or other forms of payments, to trade unions or community groups in the 1993-94 financial year; if so, in each case: (a) what is the name and address of the trade union or community group which received the funds; (b) what was the amount involved; (c) what was the purpose of the payment; (d) under what program was the payment; (e) who approved the payment; and (f) what acquittal requirements are there pertaining to the payment, and are there any outstanding acquittals.

(2) Has the department, or any of its agencies or statutory authorities, approved, made available, or does it intend to make available, any grants, or any other forms of payments, to trade unions or community groups in the 1994-95 financial year; if so, in each case, please provide details as per (1)(a) to (f).

In relation to the Australian International Development Assistance Bureau, my colleague, the Minister for Development Cooperation and Pacific Affairs, has provided me with the following answer to the honourable senator's questions:

"In relation to question 1 (a) to (d) details of all direct payments made in 1993-94 to Non Government Organisations (NGOs) under the aid vote are provided in the 1994 AIDAB NGO Cooperation Annual Report. This report is released at the Annual AIDAB/NGO Consultations held in September each year. Guidelines on the programs listed in the report are publicly available.

In relation to questions 1 (e)—(f) and 2 (a)—(f), information in respect of the matters referred to in the honourable senator's question is not readily available. To collect and assemble it would be a major task and I am not prepared to authorise the expenditure of money and effort involved in assembling such information."
In relation to the Australian Trade Commission my colleague, the Minister for Trade, has provided me with the following answer to the honourable senator's questions:
"Austrade has not approved or made available payments to trade unions or community groups in the 1993/94 financial year.
Austrade does not intend to make available any grants or other forms of payments to trade unions or community groups in the 1994-95 financial year."

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Grants to Trade Unions and Community Groups

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs, upon notice, on 24 August 1994

PARA.TAB: (1) Has the department, or any of its agencies or statutory authorities, approved or made available any grants, or other forms of payments, to trade unions or community groups in the 1993-94 financial year; if so, in each case: (a) what is the name and address of the trade union or community group which received the funds; (b) what was the amount involved; (c) what was the purpose of the payment; (d) under what program was the payment made; (e) who approved the payment; and (f) what acquittal requirements are there pertaining to the payment, and are there any outstanding acquittals.

(2) Has the department, or any of its agencies or statutory authorities, approved, made available, or does it intend to make available, any grants, or other forms of payments, to trade unions or community groups in the 1994-95 financial year; if so, in each case, please provide details as per (1) (a) to (f).

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am advised that the answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) (a) (b) Details for 1993-94 and information about each scheme/program are listed below, as follows:
List 1 provides the names and addresses of grant recipients under the Grant-in-Aid (GIA) scheme.
List 2 provides the annual value of grants under the Grant-in-Aid (GIA) scheme.

List 3 provides the names and addresses of grant recipients, brief descriptions of projects, the value and date of expiry of grants awarded under the Migrant Access Projects Scheme (MAPS) and three Special grants.
List 4 provides the names and addresses of Migrant Resource Centres (MRCs).
List 5 provides the amounts of core funding provided to MRCs covering the period 1 October 1993 to 30 September 1994.
List 6 provides names and addresses of grant recipients and the value of grants awarded under the Immigration Advisory Services Scheme (IASS).
There were, however, a number of payments not included within a specific scheme or program. These are detailed in List 11 below.

(c) Funding is either for operational purposes—involving salary and associated costs of a worker(s)—to implement a program of settlement assistance (eg GIA, MRC) or for specific projects, negotiated with the Department (eg MAPS, Special grants). Further details are shown under each grant heading below.
There were, however, a number of payments not included within a specific scheme or program. These are detailed in List 11 below.
(d) In 1993-94, the Department made grants/payments under the following schemes/programs:
.GIA scheme
.MAPS (major and minor projects)
.MRC program
.Special grants
.IASS
.CRSS
.Committee for the Allocation of Loan Funds to Refugees in Centres (CALFRIC) Ltd administrative grant.
There were, however, a number of payments not included within a specific scheme or program. These are detailed in List 11 below.

(e) I awarded Special grants and grants under the GIA, MAPS, MRC and IASS schemes. Departmental officers, acting pursuant to authority delegated to them by me, approved payments to eligible CRSS support groups and the administrative grant to CALFRIC Ltd.
There were, however, a number of payments not included within a specific scheme or program. These are detailed in List 11 below.
(f) Acquittal requirements are set out below under the respective scheme.
There were, however, a number of payments not included within a specific scheme or program. These are detailed in List 11 below.
(2) (a) (b) Details for 1994-95 and information about each scheme/program are listed below, as follows:

List 7 provides the names and addresses of grant recipients and the annual value of grants awarded by me in the context of the 1994-95 funding round under the GIA scheme with effect from 1 October 1994.

List 8 provides the names and addresses of grant recipients in the context of the 1994-95 funding round under the MAPS. The addresses of organisations which were awarded grants under both the GIA and MAPS schemes are contained in List 7 below.
List 9 provides a brief description of projects and the value of grants awarded by me in the context of the 1994-95 funding round under the MAPS with effect from 1 October 1994.
List 10 provides names and addresses of grant recipients and the value of grants awarded under the IASS.

(c) Funding is either for operational purposes—involving salary and associated costs of a worker(s)—to implement a program of settlement assistance (eg GIA, MRC) or for specific projects, negotiated with the Department (eg MAPS, Special grants). IMMIGRATION ADVISORY SERVICES SCHEME (IASS)—GRANTS AWARDED FOR 1994-95
PAYMENTS NOT COVERED BY A SPECIFIC SCHEME OR PROGRAM
Assessment and Counselling Services to Cambodian Detainees (1)

PARA.TAB: (1) (a) Victorian Foundation for the Survivors of Torture Inc., House 23, 35 Poplar Road, Parkville, Victoria, 3052
(c) The purpose of the payment was to provide assessment and counselling services to Cambodian detainees.
(e) The Director, Immigration Detention Centres Project approved the payment.
(f) Payment in full was made after services had been provided. There are no outstanding acquittals.
(2) (a)-(f) Not applicable.
(1) (a) Refugee Council of Australia, 69-71 Parramatta Road Camperdown, NSW
(b) Funding of $110,210 was approved to carry out five projects, with a component of $22,008 as a contribution to core funding.
(c) The five projects are as follows:

(i) Identify the information needs of people lodging nominations under the Humanitarian Program with the aim of meeting gaps in information provision. Report on and identify possible actions to address the findings.
(ii) Participation as a member for the advisory committee to the Country Information Service.

(iii) Undertake a program to facilitate and encourage member agencies to take a pro-active outreach to new arrivals under the Humanitarian Program, with particular attention being given to those without established community groups already in Australia.
(iv) Develop a community education strategy designed to promote Australian efforts for refugees in order to gain wider public support for them.
(v) Develop a strategy for promoting the enlistment of additional Community Refugee Support Scheme (CRSS) groups. Assist in the development of a regular CRSS newsletter.
(e) I approved the funding in September 1993.

(f) The Refugee Council of Australia is required to submit quarterly progress and financial reports. An audited statement of receipts and expenditure is required within 3 months of the completion of the funding period. There are no outstanding acquittals.
(2) The grant described in (1) is a calendar year grant and so continues in the 1994-95 financial year.

PARA.TAB: (1) (a) Victorian Foundation for Survivors of Torture Inc, PO Box 96, Parkville, Victoria, 3052
(c) To provide assessment and counselling services for Cambodian detainees in Westbridge Detention Centre.
(e) I approved the proposal on 18 November 1993.
(f) Consultancy arrangement: initial payment of $10,000 with balance finalised after delivery of services and reporting obligations met. There is no outstanding acquittal.
(2) (a) Victorian Foundation for Survivors of Torture Inc, PO Box 96, Parkville, Victoria, 3052
(c) As for 1.
(e) As for 1.
(f) Consultancy arrangement: initial payment of $5,000 with balance finalised after delivery of services and reporting obligations met. There is no outstanding acquittal.

(c) To establish and maintain a register of "Offers of Support" for applicants to the Cambodian Special Assistance Category (SAC) who may return to Australia
(e) I approved the proposal on 18 November 1993
(f) Consultancy arrangement: payment finalised after delivery of services and reporting obligations met. There is no outstanding acquittal for contracted period.
(2) The following details payments for 1994-95 financial year:
(a) Refugee Council of Australia (Inc in ACT), Locked Bag 15, Camperdown PO, NSW, 2050
(c) To maintain a register of "Offers of Support" for applicants to the Cambodian SAC who may return to Australia

(f) Consultancy arrangement: payment made for services up to 8/6/94. Services provided from 9/6/94 to date cost in the vicinity of $500.00. Payment for future services will be negotiated with service providers.

ANSWER.PARA: Application Assistance to Asylum Seekers in the Community

PARA.TAB: (1) (a) Refugee Council of Australia, 69-71 Parramatta Road, Camperdown PO, NSW, 2050
(c) To assist asylum seekers in the community with the preparation and presentation of their refugee status claims before the Department and the Refugee Review Tribunal.

(e) Payment was subject to Budget appropriation and Ministerial approval. Contractual arrangements were finalised in June 1994 for provision of the service. Funding was met by the Department on a quarterly in advance basis.
(f) Audited financial year reporting, including reporting on performance activity, is required. Reports for 1993-94 have yet to be received.

(2) (a)-(f) Pro rata continuation until December 1994 of the 1993-94 arrangements, at a cost of $186,284, is being undertaken. The scope and level of further funding of application assistance to be provided asylum seekers in the community in 1994-95 is under consideration. If continued in 1994-95 the service agreement will be with the Refugee Advice and Casework Service of 161 Fitzroy Street, St Kilda, Victoria, which has assumed responsibility, from the Refugee Council of Australia, for dealing direct with the Commonwealth.

ANSWER.PARA: Application Assistance to Asylum Seekers in Detention

PARA.TAB: (1) (a) Refugee Council of Australia, 69-71 Parramatta Road, Camperdown PO, NSW, 2050
(c) To assist unauthorised boat arrivals in detention with the preparation and presentation of their refugee status claims before the Department and the Refugee Review Tribunal.
(e) Payments were approved by Departmental officers under project agreements with service providers.
(f) Acquittals are required for all service delivery to boat arrivals. Acquittals are current to July 1994.

(2) (a)-(f) An interim contract with the Refugee Advice and Casework Service of 161 Fitzroy Street, St Kilda, Victoria, a subsidiary organisation to the Refugee Council of Australia, has been set in place for 1994-95. The contract requires the provision of refugee application assistance to boat arrivals and to all other asylum seekers in detention. The Refugee Advice and Casework Service has assumed responsibility for dealing direct with the Commonwealth.
$833,000 has been allocated for this service in 1994-95. Financial and performance reporting will be required. An open tender process for the provision of this service is under way.

ANSWER.PARA: Assistance in Meeting Living Expenses for Asylum Seekers in the Community

PARA.TAB: (1) (a) The Australian Red Cross Society, 206 Clarendon Street, East Melbourne, Victoria, 3002
(c) To provide assistance with meeting the basic food and shelter requirements and medical expenses associated with urgent and/or life threatening medical conditions for asylum seekers.
(e)The Government authorised a formal agreement with the Australian Red Cross Society to deliver the asylum seeker assistance for the Department in 1993-94. This has been renewed for 1994-95.

(f) Comprehensive monthly reports of expenditure and recipient numbers are provided to the Department under the formal agreement with the Red Cross. In addition, audited financial statements for 1993-94 are required by 30 September 1994.
(2) (a) The Australian Red Cross Society, 206 Clarendon Street, East Melbourne, Victoria, 3002
(c) As for 1.
(e) As for 1.
(f) As for 1 but with audited annual statements for 1994-95 due by 30 September 1995.

ANSWER.PARA: Bureau of Immigration and Population Research—1993-94 Research Program
