ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Grants to Trade Unions and Community Groups

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy the following question on notice on 23 August 1994:

PARA.TAB: (1) Has the department, or any of its agencies or statutory authorities, approved or made available any grants, or other forms of payments, to trade unions or community groups in the 1993-94 financial year; if so, in each case: (a) what is the name and address of the trade union or community group which received the funds; (b) what was the amount involved; (c) what was the purpose of the payment; (d) under what program was the payment made; (e) who approved the payment; and (f) what acquittal requirements are there pertaining to the payment, and are there any outstanding acquittals.

(2) Has the department, or any of its agencies or statutory authorities, approved, made available, or does it intend to make available, any grants, or other forms of payments, to trade unions or community groups in the 1994-95 financial year; if so, in each case, please provide details as per (1)(a) to (f).

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: Grants and other forms of payments were made to a number of community groups (and some trade unions) through 14 different programs within my portfolio. I have provided information on these payments by program.

PARA.TAB: (1)Community groups which received funds in 1993-94:
(a)see Attachment A.
(b)see Attachment A.
(c)see Attachment A.
(d)The payment was paid under the Rural Access Program (RAP).
(e) The Minister for Primary Industries and Energy;
The First Assistant Secretary, Rural Division, Department of Primary Industries and Energy;
The Director, (44A Delegate), Rural Access & Communities Section, Rural Division, Department of Primary Industries & Energy.

(f) Grant projects at Attachment A are still under administration and acquittal requirements pertaining to the payments are therefore still outstanding. Progress reports are required to be submitted by grantees on both the administration and financial aspects of projects.

On completion of the project, grantees are required to submit a final report together with a financial report stating how funds were spent and certified by a qualified public accountant or, if less than $10 000 accompanied by a Statutory Declaration.

(2) The Rural Access Program (RAP) intends to make available grants to Community Groups in the 1994-95 financial year. These grants will be approved and made available on the basis shown above. There will be two assessment rounds in 1994-95 and successful applicants will be approved and notified of their success in December 1994 and April 1995.

(c) Through the BARA Program the Commonwealth provides incorporated local community groups with up to $50,000 to meet part of the costs of employing a business facilitator. The facilitator assists local communities to diversify, stabilise, and expand income opportunities by assisting local entrepreneurial capacity, fostering business talent and ideas and improving individual and rural economic diversification. BARA is a collaborative program that relies on three levels of cooperation and resources: Commonwealth government; State/NT government; and the local community.

(1) In 1993-94 the Department of Primary Industries and Energy (DPIE) made payments through the National Landcare Program totalling approximately $7.12 million to community organisations and groups for 583 community landcare orientated projects. Payments for the community landcare projects were made to the groups indirectly through State or Territory agencies, whereas City Landcare and national component payments were made directly to the group concerned. The payments were made for a range of projects to improve natural resource management including community education and awareness, resource surveying and mapping, planning, investigations and trials, training, monitoring and demonstration activities.

ANSWER.PARA: The community landcare group projects, which represented all of those submitted which were eligible under the Program guidelines, were approved by the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy following advice from community based State Assessment Panels and from the DPIE. City Landcare and national projects were approved following advice from working groups of officials.

Payments were approved by officers of the DPIE so authorised under Section 4(2) of the Natural Resources Management (Financial Assistance) Act 1992. Project managers are required to provide financial statements of expenditure by 30 September of the financial year following payment, or as soon as practicable thereafter.

The specific details at individual project level sought under (a), (b) and (c) are contained in Attachment I, except for the community group addresses. Addresses for all groups have not been consolidated at this time but are held on project application forms: details of specific groups can be provided by DPIE if required.

PARA.TAB: (2) For the 1994-95 financial year some 589 community landcare group projects totalling some $8.10 million have been approved by the Minister. Details of these projects are contained in Attachment J. Payments are currently in the process of being made under the arrangements outlined above. Some of these projects will receive corporate or private sponsorship which will reduce the level of their NLP allocation.

Description:To provide specialist outreach services from the Downs Syndrome Association to address issues concerning families and schools with children who have Downs Syndrome and associated conditions.
Project:Drugs and the Family—A Community Approach

Description:To increase parents/parent workers understanding of drug issues and gain up-to-date information by participating in workshops dealing with positive parenting strategies around drug-related issues. To increase access to community referral and support services.

Description:To heighten the community's awareness of health related issues and how to deal with them. To provide a health screening program, target potential and identify health problems, and to provide a focus for community involvement in Ensay. Project complete (grantee withdrew).
Description:To develop support groups and networks through community workers for people with epilepsy and their carers in northern Queensland aiming to create a better understanding and service.
Project:Bringing Arts and Crafts to Ceduna and Districts
Description:To provide low-cost craft workshops, conducted by professional tutors to rural women in the Ceduna region of SA, increasing their skills and potential income.

Description:To provide access to women, particularly from a non-English speaking background, for mammograms at Toowoomba Breast Screening Clinic and a support group for women interested in this project.
Description:To conduct courses in practical skills such as cooking, budgeting, shopping etc for physically and intellectually disabled people to equip them for independent living.
Description:To establish and maintain a toy library for Gnowangerup and the surrounding districts which would particularly benefit low income and Aboriginal families.

Description:To provide increased professional support assistance for victims of domestic violence. The court-based service will provide personal support at court, information, referral and advocacy services.
Project:Shoalhaven Suicide Prevention Network Education Program.
Description:To conduct professionally run workshops on suicide prevention in the Shoalhaven area aimed at health professionals, Aboriginal people and the community.
Description:To publish a monthly article in the regional newspaper informing the community of courses, programs and services available through the Horsham Community House.

Description:To extend the services of the Horsham Learning Centre by employing an outreach coordinator to organise a program of courses in the Dunmunkle Shire and network with community members and providers of adult education.
Project:Medical Education in Rural Communities Without a Pharmacy
Description:To provide a series of workshops on the use of medication in rural towns without a local pharmacy to minimise misuse, particularly for at risk patients.
Project:Hyden & Districts Community Resource Centre Access Program

Description:To increase access to education and training courses, particularly post-secondary courses, professional and personal development and improve business opportunities through the establishment of a community resource centre.
Project:Respite Care of Families with Children with Disabilities—Video
Description:To produce a video about caring for children with disabilities and inform parents, carers and service providers of support services such as respite care.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Organisation:Kempsey Toy and Leisure Library Inc

ANSWER.PARA: Description:To provide a mobile extension of services from the central

PARA.TAB: Kempsey Toy and Leisure Library to geographically and/or
culturally isolated residents of Kempsey Shire including
Aboriginal and disabled peoples.

ANSWER.PARA: Description:To develop a Birthing Services Directory to provide much needed information on health and support services available to rural women and their families in the region.
Project:Practical Support Groups for Young Children with Disabilities

Description:To provide weekly group sessions for young children with disabilities and their parents in the Grenfell area. The sessions will provide age/ability based educational play activities to stimulate children and give ideas for parents to continue at home.
Description:To conduct a men's health seminar dealing with awareness of signs and symptoms of testicular cancer and management and control of stress for men in the Leongatha area.

Description:To improve access to Early Intervention for children from 0-6yrs with disabilities and learning difficulties in the districts surrounding Forbes, such as Condobolin, Tullamore, Peak Hill and Parkes.
Description:To extend a current community newsletter to more people in the Roebourne shire.

Description:To produce a resource kit for young women on health issues through consultation with young women's advisory groups in the Loddon/Campaspe Mallee regions. The project aims to provide a model useful for other rural localities.

Description:To collate, print and distribute a directory of services in the Clarence Valley for 15-24 year olds. Services included will be local, regional and state and cover areas such as health, education, recreation, training, employment, accommodation, transport, financial, crisis, legal and services for Aboriginal people.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Organisation:Mackay Air Sea Rescue Squad Inc

ANSWER.PARA: Description:To provide a navigation pack consisting of sufficient navigational equipment to conduct training classes for ten persons.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Organisation:Mackay Women's Health and Info Centre

ANSWER.PARA: Project:Stress Management Program for Regional/Rural Women
Description:To provide a stress management program through a series of workshops outreaching to women in the Mackay regional and rural area.

Description:To conduct personal development workshops for women of the South Australian Mallee, giving greater access to information and establishing a network between small communities and isolated families.
Description:To provide fortnightly information sessions and discussion groups on a wide range of women's health issues, services and information.
Description:To hold a two day workshop on parenting, designed for parents of teenage children, which aims to reduce the problems experienced in raising teenage children.

Description:To conduct a two-day choral workshop in Bellingen providing training in choral skills and musical understanding, promote choral singing as a recreation, inspire local people of all ages and develop social networks.
Project:Asbestos Related Diseases Family Support Project

Description:To employ a community development worker to liaise with individuals and families affected by asbestos related diseases. The worker will provide support, education and information on all issues affecting these individuals/families in the region.
Description:To process raw wool, supplied by ten WA merino studs, through to fabric for use by design students in the Woolworks Design Awards and Exhibition.
Description:To conduct classes on pregnancy, childbirth and parenting for rural women in Mooroopna, building on a successful trial program and aiming to establish support groups for the participants.
Description:To conduct information and education sessions on women's health including breast examination, pap smears, conflict resolution, family relationships and menopause in the Moranbah area.
Description:To conduct a tour of lectures/information talks about Motor Neurone Disease to health professionals, service groups, patients and families in rural and remote areas of Western Australia.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Organisation:Mudgee and District Crossroads Christian Fellowship for Disabled

ANSWER.PARA: Project:Crossroads Social and Recreational Activity for the Disabled

Description:To run a weekend camp and bus trips for the disabled; to provide recreational equipment suitable for people with physical or intellectual disabilities to develop motorskills, social skills and for recreation and produce a newsletter.

Description:To reduce the sense of isolation experienced by NESB women, and assist, where necessary, the access of NESB people to Government and Non-Government services. Project will establish a support network and provide a model for further application in other non-urban areas.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Organisation:Multiple Sclerosis Society of WA Inc

ANSWER.PARA: Project:Information and Education on Multiple Sclerosis
Description:To produce an information video on Multiple Sclerosis for health workers and newly diagnosed people with MS in rural and remote WA.

Description:To provide basic skills development and training for voluntary museum workers in rural Victoria in the areas of—Collection Management, Exhibition and Interpretation, Conservation and Education.
Project:A Guide to Counselling Services for Families in Crisis

Description:To provide an in-depth, easy to read and understand guide, in English and Italian, listing counselling services available for families in crisis, with particular emphasis on non-English speaking background (Italian) communities in NE Victoria.

Description:To provide programs for rural women in four separate locations covering personal development, information, referral and advocacy service, and community education on specific social issues. One program is specifically targeting Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander women.
Project:Attention Deficit Disorder Information and Action Project

Description:To produce an information booklet of local and state resources which provide services and facilities for children with Attention Deficit Disorder (ADD) and their families; to run three self-esteem camps for children with ADD; and to conduct art groups for children with ADD.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Organisation:New School of Arts Neighbourhood House Inc

ANSWER.PARA: Description:To overcome the problems of rural isolation by providing Outreach Adult Learning Courses to outlying districts.
Description:To extend an existing newsletter providing information on activities and services available to Nhulunbuy and the surrounding region.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Organisation:Noosa District Family and Youth Support Centre Inc

ANSWER.PARA: Description:To assist parents in raising their teenagers by demonstrating different methods of parenting, and by providing a self-esteem program for the teenagers.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Organisation:Northern Territory Anti Cancer Foundation Inc

ANSWER.PARA: Description:To increase the accessibility of the services provided by the Foundation to four remote towns in the NT. Training agents will facilitate public education campaigns, provide education sessions on cancer awareness and be a central access point for cancer support groups.
Project:NT Isolated Children's Parents' Association Newsletter
Description:To produce and distribute a quarterly Newsletter to geographically isolated families.
Project:Nulla Nulla Womens Craft Centre Group
Description:To train community members, particularly women, in ceramics, silk screening, sewing skills, etc and thereby increase employment opportunities.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Organisation:The Paraplegic and Quadriplegic Association of Queensland Inc

ANSWER.PARA: Project:Spinal Education Awareness Team Visit to Remote and Rural QLD
Description:To visit 18 schools in a remote area of Queensland and deliver a program which aims to prevent, through education, spinal cord and other serious injuries.

Description:To coordinate provision of information and training to the community of Peterborough and surrounding districts, especially targeting isolated women, Aboriginal people, people with disabilities and unemployed people, through tailor-made packages.

Description:To provide education and training to women, carers and people with disabilities in the areas of effective communication, the implementation of home programs, self esteem and parenting skills.
Project:Community Health Awareness and Education Program
Description:To promote awareness about sexually transmitted diseases and nutrition in the Pormpur Paanth Aboriginal community through education and the use of local language.
Description:To develop, produce and distribute mental health promotional material to rural communities about mental health service organisations and to provide education about mental health.
Project:Managing Ag Chemical Use—Assistance for Ethnic Fruit Growers.
Description:To deliver information and training to fruit growers and their employees, which will allow them to use chemicals safely and responsibly.
Description:To produce and distribute a rural service directory listing local and government services for the Warrnambool community.
Description:To consolidate and expand the day-to-day operations of the Sapphire Community House and raise awareness of health, social, educational and support services available in the Shire.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Organisation:Seymour and District Neighbourhood House Inc

ANSWER.PARA: Project:Co-ordinator for Avenel Neighbourhood House Seeding Program
Description:To employ a part-time coordinator to facilitate the establishment of a Neighbourhood House and address the needs of the whole community, particularly women.
Description:To conduct an integrated program of courses and workshops covering vehicle maintenance, health, organic gardening and domestic skills for women in the Murtoa area.
Project:Coordinator for Circular Head Family Centre

Description:To expand the current playgroup facility to a drop-in centre making information and educational activities such as community house programmes, a toy library and a pregnancy support service, more accessible to the communities in the Circular Head region of Tasmania.

Description:To employ a training and development officer who will assist young people to obtain information on health, employment, education and training; plan social and other activities; and provide a contact with relevant agencies in a disadvantaged area.
Project:Marketing and Service Quality for Business in Rural Areas
Description:To provide operators and staff of small businesses in rural areas of Tasmania with education and training in marketing, quality customer services and business management.
Project:Rural Based Day Respite Program for Special Needs Children
Description:To pilot an alternative method of providing respite care for families in rural districts who have children with special needs/disabilities by offering a daytime, weekend program.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Organisation:Southern Riverina Rural Advisory Service Inc

ANSWER.PARA: Description:To conduct four stress management workshops including one follow-up day each, targeting women and the rural family as a whole, covering recognition of personal stress, safety in the workplace, health screening and information on health, counselling and educational services available.
Description:To hold a series of workshops to encourage and improve the standard of wool and craft workmanship by women in rural and remote areas.

Description:To enhance the development of child's cognitive, motor, social, sensory and language skills through individual educational programmes. The Project aims to provide home-based Early Intervention Programmes for 10 rural families of a child with a disability.
Project:NESB Information on AIDS and STDs
Description:To provide information and training on AIDS and Sexually Transmitted Diseases for people from non-English speaking backgrounds.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Organisation:Sunraysia Residential Services for Intellectually Disabled Inc

ANSWER.PARA: Description:To increase awareness of services available to non-English speaking people, aimed at informing parent/carer of the availability of services, particularly Respite Care, for son/daughter with disabilities. To provide services to remove stress on parents/carers.

Description:To provide living skills courses such as managing on a low budget, basic motor vehicle maintenance, effective parenting, home health care etc for women in the Atherton region of Queensland.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Organisation:The Tasmanian Farmers and Graziers Association

ANSWER.PARA: Description:To conduct a gathering of farm women in Tasmania to support and encourage them in the vital role they play at home and in the farm business.

Description:To raise the rural community's access to the Toowoomba Community Legal Service. Assist in the dissemination of legal information throughout south western Queensland by a series of workshops and lectures in the target areas.
Description:To assist rural migrants of non-English speaking backgrounds with cultural adaptation and access to services through workshops, information sessions and a newsletter.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Organisation:Tumby Bay and Districts Community Support and Action Group

ANSWER.PARA: Description:To employ a part-time community coordinator who will provide information on Commonwealth and State Government agency services, coordinate local activities and services in a central location and organise a computer course and workshops.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Organisation:Upper Great Southern Disability Resources Group Inc

ANSWER.PARA: Project:Upper Great Southern Disability Services Newsletter
Description:To compile and distribute a newsletter to inform people with disabilities and their families about support services in the Narrogin region.
Description:To promote greater public awareness of all facets of health by offering health service providers an opportunity to exhibit their services at a public expo in the Gippsland region.
Description:To re-establish disenfranchised farmers back into the workforce and the community in a meaningful and effective way through education, counselling and employment re-training.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Organisation:Wagga Wagga Community Resource Centre Incorporated

ANSWER.PARA: Project:Rural Carers' Guide to the City
Description:To produce an information guide to support services and facilities available in Sydney for rural patients, carers and family members of a hospitalised person.
Description:To provide access to existing West Ulverstone Community House programs for the women in the outlying district of the Kentish and Central Coast municipalities, Tasmania.
Project:Westbury Community Health Centre Information Pamphlet

Description:To produce an Information Pamphlet for community members covering the services and activities offered by the Community Health Centre, particularly for isolated rural community members with health concerns.
Project:Wheatlands Farm Safe Field Day and Men's Health Series
Description:To conduct a series of men's health awareness evenings and sessions at a farm safe field day emphasising environmental and personal farm safety practices.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Organisation:Wildlife Preservation Society of Queensland Inc

ANSWER.PARA: Description:To raise the awareness of the planning professions, including decision makers in Local, State and Commonwealth Governments, about the concerns of women living in eight rural and remote areas of Queensland through teleconference workshops.
Project:Feasibility Study for a Rural Womens Network in South Australia

Description:To prepare and publish a report, based on widespread consultation with rural women, that will identify the need for, and develop a detailed concept of how a rural womens network might operate in SA.
Project:Midwest Womens Health and Nutrition Project

Description:To conduct community information sessions on nutrition and womens health, aimed specifically at the needs of young women with clinical eating disorders and older women facing midlife health problems.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Organisation:Wynyard Local Employment & Enterprise Agency Inc

ANSWER.PARA: Description:To conduct a series of workshops for unemployed women providing information, developing self-esteem and confidence aiming for eventual self-employment or establishment as a business cooperative.

PARA.EMPHASIS: SUCCESSFUL APPLICANTS FOR GRANTS UNDER THE LOCAL ENERGY EFFICIENCY PROJECTS SCHEME

ANSWER.PARA: Purpose:To develop and run three seminars on renewable energy systems/ energy efficiency for schools, councils and community groups.
Purpose:To identify and develop a strategy/action plan to overcome impediments to the adoption of solar passive design; educate local builders and developers on the benefits of such a design.
Purpose:To design and equip energy awareness courses, including alternative technology displays.
Purpose:To implement an energy conservation scheme comprising awareness raising, seminars, workshops and energy audits for local small businesses.
Purpose:To produce, research and broadcast a series of radio programs on energy conservation; distribute to community radio stations through the national program service.
Purpose:To design and construct a standing exhibition of ecodesign to be located in new accommodation at Rozelle Public School.

Purpose:To produce an education kit promoting energy efficient building design and construction using rammed earth technology and passive solar design; distribute to schools, local community groups and other councils.
Organisation :FRIENDS OF THE EARTH SYDNEY/LEICHHARDT MUNICIPAL COUNCIL
Purpose:To design an information kit containing information on the implementation of energy efficient building design for new medium density buildings and for renovations in the inner west of Sydney.
Purpose:To provide educational workshops, on energy and environmental issues, in seven community languages for people of non-English speaking cultures.
Purpose:To design and build interactive energy information modules for use in public areas and exhibitions.
Purpose:To organise an Energy Awareness Week in Tweed Heads targetting electrical energy use in industry, commercial and residential areas.
Organisation :UNIVERSITY OF WESTERN SYDNEY-HAWKESBURY / PENRITH CITY COUNCIL

Purpose:To design, produce and distribute an information brochure containing hints on improving energy efficiency in the home; develop a policy guideline on design and construction of energy efficient housing for the Penrith City Council; arrange seminar for architects and builders.
Organisation :WESTERN REGION DEPARTMENT OF SCHOOL EDUCATION ENVIRONMENTAL EDUCATION COMMITTEE
Purpose:To develop a series of school activities for years 7-12 emphasising the importance of reducing energy waste and improving energy efficiency.

Purpose:To establish the Library as a community resource base of energy efficiency information; publicise the resource through an expo and a special children's day with associated poster competition; produce a brochure outlining the library's resources in English and Italian.
Purpose:To run a series of theatrical workshops in each of the Wyong Shire's youth centres on different energy efficiency themes; perform at a community event.
Purpose:To develop a collection of information for the community on efficient energy use and environmental issues, particularly in the Italian language; run training workshops.
Organisation :CENTRE FOR EDUCATION & RESEARCH IN ENVIRONMENTAL STRATEGIES (CERES)
Purpose:To run a campaign to promote renewable energy and extend existing educational programs on energy efficiency.
Purpose:To devise an energy conservation/waste minimisation education program targetted at local schools and industries; encourage industry to examine energy efficiency.

Purpose:To plan and develop arrangements for a Home Energy Show at which householders will be offered discounts on a range of energy efficient products; letterbox drop to households offering a special discount.
Purpose:To engage a consultant to carry out fieldwork; arrange seminar presentations of energy efficiency initiatives by councils and promote public awareness of the GECS.
Organisation :GIPPSLAND COMMUNITY RADIO SOCIETY CO-OPERATIVE LIMITED
Purpose:To produce ten 30-minute programs on energy efficiency and twenty one-minute energy hints for distribution and broadcast through the community radio network.
Organisation :HAMILTON ADULT AND CONTINUING EDUCATION INC.
Purpose:To promote application of alternative energy sources through information sessions delivered to landcare groups in the region.
Purpose:To create a model `Energy Efficiency Centre', to be used as an educational venue, incorporating information about alternative energy sources and practices.
Organisation :MELBOURNE'S LIVING MUSEUM OF THE WEST
Purpose:To produce a series of half-hour radio programs on energy efficiency to be broadcast weekly on Community Radio Station 3WRB FM.
Purpose:To run a community education campaign on the energy and cost saving benefits of recycling.
Purpose:To run a series of seven one-day environmental workshops, using energy as a common theme, for unemployed local residents.
Purpose:To run workshops for women on practical ways to implement energy efficiency in the home.
Organisation :AUSTRALIAN INSTITUTE OF BUILDING SURVEYORS—QUEENSLAND CHAPTER

Purpose:To run an information and training program in 12 Local Authorities over a 12-month period on energy efficient techniques in the built environment; run eight one-day training sessions for Local Authority building surveyors; hold a display at the Brisbane Home Show.
Purpose:To enhance an existing education program on energy and the environment by incorporating a static display of educational materials and interactive equipment.
Organisation :CAIRNS AND FAR NORTH ENVIRONMENT CENTRE INC. (CAFNEC)
Purpose:To fund a community education tour, to the Cape York region, by the CAFNEC Energy Display Trailer with working energy models and demonstration systems.
Organisation :CSIRO's DOUBLE HELIX SCIENCE CLUB—TOWNSVILLE CHAPTER
Purpose:To construct a model of an energy efficient house for the tropics and include it in a science-based display kit for schools.

Purpose:To expand the availability of the Greenhouse Lab, a purpose-built mobile laboratory for use by schools which demonstrates the potential of renewable energy, to the general public; produce associated print material.
Purpose:To establish an energy network to promote energy conservation throughout Queensland.

Purpose:To run a broad-based advertising and promotion campaign illustrating the benefits of energy efficiency and encouraging householders to take part in Light Saver—a leaseback scheme for compact fluorescent light globes.
Organisation :AUSTRALIAN AND NEW ZEALAND SOLAR ENERGY SOCIETY—SA BRANCH
Purpose:To promote the installation of solar hot water services in the Unley local government area.
Organisation :CORPORATION OF THE TOWN OF PETERBOROUGH
Purpose:To rebuild a derelict home and use as a demonstration of energy saving initiatives suitable for the local climate.
Organisation :FAR NORTH SASTA (SOUTH AUSTRALIAN SCIENCE TEACHERS ASSOCIATION)

Purpose:To devise an energy efficiency school curriculum program whereby students can carry out energy audits, analyse data, devise energy efficiency strategies, publish ideas and inform the community.
Purpose:To develop and publish a manual for professionals and tradespersons on maintenance and upgrading of solar power equipment.
Organisation :THE INVESTIGATOR SCIENCE AND TECHNOLOGY CENTRE
Purpose:To design and install, throughout the Investigator Science and Technology Centre, "Energy Spot" signs promoting energy conservation.
Purpose:To develop an energy conservation information kit aimed at local government and school resource centres.

Purpose:To co-ordinate resources to enable construction and marketing of a demonstration alternative technology building incorporating passive solar design and construction techniques, alternative energy sources and methods of reducing power consumption.

Purpose:To upgrade the Knowledge Centre's holdings of materials on energy efficiency; transfer these to a computerised system; produce two brochures containing information on the holdings for use by school children and users of public and tertiary institution libraries.
Purpose:To establish a resource conservation centre at the school for use by the local community; develop information booklets and curriculum materials.
Purpose:To run an education program on energy efficiency to raise awareness in the community of the opportunities to conserve energy through appropriate building design.
Purpose:To organise a program of energy education activities on conservation and building design, including workshops, tours and building energy audits.
Organisation :NEDLANDS ELDERLY PERSONS HOME SUPPORT SERVICE
Purpose:To run a program for aged persons in which advice and information on energy efficiency and energy audits will be provided.
Organisation :GEORGE TOWN PRIMARY SCHOOL/GEORGE TOWN COUNCIL RECYCLING COMMITTEE

Purpose:To involve the entire school community in a community recycling scheme with the school as the central storage and cycling facility. To broaden the reach of the scheme to involve neighbouring communities.
Purpose:To carry out an energy audit and survey of households and businesses on the Tasman and Forestier Peninsulas; develop an Efficient Energy Plan.
Organisation :ROYAL AUSTRALIAN INSTITUTE OF ARCHITECTS—TASMANIAN CHAPTER
Purpose:To co-ordinate a group of speakers to conduct a series of seminars on `the energy efficient home' over a six months period; produce handouts for seminars.
Purpose:To organise 10 activity-based workshops to encourage individuals, businesses and governments to practice energy efficiency.
Organisation :AUSTRALIAN AND NEW ZEALAND SOLAR ENERGY SOCIETY (ANZSES) ACT
Purpose:To run a series of 3-hour workshops for members of the ACT community on how to improve the thermal efficiency of existing houses.
Purpose:To run information/discussion sessions on energy issues for local community organisations; produce an energy handbook and an energy poster.
Organisation :NORTHERN TERRITORY UNIVERSITY—FACULTY OF BUSINESS—PROGRAM IN HOSPITALITY AND TOURISM
Purpose:To prepare a book and educational material on energy management in tourism and the hospitality industry in the NT; prepare seminars; develop a long-range energy management education plan.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Industrial Relations: Grants to Trade Unions and Community Groups

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Industrial Relations, upon notice, on 24 August 1994:

PARA.TAB: (1) Has the department, or any of its agencies or statutory authorities, approved or made available any grants, or other form of payments, to trade unions or community groups in the 1993-94 financial year; if so, in each case: (a) what is the name and address of the trade union or community group which received the funds; (b) what was the amount involved; (c) what was the purpose of the payment; (d) under what program was the payment made; (e) who approved the payment; and (f) what acquittal requirements are there pertaining to the payment, and are there any outstanding acquittals.

(2) Has the department, or any of its agencies or statutory authorities, approved, made available, or does it intend to make available, any grants, or other form of payments, to trade unions or community groups in the 1994-95 financial year; if so, in each case, please provide details as per (1) (a) to (f).

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Industrial Relations has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: Details of grants or other form of payments approved by my Department and its agencies in the 1993/94 financial year and so far in the 1994/95 financial year are provided in the attached tables. Addresses not listed in the tables are contained in the attached extract from the 1994 ACTU National Union Directory, and additional copies are available from the Senate Table Office.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Environment, Sport and Territories: Grants to Trade Unions and Community Groups

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories, upon notice, on 23 August 1994:

PARA.TAB: (1) Has the department, or any of its agencies or statutory authorities, approved or made available any grants, or other forms of payments, to trade unions or community groups in the 1993-94 financial year; if so, in each case: (a) what is the name and address of the trade union or community group which received the funds; (b) what was the amount involved; (c) what was the purpose of the payment; (d) under what program was the payment made; (e) who approved the payment; and (f) what acquittal requirements are there pertaining to the payment, and are there any outstanding acquittals.

(2) Has the department, or any of its agencies or statutory authorities, approved, made available, or does it intend to make available, any grants, or other forms of payments, to trade unions or community groups in the 1994-95 financial year, if so, in each case, please provide details as per (1)(a) to (f).

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Faulkner Sen J.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) (a)(b)(c)(d) & (e) The information is not readily available in the level of detail that has been sought. I am not prepared to allocate resources to obtain this information but I have provided information that is accessible to my departmental and portfolio agencies which addresses much of the details sought.
Grants were made under the following grant categories to community organisations during 1993-94:
Biodiversity
Coastal Management
Community Cultural, Recreation and Sporting Facilities Program
Climate Change
Ecologically Sustainable Development
Environmental Economics
Environmental Management
Forests
Grants to Voluntary Conservation Organisations
Rangelands Management
Water Quality
Contract Employment Program for Aboriginals in Natural and Cultural Resource Management (CEPANCRM)
Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Authority Grants
National Estate Grants Program
Ocean Rescue 2000
One Billion Trees Program (OBT)
Save the Bush Program (STB)
Copies of documents detailing grant payments under the above programs have been forwarded to the honourable senator. Further copies are available from the Senate Table Office.

(f) There is a general requirement placed on recipients under these grant programs to account back to the grant provider on the expenditure of grant moneys. Acquittance is either at progressive stages or at the end of the grant period and is generally in the form of a certified statement of expenditure. These acquittance requirements are stipulated in each grant agreement.
(2) Details of grant payments have not yet been finalised for the 1994-95 financial year.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Communications and the Arts, upon notice,

PARA.TAB: (1) What capacity does Telecom have to deal with emergencies such as the storm which crippled the City of Perth and surrounding suburbs on 23 May 1994.
(2) Did the diversion of 1.7 million calls to a busy tone cause a near melt down of local Telecom services.
(3) Who authorised such a diversion.
(4) Whose responsibility was it to inform the public of such a decision.
(5) Why was the public not informed of the decision by Telecom.
(6) Was the Minister aware, prior to the storm, that the capacity of Telecom in Western Australia to deal with a crisis was severely limited.
(7) What steps will be taken to ensure that the people of Western Australia have adequate access to emergency services through telecommunications in the event of a similar crisis occurring again.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Communications and the Arts has provided the following answer on the advice of Telecom to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) I am informed by Telecom that occurrences such as the May storms in Perth have the potential to generate extraordinary volumes of calls to organisations such as the State Electricity Corporation of Western Australia (SECWA). Such volumes can exceed the levels allowed for in the design of that organisation's call answering facilities.

Telecom advises me that during the period of the storm and its aftermath some 2 million calls were made to the SECWA emergency centre number and only a small proportion could be answered by all available SECWA operators.

In an emergency situation, when Telecom recognises that such levels are likely to be exceeded, standard network management procedures are invoked in consultation with the organisation being affected. To prevent all the busy tones emanating from the organisation's local exchange, these procedures allow Telecom to provide a busy tone at the caller's local exchange for a proportion of the calls to that organisation's number. This procedure reduces the possibility of network congestion occurring, whilst still permitting callers to contact emergency services such as Fire, Police or Ambulance. These steps were taken by Telecom in consultation with the SECWA management on the occasion of the Perth storms on 23 May this year.
(2) No. Telecom advises that the Telecom network continued to operate satisfactorily enabling all other callers to contact emergency services during this period.
(3) Telecom advises that the Standard Network Management procedures that were invoked by Telecom on 23 May 1994, were undertaken in consultation with the SECWA management.

(4) & (5) Telecom advises that when its customers such as SECWA have difficulty in handling a large volume of calls, Telecom believes that it is SECWA's responsibility to inform the public if such action is considered to be necessary.
(6) Telecom advises that its network has adequate capacity to deal with crises such as the May storms.

(7) I am advised by Telecom that it is satisfied that the capacity of the Telecom network was sufficient to deal with this emergency. It is Telecom's understanding that SECWA has reviewed its emergency call operator procedures and resource plans after the May 1994 experience.
